There needs to be an in between for reviews because this game would need it. Resident evil 3, unlike the remakes of 1,2 and 4, which were direct remakes, is actually more of a reimagining, of resident evil 3 nemesis. It removes many areas of the game like the whole park and clock tower sections, and the gas station segment, but does add bits like the subway and new areas like a toy store. Jill no longer explores the RPD but instead Carlos does. The story has basically been "arranged". Think of it like a retelling or what if. I don't hate the game, because this version of Jill is pretty cool, and I like the city and the gameplay, and liked the story, but hated how they removed so much. Over 50% of resident evil 3 nemesis was removed in this remake. It's insane. Get it on sale.

Resident Evil 3 Remake is a fantastic modern retelling of the 1999 classic, offering a gripping survival horror experience. With stunning graphics, tight controls, and a compelling story following protagonist Jill Valentine as she navigates a zombie-infested Raccoon City, the game is a must-play for any horror fan. The Nemesis, an ever-present antagonist, adds an extra layer of challenge and fear. Whether you're a long-time fan of the series or new to survival horror, Resident Evil 3 Remake is an intense and memorable experience that will keep you on the edge of your seat.

7/10 / Spoilers duh. I haven't played the original in god knows how long so i wont be comparing it to the original RE3 because of my dogshit memory. Personally, I thought it was pretty decent. 
PROS: The city section was really fun and had a lot of good scares, I love how unpredictable Nemesis is compared to Mr. X in RE2. See he was something, but Nemesis here nearly made me shit my pants a couple times. / All of the written notes and documents were really interesting. In the end, 7/10. I enjoyed it more than most people probably, but I love all Resident Evil games (lets pretend RE6 doesn't exist)

The game feels too scripted. Zombies are placed along linear pathways, often surprise attacking with little chance for evasion. It really feels like there's little room for choice during gameplay. On repeat playthroughs, this linearity becomes very apparent, with many sequence feeling like a repetitive cycle of holding the W key, skipping cutscenes, and repeating this process.

The dodge mechanic feels underwhelming and almost useless outside of perfect dodges. It's often tough to time dodges for certain attacks, leading to unnecessary frustration and damage. Additionally, QTEs triggered when grabbed by zombies feel pointless, as you still take damage regardless of success, a clear step down from RE2's defensive items.

The treatment of Nemesis is disappointing. Compared to the presence of Mr. X in Resident Evil 2 Remake, Nemesis feels lackluster and scripted. The chase sequences, intended to instill fear and tension, fall flat as Nemesis's movements are hard to predict and lack the eerie audio cues that made Mr. X encounters so memorable. Instead of feeling like a relentless pursuer, Nemesis often comes across as a teleporting enemy that tentacle whips you.

Title: "Resident Evil 3 Remake: Dodging Zombies and Dodging My Own Screams"

Review:
If you've ever wanted to know what it's like to simultaneously sprint through a city overrun by zombies while also trying not to spill your coffee, Resident Evil 3 Remake has got you covered. Capcom's latest undead adventure is like a rollercoaster ride through Raccoon City, where the only thing scarier than the monsters lurking around every corner is the realization that you forgot to stock up on ammo.

Let's start with the protagonist, Jill Valentine. She's like the MacGyver of survival horror, turning every found item into a makeshift weapon with the finesse of a seasoned ninja. Seriously, forget about stocking up on rocket launchers – all you need is a trusty knife and a can-do attitude to take down those brain-hungry baddies.

And speaking of baddies, Nemesis deserves a special shoutout. This guy is like the Terminator on steroids, relentlessly pursuing you with all the determination of someone who just really wants a hug... or to rip your face off. Either way, it's hard not to admire his dedication to the art of zombie hunting.

But let's not forget about the real star of the show: Raccoon City itself. From the eerily quiet streets to the dimly lit alleyways, every corner of this urban nightmare is dripping with atmosphere. It's like a postcard from hell – if hell had a serious rat problem and a penchant for jump scares.

Of course, no Resident Evil game would be complete without its fair share of puzzles, and RE3 Remake doesn't disappoint. Whether you're deciphering cryptic codes or hunting down elusive keys, there's always something to keep your brain scratching while your trigger finger gets a workout.

In conclusion, Resident Evil 3 Remake is a pulse-pounding thrill ride from start to finish. With its heart-stopping action, spine-tingling scares, and enough zombie guts to fill a swimming pool, it's a must-play for any survival horror fan. Just don't forget to pack your nerves of steel – you're gonna need 'em.

[i]Review written in both french and english.[/i]

[h1]Français :[/h1]
Heureusement que je n'ai pas payé pour avoir le jeu, j'ai beau m'être éclatée dessus, je le trouve quand même extrêmement court pour son prix... Je précise aussi que je n'ai jamais joué à l'original, donc je ne pourrais pas faire de comparatif avec en terme de gameplay.

[h3]Points positifs :[/h3]
- Comme pour les remakes de Resident Evil 2 et Resident Evil 4, les graphismes sont magnifiques, même en qualité lowest.
- Le jeu est bien optimisé, c'est même probablement le mieux optimisé de tous les remakes jusqu'à présent.
- On peut jouer à la manette, mais ceux qui utilisent une manette de PS4 devront passer par le gestionnaire de contrôleur Steam, étant donné que le jeu ne détecte que les manettes de Xbox. C'est un problème qui était déjà présent dans Resident Evil 2 et je sais pas pourquoi ça n'a toujours pas été patché.
- J'aime beaucoup les design des personnages, mais je trouve que Carlos est quand-même... très différent de son modèle original.
- Les esquives de Jill et les patates de forain de Carlos sont des mécaniques plutôt bien pensées. Elles sont difficiles à caler au début, mais ça devient amusant une fois qu'on a trouvé le bon timing.
- Le jeu est très (trop) généreux en terme de munitions, à tel point que je me suis rapidement retrouvée à saturer tellement j'en avais dans mon inventaire.
- Le doublage français est plutôt réussi.

[h3]Points négatifs :[/h3]
- La durée de vie est médiocre. J'ai pu terminer le jeu en à peine 7h alors que je me suis pourtant forcer à ne pas trop courir pour éviter d'être trop déçue. Et j'ai quand-même été déçue.
- Le jeu n'offre pas la possibilité de changer la bande sonore. Ce n'est pas quelque chose qui me dérange puisque l'audio du remake me convient, mais ça peut déplaire aux grands nostalgiques.
- Certaines animations sont inexistantes. Par exemple, Jill n'a pas d'animation pour allumer sa lampe de poche, ni pour utiliser les ascenseurs en end-game. Ça reste un point négatif mineur étant donné que ça n'a pas d'impact sur le gameplay, mais ça montre bien que le développement a été rushé à certains moments.
- Le boss de fin est assez décevant. Je vais éviter de spoiler mais c'est littéralement le plus simple du jeu alors que les trois premiers étaient assez chauds à faire.
- Un autre problème qui était déjà présent dans Resident Evil 2, c'est que les armes ne servent pas souvent à grand chose. Le fusil d'assaut est moins puissant qu'un pistolet, le lance-grenades / lance-mines est franchement anecdotique et le magnum ne s'obtient que 30 minutes avant la fin du jeu, donc on n'a même pas le temps d'en profiter et il est complètement inutile face au boss de fin.
- Le couteau n'a plus du tout de durabilité. Certains trouveront que ça fait un truc en moins à gérer par rapport à Resident Evil 2, mais je trouve que ça rend le jeu un peu plus ennuyeux étant donné qu'on peut juste foutre les zombies à terre et les achever au couteau.
- Comme pour Resident Evil 2, le système de sauvegardes automatiques est moins utile que les sauvegardes manuelles.
- Un jeu Resident Evil sans puzzle, c'est un crime.

J'ai vu beaucoup de gens se plaindre que le jeu n'était rien d'autre qu'un jeu d'action, mais je ne trouve pas que ça soit vraiment le cas. Après avoir éclaté la cervelle de tous les zombies, on peut se balader et explorer librement, exactement comme dans Resident Evil 2. Au final, les deux jeux ne sont pas non plus si différents que ça, même si ça se ressent que Capcom a voulu varier un peu le gameplay en offrant des mouvements spécifiques à chaque personnage (esquives / coups de poing) là où Leon n'en avait pas. Ce qui est dommage, c'est que ce genre de jeu a tendance à rapidement se transformer en jeu d'action sans laisser réellement de place à l'horreur et c'est quelque chose que je reproche aussi bien à ce jeu là qu'à Resident Evil 2 et Resident Evil 4. Enfin, ça reste un bon jeu et, même si je ne saurais pas dire ce qu'il vaut par rapport à l'original, je peux quand même affirmer qu'il est trop court pour son prix et je conseille d'attendre une période de promotion pour l'acheter.

[hr][/hr]
[h1]English:[/h1]
Good thing I didn't pay to get the game, although I had a blast with it, I still find it extremely short for its price... I should also point out that I never played the original , so I can't make a comparison with it in terms of gameplay.

[h3]Positive points:[/h3]
- Just like with the remakes of Resident Evil 2 and Resident Evil 4, the graphics are magnificent, even at lowest quality.
- The game is well optimized, it's probably the best optimized of all the remakes so far.
- You can play with a controller, but those using a PS4 controller will have to go through the Steam controller manager, since the game only detects Xbox controllers. This is a problem that was already present in Resident Evil 2 and I don't know why it hasn't been patched yet.
- I really like the character designs, but I think that Carlos is... a bit too different from his original model.
- Jill's dodges and Carlos's sucker punches are rather well thought out mechanics. They are difficult to time at first, but it becomes fun once you get the timing right.
- The game is very (too) generous with how much ammunition it gives you, so much so that I quickly found myself saturating with the ones I had in my inventory.

[h3]Negative points:[/h3]
- The game's lifespan is very short. I was able to complete the game in barely 7 hours even though I forced myself to not run too much to avoid being disappointed. And I was still disappointed.
- The game does not offer the possibility to change the audio. It's not something that bothers me since the audio of the remake suits me, but it may displease the most nostalgic fans.
- Some animations are non-existent. For example, Jill does not have an animation to turn on her flashlight, nor to use the elevators in the end-game. This remains a minor negative point given that it has no impact on the gameplay, but it shows that development was rushed at certain times.
- The end boss is quite disappointing. I'm not going to spoil it too much, but it's literally the easiest in the game while the first three were quite difficult to do.
- Another problem that was already present in Resident Evil 2 is that weapons are often not useful. The assault rifle is less powerful than a pistol, the grenade launcher/mine launcher is kinda anecdotal and the magnum is only obtained 30 minutes before the end of the game, so you don't even have time to have fun with it and it is completely useless against the end boss.
- The knife no longer has any durability. Some will think that it's one less thing to manage compared to Resident Evil 2, but I personally believe that it makes the game a little more boring since you can just knock the zombies to the ground and finish them off with the knife.

- A Resident Evil game without any puzzle is a crime.

What's a shame is that this type of game has a tendency to quickly turn into an action game without really leaving any room for horror and that's something I noticed for every Resident Evil remake so far. In the end, it remains a good game and, even if I cannot say what it is worth compared to the original, I can still confirm that it is too short for its price and I advise waiting for a promo to buy it.

RE3 Remake:
Plus Points:
1. There are many new locations outside the RPD building in Uptown and Downtown that can be explored. The city feels vast and realistic, with the addition of shops like donut shops and drugstore that were not present in the PSX version.
2. The action and duels with Nemesis are plentiful and more challenging.
3. The antagonist character, Nicholai Ginovaef, is highlighted more in this remake, and the storyline is clearer compared to the PSX version.

Minus:
1. Many main story settings from the PSX version are eliminated in the Remake. Even if they are included, they are passed by quickly. For example, in the PSX version, there are stories in the Clock Tower and Raccoon City Park.
The sequence in PSX is : Uptown - RPD - Downtown - Clock Tower - Raccoon City Park - Hospital - Lab. 
But in the remake, it is : Uptown - RPD - Downtown - Hospital - Lab. 
The stories in the Clock Tower and Raccoon City Park are skipped and lost. The player only briefly passes in front of the Clock Tower and immediately fights Nemesis there without even entering Clock Tower at all. And there is no Racoon City Park at all like in PSX version.
2. The Live Selection feature (when encountering Nemesis and being able to choose the storyline path) is removed in this version. This feature was what made RE3 on PSX exciting, as the choices made determined different storylines.
3. Many exciting and difficult puzzles (such as the Base Vaccine puzzle in the PSX version's laboratory) are removed. The puzzles in the remake are not as challenging as in the PSX version.
4. Because Racoon City Park is not exist in this remake version, so you can't meet and fight with monster Grave Digger.

Overall 7/10

In all seriousness, this game is the low point of Modern/Reboot RE games. Doesn't even remotely hold a candle to the original game. I could go on for paragraphs about why, but c'mon- You know why. And if you don't someone will inevitably tell you when you try to talk about this game. And you should listen to them, because they're right. 

This game is pretty fun, but there is almost nothing about it that resembles the original other than most of the cast, the monsters, and loosely the plot and locations. It's also absurdly short, linear in the bad way (complete with unskippable "walking" sections, playable cutscenes, essentially) and has absolutely no extra modes, not even the Mercenaries mode which the original game introduced to the series. A massive shame since RE3 Mercs is unlike every iteration after it, and I'm sure I'm not the only person who was sorta hoping to see if they would do a modern iteration of it. Also, the classic costumes (1999 costumes) are not unlockables the way they are in RE2R, they cost $2.99. My autistic ass bought em, but I certainly don't feel good about it. The game was notoriously rushed, like that shouldn't even be debatable anymore. It came out barely a year after RE2R, and consists of 80% assets recycled from that game. It's also like 3 hours long. So sadly, this is about as close to a cash grab as the series has come since it's renaissance with RE7. When people criticize this game, they do so because they wanted, and deserved, better. Capcom is capable of better, the 2 RE games released following this one are proof of that.

This is the perfect example of why Steam needs more than "recommend" and "don't recommend" as review types. This is a solid "Decent game if you can get it on a massive sale." The gameplay is a step down from RE2R in a lot of ways, but it's closer to action horror akin to RE4 than the original was anyway, albeit clunkier and sloppier than RE4 or it's remake. But regardless, if you snag this for like 10 bucks? Not a bad deal, it's a decent romp if you just wanna dodge and shoot, just try to ignore the story, and the dialogue, and basically everything that's happening, if you even remotely liked the plot and tone of the original game.

This review contains mild spoilers, beware.
I know this game has been very controversial due to the remake being worse than the original game and how lazily done it is. However, I don't think it's right to call it bad. Sure, there were a lot of missed opportunities and disappointments. But you can't deny that it also had so much improvement. The graphics and music were just what I expected from a Capcom game, it was thrilling and just makes you feel like you are actually in that apocalypse. The story was quite well written. The map was well designed, especially the downtown and shops. The characters are definitely something that made the game more appealing. I mean, just look at Carlos.

Now onto the things that really disappoint me: Nemesis. I have played the RE2 remake just before this and I was absolutely terrified of Mr X. The way you heard his footsteps all over the map and didn't know where he was until he suddenly found you was terrifying. According to the lore, him and Nemesis are both tyrants and Nemesis is one of the strongest tyrians ever created. This character was supposed to be a creepy stalker that didn't leave you alone through out the game. However, he was so bad that even the zombies were scarier. The first and second encounter we had was pretty good, especially the way he can enter one of the safe rooms was so unexpected and scared me to death. But the other encounters were so bad. In his first and second boss fight, he just ran around like a monkey and you can to wait until he stopped so you can shoot him and get him down. Hell, Carlos was even there to tell you which barrel he was standing behind so you can aim there. And his last boss fight was even worse. That was a huge monstrous creator but he fainted like a pillow princess just by getting shot in those orange pops. In conclusion, Nemesis was such a joke.

Onto the second thing I really didn't like about the game is how easy it is. RE series is known for its survival horror and how you're supposed to survive with such low resource. As an example, RE2 Leon was a rookie cop who had his first day at his job. He had low resourse and wasn't that good at defending himself. Jill and Carlos however, they are completely over the top agents and you barely needed any resource. You could just press space and dodge attacks. The resource was also given a lot and they were so easy to find. It felt like a combat game than a horror game.

And the last thing I didn't like about the game was its play time. I play games very slowly and my first playthrough took around 6 hours. I really wish it was longer.

To sum it up, this game has its ups and downs but I still recommend playing it. I bought it when it had a discount and I think it's worth its price. Good work, Capcom.

Turning a classic into mediocrity is impressive. My first run through was 2 hours and while I wasn't quite quick enough and it's too late for me to refund it it's not too late for me to tell you to skip this game for now. If not for trying to smell the roses and a stupid snafu where I missed a gray door on my map in the boring hospital my play time would be even shorter. 
They focused all their resources and energy on seemingly every single thing they shouldn't have and I am extremely confident that I am not exaggerating about that one bit. This wasn't a problem in the remake of RE2 which was done by a different team even though both were developed around the same time together. How can something developed for 3 years be this short,rushed and unfinished? More has been cut than added and in both regards not for the better and it's not as if what is now gone was replaced with something else. The good parts are short and the bad parts are long. The original RE3 had maybe one sewer the entire game but in RERE3 anytime you would have been entering an interesting place instead you'll find yourself entering a sewer which seems like a move done to stitch together the remaining non sewer locations. The filler is so hard to stomach, at a certain point there is filler for the filler once you've long passed the good stuff.

If the game was really and I mean really good in this instance or kept what was good in RE3 or good in RERE2 I wouldn't mind the length but this just isn't the case. It is absurdly short and I mean shorter than Jill's skorts (not a skirt) which for now you can only get if you pre ordered it. Game shouldn't even cost 35 dollars and I paid 60 but having played it I don't know if I would have parted with 20. If this was a DLC for RERE2 it still wouldn't work as RE3 as they've completely missed the appeal of Nemesis and even then RERE3 deserves/deserved better than this. So linear, so little content, so little tension, so little survival, so little horror, so little variety, so little unscripted Nemesis and so little care, effort or ambition. The original which I played WAY after it's prime was while old and coming close to being dared was still fun to play (my dis taste for tank controls aside) and apparently it was basically made in a single year. Other than the graphics (which have issues like zombies exploding to save performance or animating at a lower framerate) this is a remake that feels like a downgrade in almost every way. To reiterate, this is a remake that feels like it would need a remake. Something could and maybe should be done to improve the game and I just can't imagine Capcom is happy or satisfied with how it is in it's current state and I don't know how much they could afford to add or fix or if they would even be willing or bother to do so it's kind of hopeless.

The ending is also awful but I gotta wrap this up as my review threatens to be longer than the game. In conclusion it would be worth a play when the price is right to minimize discontent but you'd still risk being disappointed if you've played other games and besides being a bad remake it's quite meh. I desperately tried to squeeze my moneys worth out of it by at least getting all the achievements like I did for RERE2 but it took far less time and it really is short and not terribly replayable.

"Resident Evil 3" brings the chaos of Raccoon City to life in a modern and action-packed remake. As a fan of the original and the RE series, I eagerly dove into this reimagining by Capcom, and while it delivers on many fronts, a few aspects left me with mixed feelings. PLEASE BRING RE1 and RE CV REMAKE. I WANT TO BE PART OF RE FRANCHISE.

Pros:

Stunning Visuals and Atmosphere: The RE Engine once again shines, delivering a visually impressive rendition of Raccoon City. The environments are detailed, and the ominous atmosphere is palpable, enhancing the survival horror experience.

Intense Action and Nemesis: The relentless pursuit by Nemesis adds a level of tension that keeps you on your toes. The encounters with this bioengineered monstrosity are thrilling and nerve-wracking, contributing to the overall sense of urgency. Little to Dodge is smart move.

Streamlined Controls and Gameplay: The modernized controls and gameplay mechanics make the experience accessible to both veterans and newcomers. The responsive controls add to the fluidity of combat and exploration.

Engaging Set Pieces: The set pieces and scripted events are well-executed, adding cinematic flair to the game. Moments like the escape from the city are adrenaline-pumping and showcase the game's action-oriented focus.

Cons:

Shorter Campaign: The main campaign feels noticeably shorter compared to other entries in the series. While the intense pacing contributes to the urgency, it may leave some players wanting a more extended experience. But I like it tho. expensive but shorter isnt good. Added DLC would be smart move.

Limited Exploration: The game's focus on action sometimes limits exploration. Certain areas feel more confined, and the sense of openness found in the original RE3 is somewhat diminished.

Conclusion:

"Resident Evil 3" is a visually striking and action-packed remake that successfully captures the essence of the original. While the shorter campaign and limited exploration may disappoint some fans, the intense encounters with Nemesis and the overall modernization of the classic make it a worthwhile experience.

[h1] Escape Raccoon City Before It’s Too Late! [/h1] 
Resident Evil 3 is a survival horror game developed and published by Capcom. It is a remake of the 1999 game Resident Evil 3: Nemesis. Players control former elite agent Jill Valentine and mercenary Carlos Oliveira as they attempt to find a vaccine and escape from a city during a viral outbreak. The game is played from a third-person perspective and requires the player to solve multiple puzzles and defeat monsters while being pursued by a creature called Nemesis.
 
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]💾Graphics[/td]
        [td]From the sequel of Resident Evil 2, the graphics have taken some improvements on this front. The image is overall sharper and crisp, but the UI is similar which to me is a plus. The facial animations are incredible and look realistic. The enemy design is haunting and looks so amazing, especially Nemesis.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎮Gameplay[/td]
        [td]Resident Evil 3 is similar to its predecessor. With survival horror elements you must conserve ammo and make every shot count. You have different enemies to deal with, and they can be a true challenge for you. You will find fewer puzzles in this game, and they are extremely easy which some may not like (Myself included). This game is more action paced as well so the horror and tension feels less in my opinion. The Boss fights are extremely challenging though which I was not a big fan of. You will have to test your skills with ammo conservation since Nemesis absolutely tanks your hits, which in my opinion should have been balanced better. [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]📜Story[/td]
        [td]Resident Evil 3 Remake’s story is one that is short lived in my opinion. Now I really did enjoy the story segment in this game. It’s action packed, the acting is incredible, and the characters felt really believable in this game. The story felt really linear compared to the other Resident Evil games. It’s really hard to explain how, I guess I'll just send you a list of things they changed or removed that were in the original.
[code][list]
[*]The entire clocktower and Raccoon City Park (including the Grave Digger mini Boss) area are missing. Dead Factory was replaced by the NEST 2 (Which looked pretty boring)
[*]The City itself is only half as big as before, alternative routes and small locations like the Press Building, Gas Station, Umbrella store etc. included.
[*]No randomized enemy and item locations.
[*]No live choices, which further changed the current playthrough in small ways.
[*]Much less encounters with Nemesis, which is also far less durable this time around. One grenade and he is down!
[*]No Brain Sucker, Crows, Giant Spiders and the small Grave Digger babies.
[/list][/code]
Yeah, that's a problem for me. I get that it’s a “remake” and they won’t add everything from the original, but pricing this game at $40 is just wrong in my opinion. I feel like this game was released way too quick. If they spent an extra year on this game, it could have been an incredible sequel to RE2, but it’s not. The story was great, but the game is just way too short and the replayability is small for me.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🕛Playtime[/td]
        [td]This game felt shorter than Resident Evil 2. My first playthrough was on Hardcore difficulty and it only took me like 4 hours to beat the game. You do have unlockables in this game (and plenty of them) so that can add good replayability. Sadly you don’t have any extra game modes or a randomizer mode to keep you interested for long.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎧Sound[/td]
        [td]The sound design is haunting and incredible. You can hear gunshots in the distance and crisis in Raccoon City. It’s honestly really immersive and so well done. The zombies are still super terrifying and the music is really nice.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❗Bugs❗[/td]
        [td]If you look closely, zombies in the distance skip and the animations are stuttery for them, but it’s smooth when they are close. It is distracting I will say. Besides that, there are no bad, or game breaking bugs.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔅Performance[/td]
        [td]The performance is top tier for me. I have no issues on Ultra settings and it runs so smoothly. Pretty simple here, no problems for me and you should have great performance if you have similar specs (which will be in the bottom of the review).[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]✔️Pro’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Haunting atomsphere
[*]Game is perfectly optimized
[*]Environments are beautiful (and scary)
[*]Nemesis is intimidating and well designed
[*]Many ingame unlockables and challenges
[*]Story was okay, but way too on rails in some sections
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❌Con’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Not many enemy types
[*]Little to no puzzles
[*]A ton of content stripped out from the Original
[*]Extremely linear even for a Resident Evil game
[*]Boss fights are extremely tough (way too spongy)
[*]Way too short of an experience and expensive (wait for sale)
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🏆Rating[/td]
        [td]5/10
I would wait for a 50% sale. This game does not feel like it’s worth its full price. Be patient and get the sale, you will thank me later.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔗Conclusion[/td]
        [td]I wanted to like this game. I enjoyed the story, but I just felt like the developers rushed this game into oblivion. You are missing so much content from the original it’s ridiculous. The story and voice acting is great, but the enemy variety is so weak compared to the original and feels so linear. This was a real disappointment to me and just hope they learn from this game and take their time on the next remake.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

This game is very good, quite good even! But as someone who came to this game thirty minutes after beating the Resident Evil 2 main stories, I wont lie, I feel really disappointed with what this game is offering. This game tries to add some quality of life improvements over RE2, but in turn, the mechanics in question feel unnecessary, finicky, or just choppy.
     This game doesn't have much else to offer other than its main story line, which isn't a bad thing per se but i as the player could definitely feel that i felt bored of the game play loop quickly. The most satisfying part of the whole game is how the lore and the story of the previous game tie up really nicely, which is rewarding if you're playing through these games sequentially.
     Out of the action, survival, and horror genres that this game tries to balance, I definitely felt it being much more on the action side than the survival, and the horror still remains a staple of this game as much as the last game. The story was servicing, but nothing too special. The characters feel mostly flat with very little to some character development.
     Even with my criticisms, I would definitely recommend this game if you have played the previous game and you want to see the threads of the last game and where they lead to in this game. As a standalone game, Its a lot of fun on its own, But i don't feel satisfied finishing it, and its better to think of it as a package with the story of RE2, rather than its own standalone title.

Oyuna bir kere girdikten sonra birdaha çıkmak istemiyor insan ve bu tür oyunlara bayılıyorum. Oyun size ağır gerilimli ve korkutucu sahnelerden sonra öyle huzurlu ve rahatlatıcı görsel, ışıklandırma ve müzikler veriyorki insanın bir daha güvenli alandan çıkası gelmiyor ama aynı zamanda bir sonraki sahneden neler olacağını çok merak ediyorsunuz. Bu hissiyat size oyunun ne kadar kaliteli olduğunu anlatıyor zaten. Karakterlerden bahsedecek olursak, oyunun ikinci dakikasından sonra Jill Valentine ye aşık oldum bu yüzden zombilerden falan hasar yememek için ekstra bir gayret gösterdim. Jill Valentine sahnelerinde bence bulmaca kısımları kolaydı fakat Nemesis ile olan kapışmalar inanılmaz adrenalin veriyordu ve aşırı heyecanlıydı. Bazı sahneleri tekrar tekrar denemek zorunda kaldım ama her farklı tercihim bile farklı bir eğlenceye kapı açıyordu. Carlos sahnelerinde gerilim son seviyelere kadar tırmanıyor zaten. Bulmaca kısımları Jill e kıyasla daha zorlayıcı ve oynanış açısından psikolojik olarak size daha da bir güven veriyor. o inanılmaz kurtarma görevindeki zombilerle çatışma sahnesi size korku, gerilim, heyecan, stress aynı zamanda merak, keyif, açıkgözlülük ve cesurluk duygularını yaşatıyor ve o kadar eğleniyorsunuz ki iki karakter arasında hangisinin sahneleri daha eğlenceli diye karar veremiyorsunuz. Oyunu bitirme süresi hikaye oyunlarına göre normal bir seviyede fakat keşke çok daha uzun olsaydı. Oyunun sonlarına yaklaştığımı farkedince bir süre sonra keşke oyun hiç bitmese diyordum kendime ve nihayetinde oyun bittiğinde bana anlık bir şok hissi verdi, kendimi bir süreliğine boşlukta hissettim ve cidden ne efsane oyundu ama dedim. Oyunda emeği geçen herkese teşekkürler. Gerçekten çok kaliteli oyun yapmışlar. Başta da söylediğim gibi Resident Evil 3 her zaman favorim olacak ve Resident Evil evreninde favori karakterim kesinlikle Jill Valentine!!!

I thought I'd come at this from a fresh perspective as someone who didn't play the original. A lot of reviews I see are critizing it for leaving a lot out; and rightfully so. But it's also more than that. Games in the past have cut content but still shaped up to be an admirable and worthwhile game.

Sadly, this is not one of them.

I played this directly after RE2R and knew it would be different, since technology changes. The graphics are nice. The guns feel sturdy. Progression is a bit shallow. My issues lie mainly with the story rather than the length or content of the game itself.

Instead of improving upon what they've already built with RE2R, Capcom just sort of made this a filler. 

As for the story, it feels very similar to the recent Call of Duty campaigns, where it's linear and predictable and quick. The story beats don't flow and it feels as if there are little to no stakes. I've played the RE1R after playing this and it's like they're two differnt characters. Yes, you can blame the tramua she endured and how it changed her, but it's just not written well. It feels so...empty. The story, too. Carlos was interesting; probably the best written in this game. It's just sad to see a good story be strung out for what seems to be filler.

The RE4R was fantastic. It's just so disappointing to see potential ruined. This very much plays and feels like a DLC; I'm almost certain Ada's DLC in the RE4R was either longer or more enjoyable.

Also DRM. Another gross tactic used by industries to excuse bad corporate decisions.

This game is very short and very fun. I've been playing through the entire series recently and was expecting mixed feelings based on what others have said. What a mistake. This game is awesome. Instead of doing a normal review, I'm going to list some common complaints and blast them

1. Its too short. 

True. This game received the least amount of love among the original sequels. But guess what? We knew this since the 90s. Is this an excuse? No. Should you have known what you're getting? Yes. The game now goes on sale for less than $10. Its totally worth the 8 hours you'll get out of it. If you paid $40 or more when the game released and you're salty about it, you openly ignored well known knowledge that has been available for decades. Your fault you didn't wait for a sale. You're a typical gamer that doesn't vote with his wallet but opens it up immediately whenever you see a loot box, overpriced costume or other gimmick that separates you from common sense and you're a curse on this industry.

2. Dodge. So many complaining about how difficult it is to dodge Nemesis. Its not. And there is an easy mode that practically holds your hand through the entire experience. Safe rooms are everywhere. Its not that hard.

3. Backtracking. Yes, there is a lot of it in this game but it remains interesting and the environments are awesome. For an example of lame backtracking: See Resident Evil 0. This game is far from annoying in this category.

4. Its not RE2. 
  
No crap. Resident Evil 2 and 4 are legendary. This game isn't them but its a hell of a ride on a budget.

5. Blah blah...something something multiplayer. Yeah, we know...Capcom releases multiplayer gimmicks and abandons them. List this under common knowledge and don't expect anything of substance from them in the future.

Overall the game gets a solid 8 out of 10 from me. Be smart tho...don't buy from A HOLE companies.

I really like this game, but:

Warning: Capcom is adding unfamiliar DRM to their back catalogue of games. This corp has repeatedly shown their stance towards mods in their games as well and seem to be taking action. I would caution you against purchasing any capcom product that contains this DRM as it’s unfamiliar, and untrustworthy. For now, if you really want this game, or any capcom game, I would stress that you watch and observe to see what happens in the near-ish future. 

Please note that there is a lot of misinfo circulating about with regards to this situation. Please do your due diligence and research everything and even fact check myself before making a final judgement. I am doing the best I can to sift through the false info and properly inform myself and will update this review accordingly.

DRM is not always a bad thing, if used correctly, it protects initial sales. Then good publishers will remove it later on allowing for better experiences. I am upset when DRM harms performance, which it often does (like Jedi Survivor). I find that inexcusable, poor performance that screws over the paying customer should always be frowned upon. Recently, denuvo was removed from RE8, which is good. But, when it was first added the game suffered many problems which modders had to remedy until its removal. Enigma seems to be capcom’s replacement for denuvo.

Earlier this month, RE Rev was updated and performance was harmed. Shortly after, capcom reversed the update. This is concerning because REV was released almost 11 years ago and the game’s already been cracked (both the pc and 3ds version), as with most older games. This update to add DRM to an old game is incredibly fishy, especially with how it came with no announcement from the publishers themselves. Almost as if somebody was trying to hide it.
Denuvo a very good DRM, since there’s few who know how to crack it, even then it’s tough. Denuvo itself costs ~$5,000 per month for the license, ~$60,000 a year. A game’s sales can’t keep up with the fee forever, and the DRM has to be removed/replaced to salvage income. 

Enigma is $59,920 cheaper. It costs about $400 for initial purchase, and $80 annually for upkeep. Enigma was checked with a virus scanner, and got 34 positive flags, ~%50 of what Virus Total checks for. Scanners can have false positives. The REV .exe will show 1 positive flag (at least for me). This one is easily written off as a false positive. Generally low single digits are fine. When you are getting into double digits, there’s problem. The dev for Enigma has been purported to have a fake address in the US, and the domain name’s been alleged to be bought through a Moscow front (fact check me). This DRM is incredibly sneaky, and according to others, is capable of quietly worming its way through your PC. These factors, even if partially false, are concerning, keep this away from your pc.

On October 25 of 2023, there was a capcom R&D presentation.
“RE:2023 Anti-cheat and Anti-Piracy Measures in PC Games Recommendations for In-House Production”
14:00 – 16:00 ish. The pres states that all mods, unless officially supported, are no different than cheating. Yes, with regards to DRM, all foreign code is considered tampering. But, they go further, and say that mods tarnish the product’s (and corp’s) image as they may be mistaken for legitimate parts of said product. Earlier last July, a tournament competitor in a SF6 match forgot to disable his Chun-Li n*de mod. This is likely what capcom is referencing. But, they’ve taken things further.

Capcom is no newb to “nuking” youtube creators’ channels. They’ve removed content and channels for discussing info that the corp themselves leaked. Capcom has taken action against MH creators, most notably speedrunners. This was because their videos featured mods, some as harmless as to simply aid with running or slightly modify the experience (skins/costumes/fov). Capcom has tried to take down modders’ work as well. Yes, these modders were making n*de mods, but never the less they came after a modder, who’s to stop them from taking things further and coming for everyone else?

Considering the corp’s past and recent actions and statements, it’s safe to say that they are/will be coming after modders. People like to add that Enigma was added to RE5 last year and that no one has had any problems. Even so, ghost updates are sketchy, since there’s no point in copy protecting a long-cracked game. For now, I advise customers to watch, listen, and wait to see what the corp does. We can choose to make it apparent to them that mods are an inevitable factor of PC gaming. I know where my stance is, if I can’t make Nemesis into Shrek, then I’ll happily take my money elsewhere.

Thank you if you read this far, I’d be happy if you had any info (legit that is) or comments you’d like to share.

I have one more speculation (not an allegation or accusation, simply a theory coming straight outa my rear end). I think that modders are beginning to pose a business threat to companies like capcom.

Jill Valentine wakes up from nightmares in her untidy apartment one balmy September night. That she's not exactly housewife of the year ceases to matter just as her suite is vandalized by a strange monster with supernatural powers. As if it wasn't enough that the zombie apocalypse is currently raging outside the windows.

The story of Resident Evil 3 takes place even before the escape of Leon and Claire, later concurrently with it. Jill, a former soldier and member of the elite unit S.T.A.R.S., has her hands full in a matter of moments, collecting survivors and putting them on the subway out of the city.
Everything gets complicated when he meets the strike force of the evil corporation Umbrella, which is responsible for releasing the T-Virus.
The original RE3 was no screenwriting gold, but Capcom tries here to reflect the changes in social discourse, a little unfortunately. So Jill is no longer mowing down zombies in a miniskirt and strapless top: her 2020 version bears a striking resemblance to another rejuvenated hero of our time, Lara Croft. And actually also by behavior.

Resident Evil 3 is a good game as it has the new RE engine that CAPCOM are being praised for. It is a "prequel" to Resident Evil 2 so realistically you play this one first before RE2. The game is great from start to finish but... it is WAY to short and WAY to expensive for its own good. Please, PLEASE do not get me wrong, RE3 is amazing itself with its graphics, gunplay, the new RE engine and modding but that's all that is really good about it. I may have an "unpopular opinion" with what I am about to say but it is my opinion. Below I will state WHY I sadly cannot recommend this game.

[h1][b] Why I cannot recommend RE3/Cons [/b][/h1] 
⚫Lets get this started, shall we. First of all, I have NEVER played RE3 in my life. So, I was going in blind. I decided that I would play the game on Hardcore first. The game was WAY to easy on hardcore. I mean... I got a B rank but I completed the game in under 3 hours. So what I am saying is, the game is WAY to short. £32.99 for 3 hours of my time (its actually 2h 40m ish).
https://steamuserimages-a.akamaihd.net/ugc/2047503411645156010/E2C5F77213CF08CE2C8F8C19F703E933BA74A8C4/?imw=5000&imh=5000&ima=fit&impolicy=Letterbox&imcolor=%23000000&letterbox=false
⚫Hardcore felt like Standard difficulty. The game was a bore fest with the "Zombies". The only thing that EVER came close to killing me on Hardcore was myself with my grenades.
⚫I have seen a few reviews stating that the game offers no replay ability... I can see somewhat what they mean. So, If it took me 3 hours for one run, B rank. Another run for S rank will be faster as I have done the game (Infinite ammo guns unlocked now) then 1 more run on Inferno difficulty and thats the game 100% more or less. So I reckon It would take me.... 8 hours to 100% this game and that is multiple runs.

EDIT: As of 14/01/24 I decided to play the game on inferno mode to earn my last 5 achievements. I was expecting this to take me forever and offer a REAL challenge... it only took me 1 hour 48 minutes and 12 seconds to do the game with an S rank. 6 hours of playtime. I am absolutely appalled. 

[h1][b] Pros [/b][/h1] 
⚫Its running on the new RE engine so if you have seen RE2, RE7, RE Village then you know what your in for.
⚫Graphics are stunning yet again. What do we expect? Its the new RE engine.
⚫The mods for the game can go out of their way and give you a good laugh or in general make the game much better.

[h1][b] My Verdict [/b][/h1] 
As a new player to RE 3 I feel cheated out of my money. I paid £49.99 for less than 3 hours of gameplay and for that I sadly cannot recommend RE 3. I wish I could leave a NEUTRAL review for this game as I loved it but its WAY to expensive for what you get. 

[h1][b] 10/10 for gameplay, graphics and mods but 2/10 for length of game and price [/b][/h1]

This is an action game with a Resident Evil title in the vein of Resident Evil 6 and it is not impressive.

Resident Evil 3, successfully reimagines the classic 1999 title, delivering a gripping experience that captivates players from start to finish. With 23 hours invested in this survival horror masterpiece, I can confidently say that Resident Evil 3 offers an adrenaline-pumping journey filled with intense action, clever puzzles, and a compelling storyline.

The gameplay mechanics shine, with tight controls and responsive movements that enhance the overall immersive experience. As Jill, I found the ability to dodge incoming attacks at close range to be a game-changer, adding a layer of strategy to the combat. The inclusion of Carlos Oliveira as a playable character in certain sections brought diversity to the gameplay, keeping the overall experience dynamic and engaging.

The visuals are stunning, showcasing the capabilities of the RE Engine. Raccoon City is brought to life with meticulous detail, and the character models, especially that of Nemesis, are both terrifying and impressive. The atmospheric sound design contributes significantly to the game's suspense, making every step through the desolate streets and eerie environments a nerve-wracking experience.

The primary antagonist, Nemesis, is a formidable foe that evolves throughout the game, creating a sense of constant dread and tension. The encounters with Nemesis are adrenaline-fueled, requiring quick thinking and precise shooting to survive. The variety of weapons, including customizable firearms and combat knives, adds depth to the combat system, making each encounter a strategic challenge.

The inclusion of additional difficulty modes and an item shop upon completion provides excellent replay value. Unlocking new weapons and items through completing challenges adds an extra layer of satisfaction to the overall gaming experience. The decision to tie the narratives of Resident Evil 2 and 3 more closely together enhances the sense of continuity within the Resident Evil universe.

While some locations from the original game were omitted, the rearranged storytelling and expanded dialogue contribute to a more cohesive narrative. The removal of multiple endings in favor of a focused story streamlines the experience, ensuring a more consistent and impactful narrative.

In conclusion, Resident Evil 3 is a stellar remake that successfully captures the essence of the original while delivering a fresh and thrilling experience for both long-time fans and newcomers to the series. With its intense action, atmospheric setting, and well-executed gameplay mechanics, Resident Evil 3 is a must-play for survival horror enthusiasts. I wholeheartedly recommend this game to fellow players, as it offers a memorable journey through the nightmare-infested streets of Raccoon City.

There are two aspects to consider when reviewing this game, through the lens of how it compares to the other resident evil remakes and how it stands as a game in general. That's where this game rightfully deserves a "Mixed" rating if it were possible so while I will ultimately recommend it, I think how you rate it should be through those lens.

Compared to the other remakes, this game is absolutely atrocious. It cuts a large amount of content and expects you to just forgive and it disrupts the pace of the story as well. It fumbles its depiction of Nemesis which really sucks when the previous game had the terrifying Mr. X. It recycles a decent handful of assets from RE2R and while on it's own seems fine, it's much more obvious when you've played the other game. Gunplay and Physics are incredibly downgraded compared to the previous title, dismemberment being removed entirely and all zombies having no collision and a fixed death animation. The story length is even outdone by the recently released RE4R Separate Ways DLC. There's zero replayability unlike the other remakes which had separate game modes and reasons to replay the story, RE3R possessing nothing of that sort. Why RE3R got shafted in it's overall development will forever remain a mystery to me.

Now as a standalone title, RE3R is a very serviceable title. For starters, the game looks REALLY good, there's absolutely no debate about that. The combat is okay, in relation to my earlier statement, it's not quite the same level of greatness of the other two but it's okay enough to have fun with. The dodge mechanic may suck compared to Leon's parry of RE4 but I mean I guess it's there if you want it. Overall, this whole game operates more like a DLC for the 2nd Remake and if you take that into consideration, you'll enjoy this very short experience. 

Just mind this, buy this on a VERY deep sale. I paid about $9 for it in the most recent Winter Sale and that's about the most fitting price for this game as a package.

RE3 is a lot of the same of RE2- good survival horror. There's only one campaign this time, but after you beat the game you unlock special features that allow you to buy exclusive weapons and other such toys to make the game spicy again. I didn't really play with any of those things since it's still playing the same map over again at the end of the day, but i'm sure others will appreciate the option.

I have a few nitpicks with some of the enemy designs having instant kill moves in confined spaces / spaces with multiple enemies, as the resulting deaths felt cheap rather than fair and my mistake, but it only happens in about three areas so it's not super prevalent or anything. 

Another slight issue is that perfect dodges / perfect punches weren't referenced anywhere where I could see them and I had to look up how they worked online rather than ingame, which is a little annoyingly obtuse for a feature that provided the dopamine peaks for my experience.

Really would've liked a Carlos mode since decking lickers out of the air was awesome and Jill's a lot more boring in comparison when you have to play as her again, but apparently RE4 remake has more of that perfect-counter goodness so i'm looking forward to that.

Sometimes remakes don't need to be faithful to be good games. If they're too faithful, especially if the original had very dated game design, then you end up with shit like RE1R (which honestly felt more like the Twin Snakes of RE1 than a remake. It was bad.)

Simply enough, it's a remake of 3 with RE2R's engine. If you liked the UI and gameplay of RE2, then you'll enjoy RE3R just fine.

DX12 would do nothing but crash the game, especially when I tried to first start it. The main drawback is ray tracing, and it wouldn't even impact the experience to be honest. Another complaint is that one of the best lines was used way too early, and you'd know exactly which one it is if you've seen the game.

Other than that, a lot of the issues I had were just skill issue, so I can't add them here. Try it out if you aren't worried about it doing justice to the original.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
An okay remake of the original PS1 Resident Evil 3, with similar story and gameplay, but with updated graphics. The game retains the "arcadey" feel of the original which is something to look forward to. However, a lot of content were removed and changed till you can barely compare to the original game. The game itself is exceptionally short and has way too many scripted events, feeling as if you're playing a visual novel game, rather than an action oriented game.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
It is a remake of the classic arcade game and generally a survival horror third-person shooter game where you play as Jill Valentine and Carlos Oliveira. Players must explore the environment to open doors and locks in order to proceed and/or upgrade equipment. Puzzles are required to be solved to gain access to areas and unlock equipment, since equipment and storage is scarce, players need to constantly manage their inventories.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The graphics is extremely good and light, an obvious upgrade from the original PS1 game.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
Music and audio is relatively good, especially when using THX Surround.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
Controls are realatively easy and fine tuned both for Controller and on Keyboard+Mouse

[h1]Bugs & Issues[/h1]
1. Animation and movement is very janky as it will make you wonder, why would any character move like that?
2. Your "Sprinting" feels extremely slow, more like a slow jog, killing the mood of the entire game due to no sense of urgency
3. No bugs for the game found so far

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Overall an okay game, the only reason to get this game is nostalgia, as even re-playing the game feels more of a chore as it is too short with limited rewards. Players can actually finish the game less than 2 hours which is saying something (even some Demo games are longer, that is saying something), get this game only when on sale.

The Remake of 'Resident Evil 3' is still controversial. After playing the remake of the fourth instalment, I want to state that the negative bias seems hardly justified.
I recommend this game to virtually everyone who likes Survival Horror and Action Adventures - if you don't mind the horror aspect. There are some nasty and gruesome scenes in this game. The presentation is virtually flawless. And I think that is what matters here: The developers had a clear vision of how to modernize this game that has become absolutely unplayable on modern platforms. They cut some content, and they changed the atmosphere a bit to bring RE3 in line with RE0-RE6 which you can play now in a single uninterrupted line of game experiences.
What has been lost in terms of old charm and appeal is compensated by throwing out the cheesiness and silliness of the original dialogue, cutscenes and plot elements as well. Nothing shows this better than a comparison to the remake of 'Resident Evil 4' which definitely suffers from tacked-on action-sequences (the cave-segment is the worst offender) and the pirate-themed playground areas. I wished they had just cut those segments, bringing it to the same level as the remade RE3.
'Resident Evil 3' is inferior to the remake of part 2, because that title just offers more gameplay and a unique double perspective on the plot (Leon/Claire). But in my book it is superior to the remake of part 4, because it is more cohesive, more coherent and scarier most of all. I have only one complaint: It is a little too short. My vote is 87/100 - excellent and well worth full prize.

It's mechanics are mostly similar but has some improved mechanics such as a "dodge", which makes for more interesting enemy encounters and boss fights.

Is it as good as the second one?  No, from a story perspective it's probably a notch down (it's not bad though), but it was a lot of fun! I liked switching from protagonist to protagonist and that they both played slightly differently, and it was great that they had you on do more boss fights, holdouts, and running away sections. But moreover I enjoy how this game segues into the second game and helps flesh out why things are the way they are in the universe of Resident Evil.

After the remake of Resident Evil 2 which everyone loved, naturally the remake of Resident Evil 3 dropped next, aaand... Well, people mostly disliked it, like - a lot.
This is not by any means a terrible or a broken game. Couple of reasons why this got so much hate was because of all the cut content from the original game, the campaign here was also incredibly short in comparison to RE:2 and the multiplayer included I think as a consolation was pretty much DOA, very bare bones, abandoned and plagued with cheaters.
This absolutely sucks balls, because the gameplay here is pretty much just RE:2 all over again, which isn't a bad thing because that game played very, very well - hell, this comes with a few new mechanics, like actual dodging, with a risk-reward system for you to also time your doges perfectly which takes a little to get used to and learn the timing of. That, plus your knife becomes more of a tool here than a last resort line of defence.
There's a lot of cool weapons here, crafting and looting is pretty much all the same here, and the map is a little more spaced despite being (obviously) linear, which works great for the gameplay and the new dodging mechanic, however it doesn't have the same horror charm to it as the cramped spaces and corridors of the RPD, not a massive problem for me, but definitely a notable change.
Did I mention how fu****g short the campaign here is? I have played the previous remake a good few times for leisure and I acquired a little over 40h just replaying that game like maybe 3.5 times, with some additional "fu****g around time" yet here in RE:3 I played that game through I think twice, and boom - a little over 7h xD 
Again, why play this extremely inferior version of RE:2 when you can just play RE:2 instead? Probably for the same or less money too. 
The most heartbreaking thing for me was the Nemesis, which on paper sounds so much scarier and overpowered than Mr. X could ever dream to be, buuut... He only really appears in some scripted events, to otherwise just hang around the same areas. He technically has a lot of tools in his arsenal, like the tentacle which he can use to not only slow you down but also travel extremely fast himself, in addition to being able to run and use some crazy weapons like a fricking bazooka or a flamethrower, like DAMN! Except, again - the weapons are either mostly scripted events or strictly boss fights, and you can counter all of it with your new dodge ability, sounds cool AF, but it gets really easy once you learn how to use it, and suddenly the Nemesis becomes so much less intimidating than Mr. X :/

In conclusion, it's RE:2 with a few new additions, mostly unchanged core, uninteresting campaign and for the same amount of money. Don't Play Resident Evil: 3 just stick to the 2

The Resident Evil 3 remake feels like it was made just to let Capcom say they covered all the bases- like they wanted to get it done and out of they way so they could get to Resident Evil 4's remake. Resident Evil 2 and 4's remake do everything this game tried to do but better in every way, and that really just makes me sad. For example, Mr. X in 2's remake is a much better enemy as he quietly appears around the area you're in, pursuing you and usually catching you in a tight space forcing you to react. He's also usually lingering around the place where you last saw him, staying as a quiet threat the entire time. In this game, Nemesis has a big flashy cutscene or event every time he shows up, and it's usually in a wide open area- and if it isn't, you can just use the dodge mechanic to avoid a melee attack. He's hardly a threat in my opinion, and just doesn't capture the anxiety and pressure you felt with X. You can explore most areas in Resident Evil 4 remake's big, interconnected map to get some extra items, usually health or ammo- but you just don't really get that in this game, as it's sort of thrown right where you need to be going anyways, and nothing really feels connected like the other two remakes. The cutting of the exploration of the city, certain decisions, entire areas, and random encounters with Nemesis hurt the experience so much, and I wish this game was handled with more care. It's not all negative though! I do really like the new designs that the characters were given in the remake, the new enemies in this game that aren't in the previous remake were great to see (minus those bugs in that maze section, I really wanna know who needed that in the game), the combat is more dynamic over the previous remake, and Jill and Carlos play off of each other very nicely! I truly hope though that there is something going on behind the scenes for a big update to this game to fix a lot of its problems, but I'm doubtful. If you really want to experience this story, I would find a way to play the original.

As someone who didn't play most of the originals but loves the new RE games, I give RE:3 a solid "decent" rating. While it's an amazing game engine, RE Engine feels a little clunky here (especially when compared to RE:4 remake). However it's got all the core gameplay mechanics that make the reboot so fun: excellent shooting, rewards for exploration, and horror.

My only real complaint was Nemesis' behavior. I understand that they wanted to make him unique instead of just another "Mr. X" but his mechanics felt unfair. When chasing you he can close massive distances instantly and there's almost no way to see it coming. All of the sudden he's behind you, blocking your camera and smacking the hell out of you. In true RE fashion, taking damage like this results in a stun which adds to the cumbersome feel of the game. It's not overly obstructive in the grand scheme of things, but it was needlessly stressful in a not-fun way - compared to other stalker enemies that keep pressure on you constantly but fairly.

While not my favorite RE game, it's worth a buy on sale.

Having not played the original Resident Evil 3, I can say this game is definitely a fun game but is it better than RE2R? That's still up for debate. Most of the complaints for this game were the contents which are cut from the original, I can't have a say on that as I never played the original before so this review will be solely based on my experience in on the Resident Evil 3 Remake.

Starting off, the graphic is absolutely stunning and easily able to hold in own even in today's standard. The best part is it's well optimized and throughout my entire gameplay, I did not once encountered any stutters. The RE Engine is a work of wonder for sure. Similar to it's predecessor RE2R, the gameplay is linear and overall gameplay doesn't change must from previous game with the exclusion of few new in-game weapons and mechanics remains largely the same. There's few new types of enemies for sure but the concept are roughly the same. I'm not sure if it's just me but I felt that the gameplay for RE3R is much more refine and even the combat and dodges are more fluid than the previous game. The game's action sequences and boss fights are also more engaging than previous one and Nemesis is definitely a heck lot stronger than Mr. Stalker. Everything about this game for me as a whole is really fun but the story however could've been expanded more as it felt quite short and some plot points could've been utilized better. The game focuses more on action and less on horror elements. This isn't the case for RE2R as you might get chased around by Mr. X. In this game however, if you are to get chase. Usually it'll end up with a boss fight.

Another Improvement over the initial remake is that it's soundtrack and music are much better tailor for it's environment now. I really like the safe room music and when shit hits the fan, the music changes too. This gives a much more tense feeling compare to previous game. Some other minor changes include how knife works. Now you don't need to collect them anymore as it'll be included in your inventory and won't be broken like previous game. This works well especially if you're on harder difficulty where bullets are really limited. However, the knife does deal less damage when compared to previous game. The graphics of the surrounding environment is also one of the highlights of the game. The entire hospital gameplay is really enjoyable.

Overall I definitely enjoyed this game despite it's minor flaws. However I do believe you can get this game when it's on discount because it'll be more worth that way as the gameplay hours and replayability doesn't really justify it's pricing. There's however the optional multiplayer game mode but let's be honest, ain't no way anyone is buying this game for that. I would give this game a solid [b]7.5/10[/b]. The puzzles and action element of the game is definitely the highlight and overall a good remake from Capcom.

So after playing through the game twice and seeing all that R3make has to offer I've come across some things to mention.

#NotmyJillValentine
#NotmyJillValentine
#NotmyJillValentine

[u]First off, credits where credits are due[/u]:
- The Opening Live intro cinematic is phenomenal! Seeing this while being hyped about the game really gets you in a great mood but also immediately raises the expectations you have for the game.
Meaning: Sadly you'll be kind of let down afterwards.

- The way unlockables like infinite Weapons are earned is amazingly executed and feels like the most satisfying reward system any RE has ever had. Thanks for giving me a way to get my overpowered weapons before having to speedrun the game on the hardest diffulty. Adds a lot of fun to the game overall.

- Also gotta give props to the dialogue/voice acting thoughout the game. Every Resident Evil suffers from the same cringe, dumb and ridiculous over the top self-confidence dialogue and I'm very happy to say that this one reduced it  A LOT. 
So this Category was way better handled than in the RE2Remake last year. 
Overall I really enjoyed the Voice actors I truly think they did a great job here.

Is it a good game? Well definitely. 
Is it a good Remake? Not in the slightest.

For me personally seeing things from the original being cut didn't have too much effect on me since I've never played the original RE3. I have seen multiple playthroughs though so I'm familiar with the old game.
Overall I don't see any dumb changes when it comes to the Story, however [spoiler] "killing" Nicholai or leaving him to die after the missile is about to hit RC doesn't really make sense considering he's still very alive and kicking in RE:ORC. But it's like whatever [/spoiler].

[u]Now to the bad part[/u].

- Clearly what this Remake lacks is content. I really do think that it's a great and fun game overall but it sure does suffer from the lack of content. Even while playing it for the very first time (started on Hardcore) I've felt like things were rushed for no reason. From the beginning where Sh*t went down in like about 5 minutes (yes Jill was asleep but still) up to the point where [spoiler] Jill gets infected by the Nemesis and just lays bleeding and unconcious on the cold ground for almsot a Day? What? Every sane Person would have died right there on the Spot that really was immersion breaking for me [/spoiler].

- But the biggest flaw of this game is that I genuinely felt like the Devs didn't play/know the OG RE3 all too well. Many things were changed for no reason like [spoiler] Brad not being killed by the Nemesis. I think that scene was iconic! I mean yea he already got introduced in the first 5 minutes but seeing him kill Brad like he did in the original game would have been astonishing for me! [/spoiler]
Many things were simply cut like the Gravedigger (Worm) or RE's famous puzzles (which many agree on RE3 having the most difficult puzzles in the whole Franchise).

- Another point that really bugs me is  Resident Evil: Resistance. While it is indeed a fun and interesting Game set in RE universe it simply doesnt justify RE3 being this short and having a price tag of 60€.
Also what's important for me here is: The original RE3 introduced everyone to the famous 'Mercenaries' mode which many fans of the Franchise loved over the past decades being in many RE titles. Clearly fans stated that they'd wished for it's return for this Remake but instead we got RE:sistance which nobody really asked for.
Sadly feels like the Devs don't care about what their fans and supporters really want... :(
You cannot even by RE3 and RE:sistance seperately. That's just the most greedy thing for me. Even if I Like Resistance.

- When it comes to graphical design yes it is a little bit of a downgrade when compared to RE2 (2019) but due to this game being  way faster paced and way more action oriented (which I don't mind at all because it makes sense with the whole Nemesis thing going on) it didn't really bother me at all especially because the things that are mainly focused are still top notch.

Those are just a few points why - even if I really want to - cannot give this game a thumbs up. However, If I were to give this game a rating out of 10, it would be a solid 7/10 for me. 


***Obviously the Review only counts for RE3 and not for its included game RE:Resistance***

Annoyingly short and the early game inventory management and loot economy is horribly un-tuned. Constantly felt myself having zero inventory space while simultaneously having no resources, and the frequent back tracking to pool resources in my box was quite annoying.

!! Spoilers below !!

Boss fights were hit and miss. The first encounter with Nemesis was fun, if a little too scripted for my liking, and when he chases you around the city he can be a bit brutal especially considering the lack of healing items. Later on when he gets a flamethrower and torches the skyscraper he somehow becomes less powerful but much more fun to fight on the roof of said skyscraper, 

Nemesis' rocket launcher was a fun, albeit shortlived segment that I enjoyed, but the next time we encounter him I wanted to tear my brain out of my skull. What the hell was that fight by the at the fountains where he climbs the clocktower?? Jill's voice lines made me assume I had to shoot him off the clocktower, but in actuality he just... sits there? I used a dozen grenade rounds, thirty or more shotgun rounds and fifty or so handgun bullets before he went down, and by that point it was just dull.

The Nemesis fight near the acid tanks was much better though. Carlos helping me out and the constant waves of regular zombies made a simple circular arena into an interesting ara to navigate. Final Nemesis fight with the rail gun was awful though. He had zero powerful attacks and it felt very short lived.

Carlos and Jill were great protagonists though, and the focus on their combat training via the dodge mechanic made me feel much more adept at fighting large groups of enemies. The re-use of many Resident Evil 2 assets both makes sense and feels like a disappointment at the same time. Did we really have to navigate the RPD again? How about the sewers and the same streets? 

It felt far too contained within the same area as Resident Evil 2, and honestly felt more like DLC than a standalone game, especially given its short run time.

Still, it has some standout levels like the burning skyscraper, the hospital and the acid tank bossfight with Nemesis, along with more tuned combat than most other Resident Evil games.

Growing up in a place without internet access, my childhood gaming experiences were defined by the captivating world of the Resident Evil franchise. The early titles, especially Resident Evil 0 through 3, hold a special, nostalgic place in my heart. With the remastered series, Capcom has truly outdone themselves, exceeding expectations and rekindling the magic of these classic games.

The Resident Evil 3 Remastered is a shining example of how to breathe new life into a beloved classic. The game preserves the essence and atmosphere that made the original a legend while updating it with stunning modern graphics, refined gameplay mechanics, and immersive audio design. Every minute spent playing this remastered version feels like a thrilling trip down memory lane, but with the polish and sophistication of contemporary gaming standards.

Capcom's attention to detail in the remaster is commendable. The reimagined Raccoon City is more vibrant and terrifying than ever, filled with meticulously rendered environments that enhance the game's tense and eerie atmosphere. The updated character models, particularly of the protagonist Jill Valentine, are impressively realistic, adding depth to the narrative and engagement in the gameplay.

Moreover, the game's pacing and action have been expertly tweaked to suit modern gaming sensibilities. The balance between horror, action, and puzzle-solving remains as compelling as ever, ensuring that both longtime fans and newcomers to the series find the experience exhilarating. Resident Evil 3 Remastered is not just a remake; it's a masterful reimagining that pays homage to its roots while standing tall as a modern-day classic in its own right.

Remake? More like Re-Cut!

Updated graphics, but cut content. Really short game (4 Hours upon completion). 
No point in buying unless in Winter sale. Even then, it's not exactly thrilling like Resident Evil 2 Remake. It looks so obvious that it's a rushed product, and unlike RE2, there is no replayability value. Seems like you can't strike Gold twice with RE Remakes.

- - - Annoying Tid Bits - - -

* Priced at £32.99 full price (At Reviewers Date), and a playtime of 4 hours, that's £8.20 per hour of "fun". Think about that.
* The replayability that I suppose is in the game is a stupid shop menu that allows you to buy some buffs and infinite weapons for your next pointless playthrough. How original...
* I haven't played RE2 Remake in some time, but I am 99% sure that a great deal of assets used in RE3 have been taken from RE2. From a AAA game company, I would expect better than some cookie cutter nonsense.
* Chucking in another team deathmatch game to add as filler is just about all the proof you need in this company's confidence in this product. There is none!

- - - How To Fix This (Hindsight) - - -

* Scrap the team deathmatch game, and instead add a Mercenaries mode in the base game. +Adds replayability, possible multiplayer interaction, and a chance to introduce a faster paced gamemode for those particular players into that kind of thing.
* Adding new content on top of the original remake. A few more levels, including the original game's missing levels. +Adds surprise to those diehard original fans that know every inch of the original game with these new levels. It also fills up the game's runtime, and fixes the atrocious pacing between the final boss battles.
* Adding more puzzles. I thought RE was a mix of action and puzzle solving, but I didn't find it here. +Adds runtime and engaging player experience.
* New assets. Simple as that. I expect a few assets from previous games of course, but not this many.

I'd recommend waiting for a sale to pick this game up. Not that it was bad, in fact I liked it quite a bit, but it's definitely really short. My playtime at the time of writing this is right after finishing my first play through (~4 hours according to steam, but ~3 hours in-game time). I don't think that's a huge negative though as I do think some games overstay their welcome. I do plan on playing this game a few times though as the unlock systems that you get access to after finishing the game seem interesting and encourage multiple play throughs. 

If you liked the RE2 remake, you'd probably really enjoy this as well. It's a bit more action packed than that game, but there are some cool nods to it and it feels like a proper sequel. 

Note that I didn't play the original RE3 prior to this, so some of the complaints I've heard from other reviews about missing story content and such didn't affect me at all.
The game is fun, and isn't all jump scares. There is a setting for people like me who want to play but not die at every turn. Enjoy the nostalgia.

This game finds itself in an odd middle ground. I have not played the original, so can't really compare. It is very short (for a first time play-through) compared to other titles. A short game isn't necessarily bad but in the case of RE: 3 Remake it feels like it is missing much needed content. The game looks beautiful. Not a lot of repeatability. Nemesis feels less random and threatening than Mr. X in the pursuing bits in the game. The new Nemesis design is ok, but the additional changes that happen are a poor decision in my opinion. I've 100% this game twice. Both runs were significantly quicker than RE: 2 Remake to completion. I think Jill looks a bit generic, but Carlos looks incredibly redesigned. The final boss fight is a bit strange but at the hardest difficulty is incredibly challenging. No additional main game content or DLC to help it post lunch. At this point RE: Resistance is dead and a meaningless addition, it's post lunch content is irrelevant. In this new generation of RE since RE: 7, this game isn't up to snuff and feels like the black sheep. Get it on sale if you're a fan of the franchise. Buy a different RE game if you want a similar but better experience.
