This game stands as a thrilling and intense installment in the iconic series. The game's storyline is gripping, weaving a narrative that keeps you on the edge of your seat without spoiling any surprises. It's a solid 8 out of 10 for its plot – there's a perfect blend of horror, suspense, and action, ensuring that the story remains engaging throughout.

When it comes to gameplay, Resident Evil 3 offers a balanced and challenging experience. It scores a 7 out of 10 in this department. The controls are responsive and intuitive, making navigation and combat feel smooth. Although there's room for improvement in some areas, the overall gameplay mechanics are solid and contribute to an immersive gaming experience.

The graphics in Resident Evil 3 are nothing short of impressive. With a 9 out of 10 rating, the game shines in its visual presentation. The attention to detail in the environments, character models, and lighting effects creates a hauntingly realistic world that enhances the overall horror atmosphere. The graphic fidelity is top-notch, contributing significantly to the immersive and eerie feel of the game.

In conclusion, Resident Evil 3 is a commendable remake that lives up to the legacy of the series. It blends a compelling story, engaging gameplay, and stunning graphics to deliver an experience that both fans and newcomers to the series will appreciate.

I cannot recommend Resident Evil 3 2020. While it is a decent game. It is inferior to the original Resident Evil 3: Nemesis in every way except for 2 areas, Graphics of course and characters. Though there are 2 characters i do find issue with.  ----WARNING SPOILERS AHEAD!!!!----

My first issue with this game is how linear and short it is. you can beat it in 2 hours, and that's not speed running. Another issue i have is with Nemesis, one, his redesign is sub-par to put it kindly. They made him look beastly and savage, actually, they made him look like the super licker from Resident Evil the Movie, which make it even worst. His original designs for his 3 forms was good, why the hell they didn't just recreate and remaster it is beyond me. Honestly, they could of literally ripped the Marvel vs Capcom 3 nemesis and out him in the new nemesis place and it would look far better then what we got. His voice however i will compliment is good, no other game besides the original had a good nemesis voice, this one does, so that's a plus. His other forms are also not great, except the final form, i didn't mind it, but it wasn't a threat, which is the problem. Nemesis is NOT A THREAT in this game. 1 Frag grenade literally will down him, the explosive barrels and generators you can trigger help stun him as well.  In the original game it took 24 shotgun shells to down him, once, and you had to down him twice in a row to get any loot from him. Now, just shot his chest contraption and BAM, hes down after maybe 5 shots. With these issue, Nemesis isn't scary, which is a serious problem. He is supposed to be the most powerful tyrant ever created, a damn near unstoppable force. He suppose to be challenging and terrifying, which he was for all of 5 minutes, until you discover how to easily dispatch him and now the main bad guy of the whole game is a joke. 

Weapons are pretty bare bones, the original game had weapons you could unlock by battling nemesis and earning parts to craft better gear like the STI Eagle 6.0 or the Lever-Action Shotgun, those are gone and no mine launcher either which sucks. Granted the MGL can fire mine rounds, which somehow damage nemesis more then explosive rounds. Sigh....

Ok, now onto Jill, Jill for the most part is amazing, she looks both beautiful and tough, like she actually was an ex delta force operator turned cop. Which, if you know her back story, shes was the first woman that entered and passed delta force selection in the resident evil lore, which is awesome. Her outfit redesign is good in my opinion, it makes senses for her situation. However, she has 2 issues. 1. Her classic outfit, is NOT her classic outfit, its a mock up of it and it looks rather bad on her. Very bad, i dunno why they even bothered it they weren't gonna do it justice. Modders! Fix this heresy! Ok, the second is her attitude. Jill in the original series was tough, kind hearted, witty and determined.  While she still has some of those traits, shes gain a few new ones i do not like. Shes lost that witty charm and gained a foul mouth, which at times is funny, others it makes me roll my eyes. I know CAPCOM wants to "modernize" their resident evil characters, but in doing so, you take elements away from them. And this whole "modernizing" idea isn't good for the series, especially with all the glaring issues it brings up. 

No Mercenaries Mod, WTF CAPCOM. Nobody wants or asked for Resistance, OMG you had 1 job......how do fuck it up, HOW?!?!........... Resistance is crap, its literal dead by daylight / left 4 dead and its not even good. The enemy AI is retarded and in my opinion the whole concept is far inferior to oh i dunno...Mercenaries Mode! For Fuck Sake, you didn't even have to put in operation mad jackal, just add a mercenaries mode like Resident Evil 5's and your set. Or make it Survival mode where you hold out as long as possible, like COD zombies mode, THAT would of been amazing, Resistance is shit. When i tried it during the demo, i barely got to play it because nobody was on the servers testing this crap. How the hell is this mode half the size of the game. Did y'all literally shove this in here to pad out the game that is way too short and fully of missed opportunities. One missed opportunities is Jill not encountering zombie Brad and Marven, they should not have sent Carlos and Tyrell into that situation, it has less emotional impact on the story and characters. SIGH..... OK Rant over, for now.

Monsters and Gore: This games gore is very weak, the originals had much more gore then this, character deaths are well, weak sauce, and this was a problem in RE2R chief irons death was pathetic to how he got 2 different death types in the original, which were pretty cool. Zombies are asset flips from RE2R which doesn't surprise me, but no new zombies, not 1, what the hell. Hunter design was amazing, ones for that. Hunter Gamma was....ok, i prefer the original but it was ok. Drain Deimos Look cool but aren't dangerous if your careful. The originals were more of a threat. Licker made an appearance, which was too bad, but again, easy to dodge, just walk and don't make much noise, then it cant find you. No Large Spiders either, which since i'm an arachnophobe was a blessing, but at the same time, i kinda wish they had been. They were an enemy from the original games so....

Story again, could have been longer, so much more that could of been in this game. The fact content was cut, is an issue. They cut the Grave Digger, a classic foe, RE3s mini boss per say. They cut the Park, which they could of expanded on since the park section was short in the original and technically, they cut the dead factory too, though what they did was incorporate it into the hospital which at first i though was cool. But then i realized the problem with that. Umbrellas facilities are supposed to be hidden right, well, its not so hidden when dozens of trucks marked as part of umbrella are driving in and out the hospital and disappearing into a underground base which somehow no one knew about. Well, correction, 1 nurse noticed it in the weeks of the city's life but that's it? I was coming off of the Resi 2 remake and I expected it to be like that, but it was a lot more linear and each section was shorter. It's also anti-explorer as it has segments you can't get back to and sometimes it's during a chase or boss fight. The dialogue is ok, onto Nemesis. In cutscenes/scripted sequences, he is inconsistent with him being shown to break through a wall but not being able to burst through a door and bookshelf. He is also made to be a fool with his introduction showing he can't even catch one person who he got the jump on then being called a fuckface and slowed. He is not even a threat in dialogue and to characters, Brad talks of him nonchalantly, and Jill hasn't shown fear of him and just curses a lot seeming more annoyed than fearful. nemesis's gameplay is also bad as he can hit you multiple times without giving you a chance to react or even get up, He also has an insta kill attack so if you get kicked into a corner you're guaranteed to die. During his burning demolition building chase, he is slow and isn't much of a threat and on his rooftop boss battle, I did it without taking one bit of damage. He also doesn't ever fucking leave when you're in a safe room and he's outside. Overall it's a bad game but if it's on sale it's a decent play, I personally got it for 10 bucks and have been having some fun. 

Post-completion additions:
It all around is fun but not good, It's very short sadly and the story is poor. Throughout the game, Jill and Carlos are quipping and it killed the tension. The bossfights were very easy and the final boss was so easy I thought it would have multiple phases. The only time Nemesis ever kills is at the very end and it's a side character, unlike the original where he kills Brad at the very start. Nemesis also has his forms ruined, his second form is a dog unlike the original where he was still human and his final form falls into the RE Final Boss syndrome and is just a blob unlike the original which was creative with how it was like an animal near death and not a powerful final form. At the end they state the theme of the game in a weird unnatural way. Nicolai or whatever his name was, was written poorly and acted like a cartoon villain. They also took away the choice-making and didn't compensate with extra small campaigns like Resi 2 had or any extra campaign. Overall the story sucks and Nemesis sucked but it was fun to play.

Resident Evil 3 Remake is not a bad game. It's fun, I had my fun playing it on Playstation and now I'm replaying it on PC. I won't go into how much I love the RE franchise and how long I've been waiting for a remake of my favorite entry ever. I'll keep it short about the things I, as well as I imagine thousands of other players, don't like. Or hate, whatever.

1. Cut out content. Well, imagine waiting for your favorite moments to be presented in a glorious remake, only to find that they have been cut out. I wouldn't mind them being reimagined, but there's a lot of stuff missing. I would love to get that extra stuff as DLC, let it be my loss, but Capcom, just get to work and do it right.

2. The most iconic boss, Nemesis. I was scared of the original Nemesis as a kid, and I still am. The new Nemesis? He is not scary, he is not dangerous, he feels like just another boss you see in every video game. Every encounter with him in the original game was stressful, but in remake, even while playing for the first time, it was "meh". To the point that I feel like Mr. X is more scary in RE2 Remake. Such a shame.

3. The Raccoon City. In the OG there were a lot of places to explore. The remake feels like they have shrunk the map and it feels really small.

4. Replayability. Even if you go for all the challenges, achievements, and earning "S" on all the difficulties, it won't take you much time. I won't get into RE Resistance, that's another story.

5. The original costume as paid DLC? That's just pathetic. It should be unlockable for beating the game on hardest difficulty, not behind a paywall. Also, the costume looks worse it was in OG RE3.

Even though it's the worst Resident Evil remake Capcom has released so far, it's still a solid game and I like playing it. It just won't be at the top of my personal ranking of RE games. That's about it.

First off. This game is decent. It runs well, its beautiful, atmospheric and I ran into no bugs whatsoever in any of my play-throughs. If you want a nice little action adventure this game will suit your needs just fine.

That being said. I don't like this game. This is my second Resident Evil experience, previously I played RE2 Remake. Well the contrast is night and day. They simply don't compare. It's like they took the RE formula and streamlined it to the point of absurdity.

There is so little gameplay. There are several instances where you go from cutscene, to cutscene with only walking 4 steps yourself. The moment you start skipping through cutscenes after the first play-through you realize just how little interactivity there us. The interactive parts that are there? They aren't all that interesting.

My least favorite aspect of the game is the Tyrant. That's the big bad evil guy that keeps chasing you and can't be stopped. He shows his ugly mug 11 times throughout the game. Of those 11 times, 4 are boss fights with different stages. It takes 4 boss fights to kill it for good... That's just too many. After every boss fight you walk away like you killed it. Only for it to return. It's so frustrating. You'd think that after the 2nd boss fight, Jill would would grab a sledgehammer and start beating every inch of his body to pulp. Right? That's what I would do. But no.

That's not all where the writing fails. Jill is a tough badass. But in a modern way. She runs into characters that are delibearely mysagonistic just so she can show how tough she is. We get it, she's just as good as the boys are. Show don't tell, please. Good grief. I forgive this part because it's a japanese game and in Japan the male/female archetype rolemodels are a bit different from where I live. It's just cringe inducing whenever they resort to the Hollywood strong female character stereotype. That doesn't work for Hollywood, that doesn't work for Japan, that just doesn't work.

Honestly this review might be a bit bias since i don't even like the original nemesis, but i feel like i can review it anyway since i got 100% for some reason. clocking in at 50 hours to get all achievements this game is less than half the length it took me to get them all on RE2 and Village, so off rip I would already suggest anyone wait for a sale before buying it if you're going to.

Speaking on the game purely as a remake it does a terrible job, multiple entire areas from the original game were completely axed, namely the clocktower which happened to be my favorite section of the story. Secondly the ability to make choices at certain parts of the story were completely removed as well, the entire game is purely linear now. Thirdly there's little to no incentive to ever fight Nemesis for any reason anymore, the first few times you kill him he drops handgun parts then after that it's all ammo which you use way more than what he gives you anyways, say goodbye to fighting Nemesis and getting a new gun for it or continuously getting attachments from it because he's nothing but fast mr. X now.

All of the extra modes from the original do not make an appearance either, the story is all you get and that's all there is, which isn't much considering you can beat the hardest difficulty in under an hour and a half if you get the infinite rocket launcher (which doesn't take that long mind you, you'll find nothing really does in this game). It feels like this game is trying it's hardest to rush the story along so you'll go away.

To say something positive about the game however it takes the gameplay elements from the original that were either completely broken or just didn't work for RE at all like the dodge rolling and having to fight hordes of zombies all at once and actually makes them fun and functional for the short periods of time you get to do them. I actually found that when i took the time to fight Nemesis it was fun to do because it honestly felt like a souls boss each time he appeared, if only he dropped anything useful for doing so most the time.

All in all if you don't want to emulate the original or track down a $200 copy on ebay and just want to experience the story in a very brief summary, this is fine. But I would seriously caution you to wait for a big sale especially if you don't intend to 100% the achievements like I did as it is not even worth the $40 they ask for it.

Resident Evil 3 is a very strong, albeit slightly flawed, game. 

You get to revisit a certain place from RE2, which works very well, and the hospital area and onward is fantastic. The thing that drags the game down from an "excellent" score for me, is the combination of the narrow corridor-map of the city, and Nemesis. It's not as effective as Mr.X in RE2, and the whole chase feels too scripted. It's scary in the beginning, but drags on for too long (at least with the mechanics used here).

Also, the way the camera reacts when you're aiming, or getting into close combat, sometimes get in the way of a seamless playing experience (zooming in too close, being a bit jittery and unpredictable). This was not a problem in RE2. Not a huge issue, and RE3 still provides a great horror-action experience.

Otherwise, I like the characters (as usual) and the writing is fine, which fortunately feel more like action movies and games from back in the 90s and 00s, unlike the crap we mostly get nowadays, Though, I didn't play the original RE3 game. 

Also, the visuals in this game are stunning, while running consistently at a very high framerate. Afaik Capcom's engine seems to be a lot more optimised than UE5. No stuttering, and smooth + high framerate all the time, with all graphics settings maxed out. Impressive!

Just finished the original Resident Evil 3: Nemesis on the PS1 for the first time before playing this, so I have no nostalgia goggles going into this game. 

They did Jill dirty.

The entire experience is overly streamlined, all of the things that made the original unique like live selections are gone, several entire areas are removed from the original, boss fights were removed, tons of enemies were either removed or completely underutilized, the areas that remained were severely reduced in size and scope, it has lots of the worst elements of modern gaming (e.g. terrible dialogue, insufferable female characters, one-dimensional villains, male characters that can't stop telling the female protagonist how amazing she is, incredibly boring QTE's, one-button "cutscenes", way too many cutscenes relative to gameplay, etc.), there are no "horror" elements left to the game, optional endings were removed, the puzzles are gone, the exploration is gone, freeze rounds were replaced with useless mine rounds, there's no countdown sequence to the missiles at the end, etc. 

Worst of all, is that they made Jill a completely unsympathetic character, and they completely neutered Nemesis. Jill exhibited zero fear of Nemesis and just swore constantly at him without flinching. She wasn't a character; she was a caricature. There was nothing scary about Nemesis, no build up to his introduction, no development to make him intimidating as a villain, no real surprise encounters, no nothing. He just came off as an incompetent boogeyman, rather than the horrific killing machine hunting S.T.A.R.S. from the original. It was extremely lazy. 

The game felt incredibly rushed, watered down, stripped of anything that made the original good, and they insulted the original with their portrayal of Jill and the rest of the characters. Thank goodness I didn't buy this full price. What a huge missed opportunity.

Resident Evil 3, the latest installment in Capcom's iconic survival horror series, is a relentless rollercoaster of terror that will have your heart pounding from start to finish. As a longtime fan of the franchise, I couldn't wait to dive into Raccoon City once again, and Resident Evil 3 did not disappoint. 

First and foremost, the visuals are nothing short of breathtaking. Raccoon City has never looked so hauntingly beautiful, and the attention to detail in every decaying building and blood-splattered alley is a testament to the developers' dedication. The atmosphere is thick with tension, and the lighting effects add an extra layer of realism that immerses you in the apocalyptic nightmare.

Resident Evil 3 maintains the series' signature survival horror gameplay while introducing some exhilarating new elements. The over-the-shoulder perspective feels intuitive, and the controls are responsive, allowing for precise aiming when confronted by grotesque monstrosities. The addition of the dodge mechanic adds a layer of strategy to encounters, but timing is crucial, making every escape a heart-stopping experience.

While the narrative might not stray too far from the original, the storytelling is solid, and the characters are well-developed. Jill Valentine's journey is both compelling and emotional, and the supporting cast adds depth to the overarching plot. The game successfully weaves together horror and narrative, keeping you invested in the unfolding events.

In conclusion, Resident Evil 3 is a masterclass in survival horror, delivering a pulse-pounding, adrenaline-fueled experience that will linger in your nightmares. Capcom has once again proven why they are the maestros of the genre, and any fan of horror games owes it to themselves to experience the relentless terror that is Resident Evil 3.

"Resident Evil 3 Remake" is a comprehensive reimagining of the 1999 survival horror classic, "Resident Evil 3: Nemesis." This modernized version maintains the core essence of the original while delivering a fresh and thrilling experience. Here's an extensive review of why gamers should consider adding this title to their must-play list.

Visual and Audio Presentation:
The game inherits the impressive graphical prowess of the RE Engine used in the "Resident Evil 2 Remake," bringing Raccoon City to life with stunningly realistic visuals. The attention to detail in the environment, the character models, and the gruesome design of the creatures make for an immersive horror spectacle. The atmospheric sound design, from the groans of distant zombies to the explosive ordinance of the titular Nemesis, further pulls players into the game's terrifying world.

Story and Characters:
"Resident Evil 3 Remake" follows Jill Valentine, a former S.T.A.R.S. officer, as she navigates the zombie-infested ruins of Raccoon City. The narrative expands on the original plot, giving more context to Jill's character and fleshing out the story with cinematic cutscenes and interactions. The game also intersperses moments featuring Carlos Oliveira, providing an alternate perspective and gameplay experience.

Gameplay and Mechanics:
Capcom evolved the gameplay from the "Resident Evil 2 Remake," offering a faster-paced experience that aligns with Jill's character as a seasoned combatant. The addition of a dodge mechanic allows for more dynamic encounters with enemies and gives players a fighting chance against the relentless Nemesis. The game is more action-oriented, with plentiful resources and more opportunities for combat compared to its predecessor.

The Nemesis System:
The Nemesis, an unstoppable bio-weapon pursuing Jill throughout the game, is a highlight. This towering adversary has been reworked to be more terrifying than ever, with improved AI and unpredictable appearances that keep the tension high. His presence is a constant reminder of the stakes and adds urgency to the gameplay.

Exploration and Puzzles:
While "Resident Evil 3 Remake" streamlines some aspects of exploration compared to the original, it still offers a satisfying balance of combat, exploration, and puzzle-solving. The puzzles are intuitive and engaging, providing a respite from the action and rewarding logical thinking and observation.

Replayability:
The game encourages replayability through unlockables, difficulty settings, and challenges that offer rewards. Completing the game unlocks the shop where players can purchase powerful weapons and helpful items, incentivizing multiple playthroughs to acquire everything.

Production Value:
"Resident Evil 3 Remake" boasts high production values, from the quality of the voice acting to the fluidity of the animations. This polish extends to the user interface and overall design, creating a cohesive and user-friendly experience.

Tightened Experience:
The game streamlines the experience of the original, resulting in a more focused narrative and pacing. This approach may divide some fans of the original's more expansive exploration, but it also makes for a game that respects the player's time and keeps the adrenaline pumping from start to finish.

In conclusion, "Resident Evil 3 Remake" delivers a high-octane horror experience that successfully modernizes a classic. With its exceptional presentation, updated gameplay mechanics, and the ever-present threat of Nemesis, it offers both fans and newcomers a compelling adventure through the zombie apocalypse. While some may miss the depth of exploration from the original, the remake's cinematic flair and relentless pace make it a thrilling and worthy entry into the Resident Evil series.

Its clear this game was rushed out the door due to the success of RE2 Remake, because you can see it at every step you take.

Whole sections from the original have been cut out. Where's the  factory? Gone. What about the park? Gone. The gas station? You only get a 2 seconds glimpse of it, from a cutscene. The Clock Tower, the City Hall, all of that is gone.

Some other locations have also been changed or mixed with some new areas of the city. There's places where you spent a lot of time in the original going back and forth that now you simply can rush through in seconds and never go back.

Its a shame because the city is so well done. The whole atmosphere is great, and places like where you find Dario are crafted with so much attention to detail that you can't help but think IF ONLY they hadn't cut so much from the game...

But the cut content doesn't end with just some locations, enemies like crows or the Grave Digger are also nowhere to be found. 

The puzzles? There's not even a single one, unless you count the diamonds from the monument or the railway control as puzzles, which would be fucking laughable.

Even such an iconic moment from the original game if not THE MOMENT, which is when you first encounter Nemesis at the RPD, has been cut out too...
[spoiler]Now you don't even know what happens to Brad. Did he died right there where you left him? Did he escaped and died later? How did he managed to get from that bar to the police station? We'll never know.	[/spoiler]

The story has been changed a lot too. 

Some of these changes I can live with, but some others follow the same pattern as the rest, as if they were more concerned about putting all thought and effort into reaching the launch deadline rather than trying to make the remake as good as possible...

The beginning was changed for one I particularly didn't like much. The ending has changed too. Like mentioned earlier, whole areas are missing, and some fights were also moved/changed. It's not good.

I understand this was a remake and its supposed to be different and that would've been a welcome change if only they had shown some more respect for the original material, just like they did with previous remakes of the franchise.

Nemesis is more annoying and stupid than challenging or terrifying like in the original. They somehow thought it was a good idea to introduce him within five minutes from the very start of the game... 

THUS COMPLETELY REMOVING ANY SENSE OF SURPRISE OR DANGER TO THE FOLLOWING ENCOUNTERS THROUGHOUT THE REST OF THE GAME. 

What the fuck? When one of the best things about Nemesis in the original game, was how he introduced himself to the player...

And the sections where you encounter him through the city, pfft, you can see then coming a mile away. 
[spoiler]There's one part after you restore power to the tracks where all the zombies vanish and you can easily predict that he's going to appear, which he does... And to be fair its not scary, or surprising, its fucking stupid.	[/spoiler] While in the original, you never expected him to come out of that tiny window, it was probably the most 'OH SHIT' moment in the game, which this one is lacking. Instead of 'oh shit' moments, there's plenty of 'ha, I knew it' moments. Lame.

I could keep going on, since there's so much stuff that feels wrong... 

Why remove the ink ribbons? It completely defeats the survival horror aspect if you'll be stumbling upon saving machines every 5 minutes and you don't have to think or managed how you save, just save scum till the end...

There's even one ridiculous segment when Nemesis is chasing you with the flamethrower where you get 2 saving machines and 2 vaults in the span of 2 minutes. Literally, 2 minutes, while he is chasing you and you're supposed to be desperately running for your life, you get to sit down, relax, save, manage your items... Ah, whatever...

But because of that, and the fact that you practically never run out of ammo and healing items, makes the game not feel challenging at all. Hardcore mode is a joke, Nightmare is what Hardcore mode should've been, and Inferno what should be unlocked after beating the game on Hardcore (Nightmare).

Very disappointing, and what's worse, is that we'll never get a proper Resident Evil 3 remake anymore, this was it, and such a wasted opportunity...

So having JUST finished playing the game for the first time (haven't done any replays yet as of this writing), I must say... Resident Evil 3 Remake ended up being a big letdown for me in the end. I still had enough fun playing the game to finish it without it feeling like a chore to do so, and to be fair the game definitely HAS a few good things going for it (good soundtrack, immersive-looking world, a couple tweaks to some of RE2R's gameplay mechanics such as removing knife durability and adding a dodge mechanic that feels better than the original RE3's, and a couple good tension-inducing set-pieces such as the substation and several of the early in-game Nemesis chases, to name a couple examples), but sitting here reviewing the entire package now that I'm done playing it, my first impressions of the entire thing are mixed to negative, especially when viewing it as a remake of Resident Evil 3: Nemesis. 

In a nutshell, as a game that serves as a follow-up to Resident Evil 2 Remake I feel it's a letdown that doesn't measure up to it's overall more-polished predecessor, even if I admit the game is arguably fun enough on it's own depending on your mindset when playing the game... as a GAME. It's not a bad game to PLAY by any stretch, but it's a definite downgrade to everything the developers of RE2R had going for THEIR game, which still managed to keep most of the soul of the original RE2 as a survival horror game where you explore several complex, isolated locations with limited resources intact... which is more than I can say for RE3R, which on the whole feels closer to being a toned-down version of RE6 with an altered, compressed version of RE3's story than it does the original RE3, a game which cranked up the action from the original RE2 but was still at it's core a classic survival horror game similar to it's predecessor back in the day, albeit in a more open world (for the first half of that game, at least). 

Now, as a REMAKE of Resident Evil 3: Nemesis for the PlayStation 1... RE3R was simply awful. There's so much wrong with it in this respect that I feel that I could easily make my own dedicated video on the subject comparing this remake to the original on just this aspect alone, if I really wanted to. A short summary of things that come to the top of my mind, as of me having just finished the game, are as follows: Half the original game's content is missing (no clock tower, park, Dead Factory, most of Raccoon City's streets and buildings you get to explore are gone, no construction zone, the Gravedigger boss is completely gone, etc., etc..), a good bit of what DOES remain story/content-wise has been changed up in ways that feels inferior to the original more often than not, the changes in characterization feels like a mixed bag across the board (I do NOT like the changes to Jill and Nikolai's characters in this game, while everyone else I'm either neutral on or have no particular preference when compared to their original counterparts. Brad is the only character whose changed characterization I actually feel is an overall improvement from his original portrayal), the choice mechanic from the original game that influences how the story/game progressed is entirely absent (which was the source of most of the original RE3's replayability, but not here - apparently you play through RE3R once and you've already experienced everything the game's story has to offer), and they reduce the titular monster of the original game into a joke compared to his original incarnation -- one that the other characters treat more as an annoyance than a serious deadly threat to be feared (he isn't reduced to a joke in just story, either -- for most part he's been made into a joke during gameplay, too -- he's far less difficult than he was in the original game overall.). I'm just sitting here amazed at how much this game utterly failed to not only live up to my expectations as a follow-up to RE2R, but especially as a remake to one of my favorite games in the series. 

The game was arguably at it's best during the first 1/4, maybe a bit beyond that -- but once I defeated the Nemesis in his first actual boss battle, it seems like the overall quality of the game started to take a nosedive and kept going down all the way until the credits started to roll... which makes it quite frustrating for me because for that first quarter of the game I felt that I could see little hints of what this game COULD have been like if it had been given some more polish, but unfortunately a world where we got a remake of RE3 with a similar level of polish to the RE2 Remake is NOT the world we're living in right now.

So in conclusion, I'd recommend anyone who's looking into getting into the Resident Evil series to stick to the original game and avoid this remake -- the original is a far better game overall than this remake is, IMO. But if you absolutely MUST try this game for yourself, then get it on sale because I don't think RE3R has enough going for it to justify paying for it full-price... and even then I would STILL avoid playing it until AFTER you've played through the original Resident Evil 3 shortly beforehand, so that way you can experience all the differences from the original game for yourselves. But if you choose to think of and play RE3R as just a follow-up to RE2R instead of comparing it to the original game, then while it certainly could be a lot better... you could also do a lot worse than RE3R.

TL;DR Do not buy this game for any reason for any price. I’m not even joking - it’s that bad, mostly due to being 4 hours long at most, which is neither worth the full price nor the price it goes for on sale (10 bucks). Play the original. 

Earlier this year, I was greatly sick for a week. After recovering, I decided as a bit of a personal joke to myself to purchase this game while it was on sale for $10. I'd heard what people had said about it - It sucks as a remake, it's way too short, all that. But I did it anyway because I wanted more REmake gameplay and I saw no more fitting time to get some. 

Yeah, that was a mistake. 

Despite only being 10 bucks, this is one of the dumbest purchases of my life, and I am a clown for willingly, knowingly walking into this trap. I underestimated just how bad this game was and in how many ways it fails as a remake. 

I'll start with saying: I did get my wish - I got more REmake gameplay. Cool, nothing wrong there. Everything else though? Well, I'll summarize the main points: A hilariously inept and nonthreatening Nemesis, cut *important* content, references to the original being halfhearted at best, and overall a game so short that it isn't even worth buying on sale. I'll elaborate on each.

Nemesis: This guy is supposed to be a better, more threatening version of Mr. X from RE2 (a role he fulfills reasonably well in the original). Yeah no, he isn't - he only appears in scripted events, chases you for like maybe 5 seconds in gameplay, and the game gives you grenades to throw at him which will down him instantly if you really want him to stop his lackadaisical pursuit of you. In fact, that purpose is the sole reason why those grenades exist. In cutscenes, he also has Jill dead to rights multiple times, but manages to somehow fuck it up despite being what is supposed to be an unstoppable, ruthless killing machine, and additionally gets stopped by the most basic of means. At the very start of the game, he breaks through a wall like the kool-aid man, but no more than 20 seconds later, he can’t break through a locked door with one punch. Oh, and to quote Jill herself in this game: [spoiler]"Bitch can't even swim."[/spoiler] This Nemesis sucks and is not a threat whatsoever. If anything, you'll laugh at how bad he is at his job. 3make Nemesis dreams of being a tenth of the threat that 2make Mr. X is.

Cut content: Honestly, some content being cut from the original is fine, because not *everything* was important. For example, I don't care about the gravedigger being cut (he was a dumb boss anyway), but cutting the clock tower and Jill going to the police station? That's two vital moments of the game cut for...What reason exactly? Worse yet on both points (spoilers if you care): [spoiler] Carlos is the one who goes to the police station on a sidequest, but Jill, the STARS member, doesn't. As for the clock tower, you actually see it in the distance and you read a little informative pamphlet about it, but do you actually go there? LOL no. [/spoiler]

References to the original: Aside from the above, this game is desperate to prove that it knows it knows its original counterpart. There's a number of things from the original that are just kinda...there...and serve no real purpose other than to exist and delude the player into thinking they’re playing a real remake. "Haha, I promise we played the original RE3 guys, see? Look at my neat references!" Aside from the things mentioned already, one of the more glaring of these halfhearted references is Jill's "You want stars!?" line in this game, which is delivered at a really bad time instead of at the end of the game when Nemesis dies for good. You can tell the line was inserted randomly out of obligation because they knew people would notice and complain about its absence, but if it was going to be used at an improper moment, then it would have been preferable to have it absent. Come to think of it, "made out of obligation" actually describes this entire game's existence well.

As if the game didn't have enough problems, it is *short*, with very little if any replayability (I wonder why). I bought it on sale for 10 bucks and still felt robbed, and it is insulting that they tried to sell this garbage for full price. Obviously, they didn't try to hide the fact that this game was a cash grab in the wake of RE2make's success. 

In case it isn’t obvious, no, you shouldn’t buy this game. Being generous, it's worth 1 dollar per amount of play time, which comes out to 4 dollars at most, but aside from the fact that it will never be that cheap, to be blunt, I'd say it's barely worth a penny. I'd say this is the worst RE title by far...Or at least I would were it not for the fact that I'm going to pretend this game just doesn't exist. 

I have so many more problems with this game that it's difficult to list and expand on all of them, but I've tackled the key points, so I think you get the gist. The game sucks as a remake, is mediocre as a game, and too short to be sold as a full fledged game. 

Play the original. This game isn't worth buying even on sale.

Oh, and whoever came up with *that* scene? Touch grass.

I don't particularly love the original Resident Evil 3: Nemesis, but I do have a fond nostalgic feeling that comes to mind when I think about it. I was really excited when I heard RE3 was getting a remake and had my hopes up that they would improve on the original to make a stand-up title just like the RE2 remake. Resident Evil games aren't traditionally too long and I ignored what I had heard in regards to this game's length and tried it anyway. I'm normally a fan of short and sweet games also, so I should've liked this game yeah? No, I fucking hate this game. This game is short and sucks and feels like a fat con even on sale for $40. The "replayability factor" that is additional harder difficulty modes and a store for buying new things for later playthroughs mine as well not even exist because the game left such a bad taste on the first go. Stupid cutscenes up the ass. Locations that made the original game memorable (i.e. Raccoon Park, Graveyard, Clock Tower, Dead Factory) aren't even present for the likely reason of time crunch. The Grave Digger is nowhere to be found in this game which makes a little bit of sense because the fights with it sucked in the original. However, it's not like it was impossible to make them better and improve upon the groundwork instead of entirely writing it out of the game. Reused assets from the RE2make are strewn about as well as the final area of the game being lazy enough to just be a fucking white lab again, taking away the identity that the original had of containing its climax in a dingy, disgusting, rusty factory full of suspense as to when Nemesis would show up again. When does Nemesis show up in this game? **Resident Evil 3: A Psychedelic Odyssey**

Alright, buckle up folks, because we're about to dive headfirst into the wild, wacky, and wonderfully unhinged world of Resident Evil 3. Now, I'm not saying you should play this game while under the influence of hallucinogenic fungi, but if you were to hypothetically find yourself in such a state, you might just discover that this game takes on a whole new dimension.

First off, let's talk about the graphics. They're so realistic you'll swear those zombies are right in your living room. And when you're seeing double (or triple) thanks to those shrooms, well, let's just say the horde feels a lot more...horde-y.

The storyline? Oh boy, it's like a rollercoaster ride through a haunted house on steroids. You've got your classic zombie apocalypse scenario, but with so many twists and turns you'll feel like you're in a labyrinth. And when your sense of time is as warped as a Dali painting, well, it's like living through your very own epic saga.

The gameplay? It's intense. Every decision feels like life or death (because it usually is). And when your reflexes are as unpredictable as a cat on catnip, well, let's just say it adds an extra layer of challenge.

But the real kicker? The atmosphere. It's so immersive you'll forget you're sitting on your couch in your underwear. The eerie music, the chilling sound effects, the dimly lit corridors...it all combines to create a sense of dread that's palpable. And when you're already seeing shadows move out of the corner of your eye...well, let's just say it makes for an unforgettable experience.

So there you have it. Resident Evil 3: not just a game, but a journey into the depths of your own psyche. Just remember to keep telling yourself: it's only a game...

And hey there, darling reader! If you enjoyed this review and found it helpful or entertaining (or both), any rewards would be highly appreciated. But remember - no pressure! 😉 

Disclaimer: This review is purely hypothetical and for entertainment purposes only. Always remember to game responsibly.

While still excellent, RE3 does not quite meet the high standard set by its predecessor RE2 (Remade). Its tone is slightly different, and that is fine. Whereas RE2 was gothic, claustrophobic and brooding, RE3 is urban, hectic, and action-packed. It is sort of what Aliens (2) and Terminator 2 were to Alien and Terminator; but without the wide scope and the memorable characters that made those sequels truly great. From what i understand, the game that reaches such heights is RE4.

Compared to RE2, RE3 is just a bit too short and too crammed. Even the safe rooms feel too close to each other. You only get one campaign, compared to the two we had in RE2. And the one campaign is shorter and recycles some RE2 environments, include a whole part of the police station.

Still, RE3's campaign is a great one. Jill is a cool character, and the RE engine is just spectacular. Seeing events unfold in Raccoon City from a different angle is kind of fun. Some of the action sequences are superb, and the opening in Jill's apartment sets the tone brilliantly.

Typically I'd rate such a title at 8/10; but the insane production values propel it to a 9/10. Very much worth playing as a standout genre title and a fun and good-looking action-horror.

People love to hate this game. It's not perfect for sure, there's definitely room for improvement. But it's nowhere near as bad as people make it out to be. Not at all denying there are reasons to dislike it, but that depends on where your focus is. If those people would (pardon my french) get their heads out of their asses, they'll see there are more reasons to love this game than to hate it.

First of all, the game is NOT short. Look at speedrunner times, and you'll see even if by mere minutes, remake IS longer. The reason it feels short is because it is too linear. There is very little backtracking, and not a whole lot of challenging puzzles. That is pretty much all that this game is lacking.

In the original game, you would reach the cable car after clearing the Uptown and Downtown maps. Then you would need to get the car running. Remake starts at this exact point, so we can safely say we have those 2 maps removed. I'm not defending that they were probably forced to do this in order to meet deadlines. I (and pretty much everyone else too I reckon) would have gladly waited for another year, or 2, even 3, to get the absolute best game that we could have gotten. There's too much wasted potential here. You can see this in the game. There were clearly great ideas on the table. And some made it through, but unfortunately, the rest didn't.

But I still love this game. There may be heavy bias on my part because Jill is my absolute favorite character in the series, and my childhood hero. I've recently passed 400 hours in the game, and I enjoyed every minute of it. Sure Inferno Nemesis keeps pissing me off royally. But I like the challenge. There's nothing my Jill can't accomplish.

The game is not a frame by frame reworking of the original, unlike 1 and 2. There are a lot of changes and creative differences. Clock Tower is gone, but now you have the Sewers. Dead Factory is gone, but now you have Nest 2. Park is gone, but now you have an underground section of the Hospital - Hospital, which now you can explore with Jill. Unfortunately she doesn't go into RPD, as per the removal of Downtown map as I said earlier. It is what it is.

In the end the graphics are beautiful, Jill is gorgeous, fierce, brave and sassy, the storyline is improved, dodging mechanic is better, locations and the flow is more fluid, files are more part of the overall story and helps fill in many blanks, voice acting is top notch.

If a game has you wanting the work day to be over so you can come home and play it, it's a good game in my book.

Resident Evil 3’s Remake is not necessarily a bad game, but when you put it up next to the remake for 1 and 2, it’s a little tough to not walk away disappointed. I’ve never played the original games, but I did leave this game wishing that it had been more of an experience akin to the other remakes.

This game seems to take more inspiration from games like Uncharted than the actual Resident Evil series, and the sheer number of “hold forward” scripted hallways makes this rather evident for me. Along with this, it’s pretty unfortunate how many areas are just short little jaunts rather than full-fledged areas to explore. A good example of this is the sewers, which can be blasted through in as little as ten to fifteen minutes even if you’re trying to really stretch the game out. 

I just wish there was more here. It’s not a bad game, not at all, it’s just disappointing. It's still worth a playthrough, and it's a solid game overall, but it's tough to not wish for more here.

Unlike the success of RE2R, this game is a blueprint for how NOT to make a remake. This was a major letdown. But there are a few stellar things I'd still like to praise, which I'll get to shortly. Now, as for why I'd "recommend" this with the many issues it has, is simply because of my undying RE bias. Let the dissension commence.

Pros: 
- Gameplay is fun. It's smooth and easy to get used to.
- Visually stunning. Loved getting to see downtown Raccoon City in the RE Engine.
- Despite his disappointing appearance, Nemesis' functionality is fairly solid. A lot of scripted chases, but the terror he provides is still what I was wanting. He's a menace to get by and creates tension and fear around every corner.
- Character designs were great. Carlos benefited the most in terms of his character redesign.
- Opening escape sequence was great.

Cons:
- Let's get the worst offender out of the way: CUT CONTENT. Removing the sequence at the clock tower, the park area, the power plant, etc. But that's just the areas. Getting rid of the multiple endings from the og, someone deciding it was good idea to not include Barry in the end scene and many more frustrating story elements they decided to remove. I digress.
- Nemesis' appearance. God awful. Plain and simple.
- The bad hospital defense sequence. Hoards of enemies that come in easy-to-manage waves. Not challenging at all. Feels lazy and carries on for far too long.
- Two Nemesis boss battles having pretty much the exact same patterns of attack. And aside from a subtle change in the second fight, its really easy to figure out. More laziness.
- NOT ENOUGH NEMESIS. For a game literally based around this hulking monstrosity, they failed to give him enough of a spotlight.
- And lastly, this game felt extremely rushed. So much more time and care needed to be applied here.

Overall, if you're looking for a good remake, turn away. This game isn't for you. But if you're looking for great gameplay with amazing visuals, go right ahead. So if you do decide to embark, I hope you're able to enjoy. --- [b][i]7.7/10[/i][/b]

Pour the soy sauce and beef broth (or water). Let boil. Cover and cook in low heat for 40 minutes or until the pork gets tender. Add more beef broth or water if the liquid starts to dry quickly.
Pour-in the vinegar. Let the liquid re-boil. Stir and cook for 8 minutes.
Taste your pork adobo and decide to add salt if needed.
Transfer to a serving plate. Serve.

Even though it is a linear shooter, the entire world feels just as put together as any open world would, with it feeling like you'll be able to go around any corner and find something of interest. The lack of super narrow hallways is appreciated so much as I feel it suits the game play way more.

Also, Nemesis is utilized in such a fun and great way, other than the fact that there is the same boss battle twice.

Solid third person shooter, but keep in mind, they've cut a tremendous amount of content that was in the original game. So what you're seeing here is basically a short, watered-down version of RE3. 

Let's start off with some positives:
- Graphics look absolutely gorgeous and detailed; Carlos' facial hair detail looks especially badass
- Shooting and gun mechanics are enjoyable, polished and surprisingly smooth
- Perfect Dodge mechanic; adds more variety in gameplay 
- Easy, fun game to pick up; It's great for casual gamers, or even people that want to try the RE franchise for the first time
- Banter between Jill and Carlos is refreshing
- The first bossfight is surprisingly enjoyable to fight

Negatives:
- It's way too goddamn short for a modern single player game. Look by all means the classic is quite short too, around 3 hours playtime if you know what you’re doing, but this is bad by modern standards (Finished a standard run with cut-scenes, exploration, backtracking and it took me 3 1/2 hours to complete)
- We get to finally see what happened street-level in Raccoon City but it's not enough, would love to see an expanded city level with more content
- Puzzles are an absolute joke; baby level complexity. While i'm not here for the puzzles, it wouldn't hurt to add some challenge to them
- Cut content; Where's the Grave Digger bossfight? Spiders? Freeze rounds? Where's the Clocktower level? Park? City Hall? Dead Factory? Why is the last level replaced with goddamn lab level again?
- No Live-selection or branching paths
- No Mercenaries mode
- No costumes varieties 
- Nemesis is scripted and so tame compared to Mr.X
- Scripted linear segments disrupting the pacing; going back and forth between Jill and Carlos feels disjointed
- Dismemberment is worst in this game, the gore noticeably dialed back from RE2 Remake
- Copy and pasted enemies from RE2 Remake like the paleheads
- The 2 boss fights where nemesis runs in circles are exactly the same 
- Reeks of rushed development in order to get the game out early; obvious cash grab
- They tried adding a multiplayer mode in a RE singleplayer game that was dead on arrival. So dead to the point they even split the installation in case you don't want it; Nobody asked for a Dead by Daylight clone, go remake Outbreak Files or some shit as standalone 
- Replayability is reduced to difficulty runs, not to mention you can buy dlc and skip all the challenges to unlock the rewards you would get by playing regularly
- Too much ammo variations for the Grenade Launcher, you're gonna die swapping ammo types because the reload animation always loads the full magazine instead of the actual number of missing ammo

Overall 5/10.

Honest judgement? Kind of disappointed by the effort Capcom put in. It’s a watered down, flawed, but fun third-person shooter that’s devoid of all elements which made the original RE3 game and new remakes great to begin with. Whether or not you’re a casual or hardcore fan, definitely not worth the full price tag, so always get it on sale.

This game is a mixed bag, it's fundamentally very different from the original RE3, the focus on action is visible from the get go, the game is completely linear (with the exception of the initial run through downtown) and there are almost no puzzles on it. The combat for the most part is very good, the dodge mechanic is a welcome addition to the game, it was something that everyone who did runs for RE2R would have liked, the weapons in the game are a lot more useful than before, unlike RE2R now the shotgun isn't practically useless for everything other than zombies, and the harder difficulties don't put you in a situation where certain enemies become mandatory skips due to low damage (Lickers), the only real problem in the games combat being the stunlocks in the final Nemesis fight on Inferno. With combat out of the way, RE3 loses a lot of the charm from the original! Jill's personality has a series of changes which may or may not put people off (mainly she seems a bit arrogant at points) and the treatment of Nemesis is very lackluster (unlike what we got with Mr X, NEMESIS is completely scripted, outside of boss battles, he'll show up during 4 moments while free roaming downtown, other than that he's absent from the rest of the game), entire sections of the game where completely removed and the 3rd Nemesis fight is just a repeat of the second one but this time with Zombies added into the mix. The game also has a few problems including a problem with HDR that messes up your colors and a glitch that can cause your game to crash while entering the STARS Office with Carlos (if you are doing a non competitive speedrun save at the beginning of the RPD) and in true REngine fashion the game has very lackluster RT implementation and due to the forced TAA it's not a good idea to use FSR (or even DLSS if you do happen to install the DLSS mod). I'm having a blast with this game because I've been an RE fan since I was a kid, with that being said, if you are adamant that you want a full on perfect reenactment of the original game, I'm sorry but this game isn't for you, furthermore, if you want to get a good value out of this game, wait for a sale to buy it, because it's very short, even if you do want to replay it. I did my first run in 3h40 mins, the rest of my playtime has either been farming kills for records, or replaying the game on different difficulties. Notes: The Final Nemesis fight on Nightmare/Hardcore is BS! It's not difficult to dodge, but it's absurd!

A fast paced, atmospheric, and action laden survival horror game, with one of the most terrifying bosses I've every experienced.

I played a demo of this with my friends growing up and Nemesis scared the every-loving crap out of us. I have always wanted to play through this story and while I have still never played the original fully, I thoroughly enjoyed this remake. I know it has been divisive with the cuts they made, but someone summed it up pretty well. They removed elements that were not directly related to our protagonists story and slowed down the pace of the action. This feels like an action game first. I still enjoyed the breaks you got in between encounters and the puzzles, but shorter more focused story was pretty nice. We got even more enemy variety this time and the ability to dodge was really handy (while not always effective ... lol). Nemesis still scared the pants off me when he would barge in like the Kool-Aid man, and I enjoyed the hell out of running from him. Combat mechanics felt a bit more enhanced with being able to use the environment to your advantage (generators and flammable barrels). There were also several combat set pieces that were kind of puzzle-like that you had to figure out, and added to the variety which I enjoyed. You mainly play through this as Jill Valentine but switch over to Carlos (an Umbrella combat specialist) several times as well. Seeing things from both perspectives at different times in the story was pretty nice, and added to the overall experience in my opinion.

I played entirely on Steam Deck and it played flawlessly. I had it set to high/medium mix graphics, and locked it to 40fps and 40hz refresh rate. It took me a little under 8.5 hours to complete.

Overall, a solid entry in the franchise and definitely one I enjoyed. Highly recommend if you haven't played, just know it is more action focused.

That this still has the same price tag as the Resident Evil 2 Remake is appaling. This is basically DLC for RE2R. So much content from the original RE3 was cut that calling it a remake is honestly a disgrace. Imagine charging 60 bucks (originally) for basically a stand-alone DLC.

I don't dislike the game overall, in a vaccuum it's *decent*, again mostly thanks to the fact that it just reuses RE2R, but it's just not worth the asking price. Always get it on sale.

TL;DR This is a good game in a vacuum. Mechanically it's pretty good. The music is good, the atmosphere is good, the monsters are memorable. But as a *remake*, and a sequel to the RE2 Remake, it is very, very disappointing. But only in that respect. So if you want a remake of an original, this performs poorly. If you just want an isolated sequel to RE2R, then it's pretty good. What follows will go in depth about this opinion.

This game is conflicted in what it wants to be. It felt like it was being designed by two different teams at the same time; one that was committed to being a loving tribute to the original RE3, and one that didn't care.
On the one hand, you have the music; modern, atmospheric, bringing back the original RE3 score and perfecting it in one of the most lovingly nostalgic tributes to an OST I can remember hearing in a game. You have the atmosphere; dark, oppressive, bleak. The city is dying, death and despair are consuming it, and it FEELS like it. The environments are grimy, bloody, smashed, burning and crumbling. It sells the setting perfectly. It feels like a wonderful modernisation of the sights of RE3. It absorbs you into it. It looks convincing.

On the other hand, you have the plotline. It seems to rush through the story without letting any particular segment of it *breathe*. Like a tour guide leading you through a museum at a jog rather than walking through slowly, teling you the history and answering your questions.
You have the removal of whole segments from the original. The Police Station which should have been Jill's first stop, is never visited by her, and instead is a short detour for Carlos. The park is completely missing. The Clock Tower has been turned into a distant background landmark you may miss entirely if you're focused on your immediate surroundings and the boss fight that takes up most of the time it's visible. In the original it was an entirely separate location you had to explore. There were plot points tied to it; an escape route. It was a refuge, and a character-switch point.
Then you have the main antagonist, Nemesis. Arguably one of the most powerful and dangerous of Umbrella's various Tyrants. The original Pursuer of the franchise. He's been downgraded from a semi-persistent threat that pursues you from location to location to 3 brief encounters in the first 25% of the game and 3 setpiece boss fights for the rest of it. This is especially noticeable after RE2R's Mr. X and his stellar reimagining as a persistent pursuer; the role that should have been Nemesis's hallmark.
There's also the removal of the branching decision and diverging plotline system; a feature that introduced a lot of replayability in the original. As a result the game can be experienced in its entirety in one playthrough. The lazy difficulty system offers none of that replayability, as it can basically be summarised as "everything is faster and hits harder".

And then there's RE: Resistance, which is an online multiplayer subgame that was packaged alongside it, and which inherently has a low and dwindling playerbase which will eventually render it worthless. The development time for this would have been much better spent focusing on the main game itself and making sure it was as expansive and well polished as it really should have been.

It all just feels discordant. Like Capcom considered this game an afterthought while they worked on RE8. And it's a shame. Because the RE-Engine and the formula they achieved with the RE2 Remake could have made this game timeless.

I am giving this game a thumbs down because I imagine a lot of people coming to this game will be fans of the franchise itself, as opposed to new players coming to experience Resident Evil with no prior experience. On that basis, this game doesn't live up to its predecessors, neither RE2R, nor the original RE3. But if you just want to experience an RE game in the vein of RE2R and have no knowledge of the original, then this is a good game to play.

Honest review as a huge fan of this series since its inception.

Since 2017, CAPCOM has released:

- RE7 Biohazard
- RE8 Village
- RE2 Remake
- RE3 Remake
- RE4 Remake
- Many DLCs to go along with each, to include some story DLCs (RE4 Separate Ways, etc.)

Of all of the above listed, this is my least favorite, but solely for the slight downgrades in:

- Model Physics 
- Environment
- Lighting
- Shadow Quality
- Action Effects
- Sound Design

All of those that were listed above were drastically downgraded from the RE2 remake that released prior to this game. I feel that this game was rushed, as between RE2 and RE4 this is the only game where these downgrades are the most noticeable. With all of the downgrades, this remake does seem to capture the same gameplay and photo-realistic character models that RE2 remake had. Watch a comparison video to fully understand the difference. 

Above all, I feel that this game lacks conviction. A lot of missions were overlooked from the original RE3. I have 3.5 hours in this game. It took me less than a day to complete the entire game on Inferno, the hardest difficulty. Whereas it took me 10.5 hours to complete the first run of the RE2 on Hardcore, and I've just started the 2nd run on Professional. For the RE4 remake, same thing. 19 hours on my first playthrough in Hardcore, and I've just started a second playthrough on Professional. This is not even including any gameplay in the extra survivors mode in RE2 or the Mercenaries and story DLC in RE4. RE3 has no extra game modes. Although you do get some cool buffs after the first completionm, RE3 lacks the repeatability of the RE2 and RE4 remake because the game is so short and does not have multiple character story lines.

This is all, thanks.

Plays more like a junky side campaign for Resident Evil Two than an actual game of its own. Boring story, clumsy combat and repetitive environments.


As the game opens it establishes a fairly interesting backstory for the protagonist, however that backstory becomes largely irrelevant as the plot just becomes: there's zombies, don't die. That's basically the story of this game. There are zombies. Do not die. In five hours the game fails to construct any kind of more interesting overarching narrative than that nor does it really fill the survival struggle with any kind of engaging character interactions; besides Carlos aggressively flirting with Jill right to start. Which is just creepy and off-putting.

The combat is similar to that of the previous game to an extent, fairly rudimentary shooting with little gameplay variety. In an attempt to make the combat more interesting since it's being recycled into another game; the developers added a dodge feature. Except it's not really a dodge feature it's more of a quick-time-event disguised as a reactive dodge. While playing as Jill players can press the dodge button to stumble rapidly in a direction to avoid attacks. However this dodge has no invulnerability frames and thus often fails to actually protect players from harm. To trigger the real dodge, which has invulnerability frames, players need to press the dodge button right before an attack reaches them. Except this mechanic isn't explained to the player at all; which makes the game a frustrating mess until it is learned.

Many enemies in the game will ram themselves into the player's face then trigger an attack, forcing the player to perform their quick-time-event dodge just to avoid it. Until the player realizes how this works they are potentially doomed to take damage over and over because they don't understand their primary method of avoiding harm. Even when learning how the mechanic works, players must still learn the timing on each individual enemy attack to be able to utilize the dodge fully. This perpetual system of trial and error creates a spectrum of extremes where the player either cannot dodge attacks at all because they do not know the timing, or cannot get hit at all because they now know the timing and thus can consistently dodge.

There's also no stun-lock protection in this game, so players can straight up just get stun-locked into a game over by certain enemies or groups of enemies. Enemies may randomly attack twice in a row when a dozen other times they only attacked once, or have artificially accurate tracking on their attacks, or have attacks with basically no telegraph that are consequently impossible to dodge at close range in a game that is constantly about fighting in close quarters. The game hides enemies around corners, or has them approach from out of sight on multiple occasions to ambush the player and lock them into an unfair grapple. Unlike the previous game there's no way to counter grapples, players just have to mash a button to force the enemy off them. Except even if players press the button extremely fast they still take damage anyways, which makes the whole mechanic of being forced to mash the button at all feel pointless. 

Players are also constantly forced to stop and repeatedly stab every zombie they knock down, to check if the zombie is actually dead or not while also conserving ammunition. Resulting in a decent chunk of the gameplay becoming consumed by the player rapidly spamming their knife attack on most enemies at least once or twice to avoid future danger.

In general the combat in this game is very punishing yet so clumsy, cramped and cluttered that the game mostly ends up punishing players for its own mechanical shortcomings. Playing on the easier difficulties may reduce the impact of these unfortunate moments but they still occur all the same, and playing on the harder difficulty actively makes these situations a defining aspect of the gameplay experience.

Another baffling design choice was adding a weapon into the game that is borderline necessary for at least one boss fight, but carrying that weapon is completely optional and thus the player may end up in that boss fight without it. Yet if players do bring this weapon they can amass enough ammunition to basically stun-lock certain bosses and trivialize the fight. The also game has multiple moments where it transitions from cutscene to gameplay abruptly with no warning at all yet punishes players with an immediate game over if they don't react instantly. Multiple achievements in the game even spoil upcoming plot elements.

Not only does this game include multiple maps that are reminiscent of those from the previous game, which makes the atmosphere feel stale, but it also has players outright return to one that was in the previous game.


Repetitive and terribly balanced combat with an emphasis on meaningless quick-time-events that overshadow the already skimpy shooter combat system. Strung together by a monotonous, empty story with little to no intrigue or depth. All of which takes place in very same looking generic environments, at least one of which is directly ripped from the previous game under the guise of this story taking place at approximately the same time. Which doesn't even make sense as the environments are slightly changed from the previous game in ways that canonically do not coincide with the fact that this is supposedly happening at around the same time.

This game doesn't even manage to just be a bland repetition of the previous game, as the combat system has now been skewed around jumping through quick-time-event hoops yet this core mechanic is not explained to the player nor does it properly work some of the time. And even when it does work; it's just boring. Now the sensation of blandness has transformed into the feeling that this is just a really overpriced and badly balanced DLC campaign for the previous game.

What an awful Remake. 

The opening city segment is great. Not better than the original, but still great. But once you get to the end of it (which happens way too quickly with how short this game is), the game starts to fall apart. I know I'm kicking a dead horse at this point, but Nemesis is a complete joke in this game. Instead of being a tank that hunts you down and requires a full arsenal to down, he's a little scripted bitch with a goofy fucked up nose that can be downed with one grenade. On top of that, most of the rewards he gives you are useless, compared to the super powerful magnum and shotgun parts, as well as an item that can carry three first aid sprays at once in the original. They even turn him into a dog halfway through the game. In the original he'd slowly mutate more and more throughout the game to the point where he's unrecognizable, growing tentacles and larger veins, and then just becoming a pile of mush at the end. In this Remake he only transforms twice, and neither design does a good job at showing how the mutation works. They already perfected it with Birkin in RE2 OG and Remake. That also reminds me that they already had the perfect Nemesis in RE2 Remake as well, that being Mr. X.

Almost every location in this game is either boring, or completely gone from the original. Like I said, the City segment is really great at first. I love the 90's look everything has. But then you get to the power station, which introduces one of the most annoying enemies in the series (the Drain Deimos), and then you have your first real encounter with Nemesis, where you learn that he's scripted, easily taken out and easily manipulated. After that you get a boring sewer section with one type of enemy that requires zero brain power to kill, two more scripted Nemesis sections, and the first Carlos section. It was nice getting some more Carlos bits compared to the original, and the RPD section as Carlos in the Remake is alright, but it was way cooler going through it as Jill in the original. Jill had prior history there, so it felt much more interesting going through the place a second time as her (depending on if you played RE2 beforehand), and because she was the one going through it, Nemesis shows up and chases you, which is very startling on a first playthrough. You then take back control over Jill, and get to the most disappointing part of the game. The Clock Tower.

The Clock Tower is now a background set piece for the first Nemesis Dog boss fight, which drags on for way too long, or even longer if you don't bring the grenade launcher (which the game expects you to randomly do on a first playthrough). The Clock Tower was one of the best parts of the original, and now it's just in the background of a boring boss fight. On top of that, they also cut out the Park area from the original, which is less talked about, but is still a great area with a great boss fight that was ALSO cut out.

Luckily, after this disappointment of an area, we get to the best part of the game, which is the Hospital section. The Hospital section is the only part of the game that I'd say is better than the original. It has a very good horror atmosphere that isn't found in the original, and it's really fun exploring while looking for resources and items that'll get you into locked rooms. It does introduce another one of the most annoying enemies in the game (this game's version of the Hunters), but I think everything else in this section is good enough to make up for it. The defense section at the end of Carlos's part is pretty weak, but afterwards you get to backtrack through the Hospital as Jill to find some more resources that were locked off from Carlos and a new weapon, which was also pretty fun. But, just like every section in this game, the Hospital section goes by way too fast, and you'll be jumping straight back into mediocrity with the final section of the game.

The Laboratory as a location isn't bad, but when it's the final area in a series for the third time in a row, it's pretty repetitive. And what makes it even worse is that the original already knew that and made a brand new location called the Dead Factory that, as you can guess, was a Factory instead of a Laboratory, and was really fun to explore. Capcom literally went out of their way to replace a brand new location in the series with a location that we already had in RE1 and RE2 Remake, as well as Original RE1 and RE2.

Even when you just look at it as a game in general instead of a Remake specifically, it's mediocre. 6 hours is way to short for a $40 dollar game. I see a lot of people argue that the Original is also short, but the original was made in 1999, it's gonna have it's limitations, and even with the limitations, it still managed to be two hours longer than this Remake. There's literally no excuse for a game in 2020 to be $40 for 6 hours of gameplay, which is the length of a first playthrough, might I add. I've already mentioned how aside from most of the city section and the Hospital section that every location is boring to go through and why they're boring to go through, and I've also already mentioned how annoying the Drain Deimos and Hunters are. I haven't, however, mentioned how shitty the dodge mechanic is in this game. The timing on it is really odd and it only ever works 20% of the time. People also like to defend the dodge by saying it sucked in the original, which it definitely did, but just like the length of the game, the original was made in 1999. This Remake was made in 2020. They had 21 years to fix this dodge, and they failed. On top of that, at least you didn't have to use the dodge in the original. In the Remake, there are multiple points where you'll take unavoidable damage if you don't use the dodge, and on the hardest difficulty (something I did on console), you're required to use the dodge during the final boss, or you'll be caught in a stun lock and will pretty much be insta-killed.

I'll say this though. I'm glad that newcomers to the series or people who just don't have access to older consoles have some type of way to experience this game.

Doesn't stop it from being a shitty Remake and a mediocre game though.

I loved the original Resident Evil games from the PS1 era and have recently acquired remakes of RE2 and RE3. After playing through RE2 with both characters (it was great!), the time has come to tackle Resident Evil 3: Nemesis.
The story of RE3 takes place in Raccoon City, roughly at the same time as the events that transpired in RE2. You are Jill Valentine, a member of Raccoon City elite police force unit called S.T.A.R.S. As in every survival horror game, your main goal is to survive. The city is totally overrun by zombies, plus there's a seemingly invincible super-zombie (Nemesis) that's jumping out of every bush trying to kill you.
Resident Evil 3 is a lot more action-oriented than its predecessor. Jill has the ability to dodge attacks by rolling to the side, which is extremely useful (especially in boss fights). Zombies and other monstrosities are plentiful, but so are the healing items and ammo. There is more than enough ammunition to pulverize every single enemy you encounter, whilst in RE2 I was counting bullets and struggling at every corner (I played both on 'standard' difficulty). Also, almost all puzzles were cut from the original game, along with fair bits of story that came with them. You can easily complete the campaign in about 5-6 hours without skipping anything, which is terribly little. Considering there are no bonus game modes, I'm left wondering why didn't Capcom include more content instead of cutting a large portion of the original game?
In terms of presentation, RE3 is the same as its predecessor - which is good. Everything looks crisp and realistic, and sound effects are on-par with graphics. The game is pretty fun to play, since you're loaded like Rambo and there are tons of zombies to kill. The atmosphere is still creepy, but lacks that distinct survival-horror touch (probably because you have 10+ healing items in stash, along with bombs, grenade launcher and whatnot).
In my opinion, turning this remake into a brainless shooter was a poor decision by Capcom. It's still a pretty fun game and I'd recommend it, but it could have been so much more.

Okay, so this one is the shortest Resident Evil that I've played and pretty straightforward as far as progression and puzzles. It's definitely a fun game and the voice acting impressed me.

You can say it's often a "hold W simulator" but I think the level design team did a really great job here within their constraints of scope. It had to be super lean due to time/budget due to someone higher up not providing the support this game NEEDED but for something this compact, they did really well with polishing it. It's especially evident in the later playthroughs when they move and replace the enemies in surprising ways.
