I recommend this game with a heavy heart. R3make is a seriously fun game that could’ve been so much more. The remake inspired me to play the original Resident Evil 3: Nemesis, but in turn made me realize how uninspired the R3make is. In terms of character control, graphical fidelity, and the writing/character development in cut scenes, the R3make makes obvious upgrades over the original. Jill controls wonderfully making combat fluid and dynamic. In cut scenes, Jill and the rest of the cast feel well written and fully realized with some of the most human-like facial animation I have seen. The RE engine renders Racoon City in gorgeous detail but this ties into where the game faulters. Where RE2R went all in on the Racoon City Police Department, sewers, and labs, R3make level design and scope pales in comparison to the original. Racoon City streets are significantly underdeveloped, the sewers and labs feel copy pasted from RE2R, and the infamous clock tower is somehow absent. The hospital level in R3make is the only noticeable improvement, but even that is hampered by a wave defense segment that feels out of touch with the rest of the game. Taking R3make on its own for what it is, the game delivers a very fun and action heavy Resident Evil experience. However, it fundamentally fails as a remake and makes one wish what could have been.

Never played OG RE3 so I can't compare it to that. But I had a great time playing this game in and out of itself. 

It's what I would call a "rollercoaster ride" game a la Half-Life 2, Dead Space 2 or even RE4. The game is short and linear but incredibly well paced and keeps pushing you forward to the next set piece. If you want a great action game that is horror themed this is for you. If you want a more subtle, atmospheric survival horror game a la RE2 Remake, Dead Space 1 etc. then keep walking buster, because this ain't it.

It borrows a lot of its mechanics, assets and general feel from RE2R, which is why I think a lot of people were disappointed, because gone is the slow exploration and gradual build up of threat and player power level from that game, and there are a lot of things that feel... slightly off compared to that game. No counter moves - they REALLY want you to use the new dodge instead, with boss fights that blatantly expect you to have practiced it. No sub-weapons - your grenades, flashes and now-unbreakable knife are equipped like guns instead. Locations, characters and enemies from RE2R show up willy-nilly and vanish again just as quickly, seemingly as a truly bizarre example of nostalgia baiting for a game that was then only a year old.

It's almost like the uncanny valley version of RE2R - or, more likely, it was just faster, easier and cheaper to recycle a bunch of assets from a previous game to push out a new one. People say this game feels like it should have been DLC, and they're not wrong at all tbh. Slightly ironic - the OG RE3 was originally just going to be a spin-off with a different feel and gameplay loop to RE1 and RE2, but it ended up becoming part of the main series. The remake was always supposed to be part of the "new" canon and was designed to be similar to a previous game, but ended up feeling like a spin-off. Whacky.

Anyway it's fun, buy it on sale, you can beat the campaign in 6 hours on standard and even if you want to 100% achievements it won't take you super long, which is both a plus and a minus. Either way it takes its place as part of the wild and wonderful ongoing story of Resident Evil and the series' ups and downs.

While I enjoyed the game I can completely understand why some of the people who bought it at release felt ripped off. Compared to the Resident Evil 2 Remake, this game features much less content. 

It lacks alternative campaigns and game modes (challenges). One location has been carbon copied directly from the previous installment. There’s fewer guns, and equipment (e.g. blue herbs disappeared). Hardly any puzzles are featured; the ones that do appear are very trivial. There’s also a number of cinematics with QTEs which I didn’t like. 

The player character (Jill) strongly resembles the “Mary Sue” type of character—she survives impossible encounters without a scratch. Her personality is unlikable. She was better portrayed in the original Resident Evil. 

Notwithstanding the negative aspects of the game, I still recommend it because the gameplay and production values are solid; however, you should only buy it at a heavy discount, otherwise you won’t get your money’s worth.

Like the original, Resident Evil 3 Remake is more of an action game with horror elements than the other way around.
The pace is fast and you rarely have time to catch your breath. It also doesn't take long before you can fight back properly.
Despite the emphasis on action, the classic Resident Evil feel remains, thanks in part to your limited inventory and an emphasis on finding the right key items. In contrast to other action-packed parts such as Resident Evil 5 and 6, the balance is razor-sharp and there is still enough left to shudder. Think, for example, of a section full of spiders that shove their eggs down your throat in a nasty way.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4LH09yYq8X8

The game does not let you go through all these moments. Although the campaign lasts between 4 and 7 hours, you will not be bored for a single second, because there is always variation in terms of environments, weapons and monsters that you will have to battle.
One monster that yours truly has stuck with is the Hunter Gamma.
It is a real monster that resembles a hybrid of a shark and a frog and walks on two legs. These beasts will bring the sweat to your brow.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kxX0gEKPFGE

In addition to the Hunter Gammas, there are many more types of monsters that all give you nightmares. Fortunately, this game plays just as smoothly in terms of controls as the Resident Evil 2 remake.
Shooting feels nice and there are enough upgrades and new weapons in the world to make you feel a bit safer. Until you encounter the Nemesis again who killed yours truly within five seconds after the second encounter, because unlike Mr.X, that beast can run!

First of all this is one of the greatest preformed games i've ever played on this PC. With a 5700 xt graphics card and with ryzen 5 processor this runs at a smooth 144 fps in 1440p with some graphics tweaked, that still let the game have some of the best graphics ive seen in a while. Weapon and character handling is so smooth once you get used to the mechanics, so if you are into that stuff i highly highly recommend.

Gameplay and storywise: you play as Jill, getting chased by a mutant called ¨Nemesis¨, orderd to hunt down all of the S.T.A.R.S. members, a special task unit in Raccoon Police Unit. You need to survive in order to escape the city, and along the way you meet Carlos which you ocasionally switch over to. They have different weapons and dodge mechanics so some varations of characters are also involved here.

Nemesis is absolutley terrifying the first playthroughs you play this game. You can't really kill him and he has alot of HP, so running and dodgeing his very stressful attacks is something you gonna have to do. It is keeping you on edge, and it takes awhile to master to dodge his attacks, the higher difficulty you play.

It is a very short game after a few tries which is why i like the ¨speedrun¨ aspect to it aswell, with your run being timed and you get a grade for how fast you went. But that is definetly nothing important and first playthrough should always be enjoyed with no stress, cause in the end, Resident Evil games are best when it's about figuring out puzzles or how to kill an enemy.

With that in mind, while RE3 is great anyways, one critical thought is that is can feel a little... too ¨actiony¨ in this one that doesnt make it necessarily the ¨best¨ RE game of them all. Everythings very linear and straight forward once you get to know it all.

Regardless, RE3 gets a strong 7/10 from me.

Resident Evil 3 Remake. 

The original Resident Evil 3 on the PlayStation 1 was an amazing game and follow up to the original Resident Evil 2. Now as a remake it gives new spectacular graphics, visual effects and even little bit improves on the already good game engine of Resident Evil 2 which all bring the game's characters alive and offers a good game play experience as you play Jill Valentine in escaping the infested and doomed Raccoon City. The environments look very realistic and the atmosphere is one of death and decay. Staying alive and shooting your way through every single zombie and other mutant is more action packed this time with much more ammo available and with the ability to perform cool and effective dodge moves when compared to the Resident Evil 2 remake. Jill is strong as ever and well acted in this epic escape from the dead city. Other characters, including the enemies, are also well done and it's cool to see them appear in new, modern graphics and engine. 

The Nemesis is menacing but could be much more and when compared to the original Resident Evil 3 Nemesis this remake one is also deadly but appears less frequently and is not so scary and terrifying as the original. Gone are some whole areas from the original game and here this is one of the biggest drawbacks and minuses of this remake. Resident Evil 2 remake tried and succeeded to be very faithful in remaking the original in terms of areas, characters and story. To some degree it is true with Resident Evil 3 remake also, but it heavily lacks in terms of game environment length department. The city streets part is made much, much more shorter, the clock tower part is completely missing (though appearing only when when fighting Nemesis in one of his boss forms in front of it). Also Jill does not explore the Raccoon City Police Station at all. You do go there as Carlos, which is cool, but they could have made this part and other missing parts as in the original and we could have had a much longer and stronger game. The Mercenaries mini game is missing too and it's inclusion could have given an added boost for the game's overall replay value. 

Still the Resident Evil Remake 3 as it is gives the series fans and new players a good, albeit short, experience of Jill's last escape and upon completion it's good ending is satisfying. One can play the game through with the multiple difficulty levels which give an added challenge and increase it's replay value to some degree. The Resident Evil Resistance, which is a standalone game, but comes included and FREE when purchasing RE 3 Remake, is an interesting concept in itself that gives some additional good game play but again could have been done much, much better by having a longer single player section. It had the potential for being an excellent single player campaign with more story and AI driven allies for busting through the undead challenges together but for some reason it was left too much as a multiplayer focused game which seems to not have a lot of online players anymore. If you can find someone to play it with then some added fun is there.

Over and all I recommend this game for it's take on the story and for it's engine, visuals and game play. This game has it's minuses unfortunately by being short but what good it has with that one can still be happy. Best to buy it when it's on sale.

[b] Setting & Writing: [/b]
Resident Evil 3: Remake puts you in the shoes of Jill Valentine coming off the events of Resident Evil 1’s Spencer Mansion incident. Jill is determined to bring to light the events of the incident. Theres one issue though, her home of Raccoon City is in the process of being overrun by the T-Virus. Jills objective to escape the city in three days. Her plans get upended when she starts to get hunted by a bioweapon sent to kill the remaining members of the Spencer mansion incident. Throughout the game Jill tries to escape the city with the unlikely allies of the Umbrella Bioweapon Countermeasure Service (UBCS). The journey ends up divulging ulterior motives within the unit that make escaping the city that much more difficult. Jill Valentine’s only friend in the chaos is Carlos Oliveira who shares the same pure hearted goal of saving civilians and finding a cure to the T-virus before Umbrella Pharmaceuticals pull the unthinkable upon Raccoon City.

[b] Gameplay system & Bosses: [/b]
RE3: Remake takes the same gameplay approach as RE2: Remake with the updated 3rd person over the shoulder view. The inventory system and how it works is all similar as well. What’s new in this iteration is the inclusion of a dodge button. And boy will you become friends with this button. A well-timed dodge rewards you with a perfect dodge that gives Jill I-frames and a slight speed boost to continue to get out of dodge. Perfecting the timing of this mechanic is key to speed runners and saves your life. This dodge is also important because this version of Resident Evil leans more into the action aspect of things. Because of this more zombies and other enemies are thrown at you in mass. This makes using the dodge button more pertinent. The lean into action was mostly felt during the boss fights of this game. They’re huge set pieces that feel fun and exhilarating. My issue with them was that they lingered to long. Yes, my nerves were shaking a bit when I had to figure out how to down the boss. But when I found out it felt to long taking me out of the atmosphere of horror that Resident Evil tries to build

[b] Quest, Mini-games & Challenges: [/b] 
RE3: Remake is mostly a linear game with some instances of backtracking. The puzzles in this iteration seem light compared to its predecessor. There are no minigames that accompany the game outside of collecting in game bobbleheads. Challenges come in the form of completing the game and completing challenges within subsequent runs. Completing challenges award you with currency that allows you to purchase upgrades to make the next run easier. 

[b] Miscellaneous (art, music, etc.): [/b]
The game shines here via the magic that is the RE: Engine. This game engine is the backbone of Capcom’s renaissance. Everything here looks beautiful. I’m a big fan on how they redesigned Jill Valentine and would love seeing this version of her going forward. Something that I miss is the sound of silence. RE2: Remake did a good job of making you feel alone within the police station. This uneasiness created a haunted atmosphere that made it frightening to move forward at times. That felt missing in this game because the scares happened more often through cutscenes than it did standard gameplay.

It's much shorter than its predecessor and tries really hard to mirror its success. Not much has changed in terms of gameplay, and the story does have some good cinematic moments but it does go by faster than I'd like. I like Jill as a protagonist but the real star of this game is Nemesis, even if it's very predictable as a stalker type of enemy. So I enjoyed it, it's good but not great.

Resident Evil 3 is an exciting remake of the 1999 classic. Players step into the shoes of Jill Valentine, trying to survive a zombie-infested Raccoon City. The graphics are impressive, and the gameplay is a mix of action and survival horror. The story is engaging, featuring the relentless Nemesis as the primary antagonist. While it may be slightly shorter and lacking in branching paths, it still offers thrilling replayability. Overall, it's a worthy addition to the Resident Evil series.

It's obvious the producers of this game take a lot of pride in their work and the details, story telling, and engaging action make you feel like you're part of a different universe.  My only complain is that their is entirely too much breakout up the action when the game has to narrate everything for you.  Carlos and Jill's constant radio conversation interruptions, video sequences that keep breaking in and out of quick-time events and chases, and the lack creative ways of giving you a choice to discover the story for yourself were missing.  Also, I imagine a censorship decision to tone down the gore for the general audience, I miss the head popping and dismemberment of limbs when shooting at a Zombie. RE3 felt like I was shooting moving bags of potatoes. 

Those these complaints mind sound severe, they don't detract too much from the overall attention to detail and dark atmospheric immersion that we are all well accustomed to in a Resident Evil title.

Resident Evil 3 (2020) is a remake of the original Resident Evil 3 (1999) and follows on the success of the Resident Evil 2 remake. Take the role of Jill Valentine, a member of the S.T.A.R.S. police unit whose life is abruptly turned upside down by the zombie outbreak in Raccoon City. There's something else that makes Jill's situation even worse though: a menacing creature popularly known as the Nemesis, whose sole purpose is to kill all remaining S.T.A.R.S. members at whatever cost. Jill will not only have to make her way through Raccoon City in an effort to find a way to synthesize a cure for the outbreak, but also to find a way to stop the Nemesis before it takes her out.

Compared to RE2's emphasis on survival horror, RE3 makes a bigger emphasis on action horror. I would most closely compare RE3's story and action to that of the original Terminator movie. While there's bits and pieces of horror sprinkled throughout, there's more focus on the unstoppable force hunting down our protagonist. Jill's ammo and resources aren't nearly as limited as Leon/Claire's were in RE2, meaning you have more opportunity to lay waste to any zombies in your path. You'll definitely need to though, because the zombies are just as resilient as before, but now there's some new types that may throw you for a loop. Frequent boss fights with the Nemesis will dump loads of ammo on you, but you'll need it because the Nemesis hits hard and hits *fast*, especially compared to RE2's Mr. X. It is intense, it is exciting, there's explosions and tension and a little bit of horror and it is a wild ride.

RE3 in my opinion isn't as fantastic of a game as RE2. Don't get me wrong, it's a stellar remake and once again a fantastic product from Capcom and the RE Engine, but there are some areas where it falls short. Speaking of, the game itself is really short. My hours at the time of this review consists of not one but *two* full playthroughs of the game, plus extra time spent exploring and modding the game for my second playthrough. It's about 40-50% shorter than RE2, which definitely caught me off-guard when I first finished RE3. RE3 is also pretty cheesy at times. The focus on action horror means you get a lot of moments where the action feels so over-the-top that it borders on the side of ridiculous. The secondary antagonist Nikolai is also pretty corny, especially in his voice-line delivery (I can't tell if it's a bad attempt at a Slavic accent or if the voice actor genuinely just sounds like that). The cheesiness of this game isn't necessarily all bad though, I think it definitely emphasizes the fact that this is an action horror game and makes it fit that 80s action movie stereotype better.

Overall, I'd definitely recommend checking out RE3. If you're coming from the RE2 remake, I'd lower your expectations a little bit, but it is still a very fun game that I would recommend picking up in the Raccoon City bundle on sale if you can.

This game is undoubtedly very good in most horror games, but the problem is that it is a remastered version of Resident Evil 3. Compared to this year's RE4 and the 2019 RE2, this RE3 has obvious traces of shoddy production (I have not played the original version, so I will only compare it with the remade version)
1. Bullets
Capcom, are you having a mental problem? In the auxiliary mode of RE2, the number of bullets does not increase. When I synthesized bullets for the first time in this game, I was shocked. Can two gunpowder composite 30 submachinegun bullets? I think this makes RE3 completely a shooting game, and you don't have to worry about bullets like in RE2, which greatly reduces the sense of horror.
2. Zombies
I can understand the reason for using the same model as in RE2, but I am very angry about not being able to break limbs. If you don't break the limbs of a zombie, you will waste bullets hitting the head and have to use a dagger to "autopsy", which makes the game immediately troublesome. Similarly, this also makes the game more like a shooting game.
3. Nemesis T Type
I am not satisfied with Nemesis' performance. He only appears in fixed locations, and his sense of oppression is far less than the T-103 in RE2 (when I am playing RE2, I have to reason to guess which room T-103 is in). Of course, I am quite satisfied with the production team's modeling of his three stages, especially the third stage, which has a stronger sense of authority than G5.
4. Scenarios
  Rough and shoddy production. The original scene is only the hospital. The streets and police stations of Raccoon City were all directly captured from RE2, and the underground facilities of the hospital were filled with traces of the mother's nest. To cover up this fact, the underground facilities were also named Mother's Nest No. 2. Production team, you're really "smart".
  Overall, this game is a bit of a mess, and I suggest everyone buy it during the big sale like me. This way we won't lose money.

Unfortunately, this remake is inferior to the 1999 original. I played both. Problem is that this remake is lacking much content. The original had a much bigger city map, it felt like a real city you are exploring. However, the city in this remake is just a small part. They omitted many areas from the orignal, they also omitted a weapon (freeze grenades). Also, the original had much higher replay value (only in the original, different events happen when you play the game again). Corporate greed from Capcom to cut costs. It's a shame, because what is in this remake is good for the most part, but with more content it could have been a much better game. So much wasted potential. Instead of using the strengths of RE3, they recycle enemies from RE4. At some point, Capcom realized the content was not enough, so they added a low-quality multiplayer mode. Capcom was lazy, just a lack of effort.

This game should have been a home run but instead was rushed out by Capcom CEOs to capitalise on RE2's success and bundled with a DOA live service to justify a $60 price tag.

RE3 is about 60% of the original game, missing out many key locations, it has a single puzzle that a toddler could figure out, the zombies are lower quality than the ones in RE2 (dismembered body parts and dead bodies just disappear), no RNG making repeat playthrough boring (unlike the original) and replacing semi-open world sections with an extremely linear and set piece heavy experience. 

There's a lot of cut content and most tellingly of all cutscenes count towards the completion timer (unlike in RE2), if you skip all the cutscenes on your first play through you won't get more than 5 hours playtime and there's only one campaign.

Frustratingly the VA, motion capture and cutscenes are all high quality, easily comparable to RE2 but the gameplay, downgrades, short play time and cut content massively let it down. RE3 in this state should have been DLC for RE2 and priced accordingly. If it's on heavy sale it might be worth picking up but don't pay more than $15 for it, it's a cheap cash-grab at full price.

Resident Evil 3 is a thrilling and intense re-imagining of the classic survival horror game that successfully brings the terror to modern PC gaming. Developed by Capcom, this remake builds upon the legacy of the original Resident Evil 3: Nemesis while adding new elements to keep players on the edge of their seats.

One of the standout features of Resident Evil 3 Remake is its stunning graphics and attention to detail. The game's environments, characters, and creatures are beautifully rendered, immersing players in a post-apocalyptic Raccoon City. The dark and atmospheric setting perfectly complements the tense and terrifying game-play, creating an unforgettable horror experience. 

The game-play itself is fast-paced and action-packed, with a focus on survival and resource management. As protagonist Jill Valentine, players must navigate through the city while evading or battling hordes of monstrous creatures. The controls are smooth and responsive, allowing for precise aiming and quick reactions during intense combat scenarios. The addition of dodge mechanics adds an extra layer of strategy, making each encounter feel challenging and rewarding.

The story-line in Resident Evil 3 Remake is engaging and well-executed, effectively conveying the desperation and chaos of the outbreak. Jill's character development is particularly notable, as her determination and resilience are showcased throughout the game. However, some fans of the original may feel that certain story elements have been streamlined or omitted, which could be seen as a missed opportunity. 

Another highlight of the game is the inclusion of the asymmetrical multiplayer mode, Resident Evil Resistance. This mode pits a group of survivors against a player-controlled Mastermind, who sets traps, spawns enemies, and tries to eliminate the survivors. While it adds replay-ability and a fresh multiplayer experience, it may not be as captivating as the main campaign for some players. 

One minor drawback of Resident Evil 3 Remake is its relatively short length. The game can be completed in around six to eight hours, which may leave some players craving for more. However, the intense and action-packed nature of the game-play compensates for this to some extent.

In conclusion, Resident Evil 3 Remake is a must-play for fans of the survival horror genre and the Resident Evil franchise. Its stunning graphics, intense game-play, and engaging story-line successfully capture the essence of the original game while introducing modern enhancements. Despite its shorter length and some streamlined story elements, this remake delivers a terrifying and thrilling experience that will keep players hooked from start to finish.

Although heavily criticized by the series fanbase, RE3R is not a bad game, but it's not a good remake either. While the previous remakes changed some things here and there, they still remained faithful enough to the original games. That's not the case here, almost everything has changed. In fact, the only thing connecting this game to the original RE3 is the same "cast", the characters. Speaking of which, the removal of the mercenaries mode was a big mistake, not to mention the player's decisions during cutscenes and the unlockable outfits - at least mods can fix that. Despite its flaws, the game is still enjoyable but could have been much better.

Resident Evil 2 quickly became one of the best games I had played in years, and re3 did not disappoint as well. I appreciated that the story took a more systemic approach to analyzing the current conditions of Raccoon City. Even though the story was shorter than re 2 I appreciated its take on how individualized human greed destabilizes the integrity of institutions. Carlos and Jill are both fun characters and in a way feel a little more mature than Claire and Leon in re2 (though I love them both). However I will say that there is considerably less content than in re2 and while the reuse of multiple locations was really satisfying from a narrative perspective it contributed to this feeling of re3 being a DLC to re2. That being said the game was much better making these narrative choices it made me feel more invested in Jill and Carlos to see how they paved the way for Leon and Claire in re2. For the reason I recommend the be played in conjunction with re2 and should consider buying it on sale. All in all id give this a 8/10 but i highly recommend it if you like resident evil, horror games, or played re2.

Aside from the obvious complaint that everybody has (the fact that the game is quite short), I have something else to add. I noticed how enemies in this game seem to lack any audible footsteps, especially Nemesis. You would expect something as big and heavy as him, like Mr. X, to make a loud thudding when walking but he was as quite as a mouse; during chase scenes, I was caught off guard as he punched me. Thinking I had put a considerable amount of distance between us, no audio cues (in this case footsteps) could tell me he was right behind me. As for the argument of "Just turn the camera around", it's inconvenient when you have to look where you're going while being chased.
As I haven't finished the original game, I have no way of comparing the two. Aside from that, this was an enjoyable game with, not surprisingly, replayability to squeeze more hours out of the money you spent.

This is an excellent remake of the classic RE3. This one is kind of shorter than RE2 but I think it's harder in certain ways, like in terms of action certain parts are more difficult than RE2, but the puzzles in RE2 are more difficult the first time around. This one didn't have as many puzzles, but seemed to be more action oriented. I was happy to play as my favourite character Jill, so that lets me give the game a higher rating.

Overall I'd give this game a 9/10, it's not quite the masterpiece RE2 was, but it's still a top-notch quality title from Capcom. I don't regret buying this at all, I loved the game enough to buy all the DLC as well (I got the DLC and game on sale). I hope Capcom is working on a Code Veronica Remake, as that takes place after RE3 and we'd get to see what happens between 3 and 4. Also I hope they to do a RE1 remake in the same vein as these remakes, the RE1 Remaster of the GC Remake is great but I think it'd be cool to see the original setting in this style.

Friends, gamers, but most especially...Capcom--

Why...does this game exist, I ask myself and you? For whom was it made? I've never had such an existential response to a triple-A title. I came-up with an answer but, read-on.

Was this like, Capcom testing out the new theatrical stuff for the RE-4-remake? Was it made by another, smaller team than the RE-2 remake? I don't know but, fun fact: this reviewer once predicted RE-4 would not get remade/remastered because it did not need one (it definitely deserved one) but hey, I love being wrong in the right way. Let's get after it. RE-3...time.

Did you know...the original Resident Evil 3...doesn't technically exist? I mean, uh, the original is *actually* called...RE3: Nemesis. This is not a remake/remaster, it's literally a 'retell' of that game's main plot and that is all it is. 

It does have the new RE engine obviously but, as far as 'new content,' there is none. But, I still enjoyed it enough to cheese tf outta nemesis and that dude really needed to get offed. TL;DR--buy it on sale for no more than 20$ but, only if you are one of the three types of individuals I came up with below the dashes because I DO NOT KNOW WHO THIS GAME IS FOR, STEAM-PEOPLE.

This will be my softest recommendation of...any game I've ever played on P.C., and, any Resident Evil game, somehow. So, before I review it quickly, this game is for...three types of people.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Type 1: you played the Resident Evil 2 Remake recently. This is effectively DLC for it and while the reused-assets aren't too on the nose, there is enough here to justify...a *10-20$* price-tag.

Type 2: you are either a long-time fan of the series*or*, like some, Resident Evil puzzles are not your jam and you want a stream-lined experience. I think some gamers might enjoy this game solely because: it's easy af, the gun-play is as tight as RE-village, and, it's not a horror-game. This game did not have any *actual* puzzles either, in my opinion...nothing optional or nearly as difficult as those spherical maze puzzles in RE-Village and as far as back-tracking, only two areas of the game actually have back-tracking also--the rest is linear. In that way though, I was able to beat this game in 2 sittings so, it's not worth full MSRP.

Type 3: *You want to play on the hardest difficulty right out the gate (you should, it's hard af)*. This one's me. I started on standard and found it insultingly easy. I got bit by zombies *five times* in a row and my health didn't even go to danger, just 'caution.' Then, I switched to HxC mode and boy, was it worth dying 40 times in one play-through. Here's a quick review of pros/cons but again, if you're not one of these people, this game is likely not for you. It's barely for me and I'm the one reviewing it!
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

If you are one of these people, read on but if not, honestly, play RE-2's remake first and if you need more content after the...other main story-character there, this one's got two more characters. 

Pros:
-Fantastic Gunplay
-Satisfying movement--the game has a perfect-dodge aspect that's entirely necessary on higher difficulties because when pulled off, time slows down and you lock on to an enemy's dome with whatever weapon you have out. Very bullet-time-y.
-Focused story/gorgeous graphics/the best looking character models in the RE series before the RE-4 remake
-Not a single frame-dropped, no glitches...and I'm running ultra-settings on a 240+hz monitor. 

Cons:
-Cut content: in re3-nemesis, for example, there used to be this feature where you could choose between two outcomes at multiple points in the story, frequently. This game has no choices except 'how hard' you want to play it at. Side note: if you play on HxC+, ffs, be sure to get the extended-mag for the glock...I literally only beat this game because I had...two glocks.
-HxC BS: at one point on Hardcore mode, I realized I was lacking the extended mag for the glock which made it impossible to progress. Usually on harder difficulties, while one needs all the weapons uh, let's just say I was not happy that Nemesis actually carries a gun-upgrade and you have to either throw a grenade or waste a ton of ammo to get it. 

-It's short, almost the shortest in the series/it is the shortest modern RE game. While I have 12 hours on record, according to the game, I beat it in a little over 10 hours/I did waste time re-doing the part to get the glock-mag/switched from standard to hardcore but, that's literally...a few days of very minimal gaming. Not worth $40.

Ultimately, if you think of this game as a DLC to RE-2, it is worth recommending to fans and only a specific few who are not.

Of all types of people I think would like this game that I list--honestly, it's people who dislike RE's heavy focus on back-tracking, puzzles, and horror. This is an action game and super linear: the hardest part for me was deciding what gun I was gonna kill Nemesis with. Yes, it was the glock.

I am writing this as someone relatively new to the series, since the only game and lore I experienced was the RE 2 Remake.

Generally, I do appreciate the resident evil formula so it was not hard to like the game. But, compared to RE2R it definitely has flaws.

Nemesis: Considering I never play this genre, Mr. X from RE2R gave a terrifying and uncomfortable presence. Combined with the general quiteness, loud foodsteps from him and his slow methodical walk, it was well done. The counterpart for him in RE3 is insanely luckluster. His appearence is painfully scripted and tbh, considering scripted events like those are not in your control, it makes you feel safe instantly. He does have way more abilities than Mr. X, but they are used in such an awful way, it is disappointing.

Gameplay: The way you move, shoot, loot etc. is similar to RE2R, but with a few additions. Both characters have their unique dodge/parry ability, which I appreciate. They do feel clunky at times (especially Carlos), but maybe it is something that can come with practice. The bigger problem however is how the gameplay is structured. They are many, many scripted sequences where you either don't do anything, or just hold one button. It reminds me of those ridiculous CoD campaigns with their insane (in a bad way) action sequences where you also don't do anything. Boring is a nice way to describe it. Also the game is way more linear compared to its prequel. 

Story: Story-wise I obviously don't want to spoil. It is just rather unsatisfying to say the least.

Overall, if you liked RE2R, you probably will still enjoy RE3 probably. Similar mechanics, just worsely packaged.

[h1] Review[/h1] 
The original RE3 was great. I really liked it. It was more linear than 1 and 2 but I felt much more dread due to the nemesis being able to appear on a lot of places I didn’t expect and also was able to follow you through doors. It shattered my expectation of the game. Boss fights were mechanically more interesting although the aiming and dodge system were rather broken. I was hyped up for this one as it seemed a game that could be way much better with a remake unlike RE2 which was already really good.

[u]Gameplay[/u]
There is solely two changes in the combat. Defence items got removed, meaning your knife is now unbreakable thus you have to carry it all the time in a no item box run, and the dodge move from RE3 original is back. This time it works very well and considering how the nemesis moves a welcome addition. Although one that makes the game a bit too easy. Combat is much more action focused as is the whole game. It reminds me more of RE6 which I unironically liked. But is that really the route they want to go again?

There are more difficulties aside veteran, two more you unlock but those tend to also be easy due to the possibility to buy an infinite AR in the points shop after a playthrough or two. You get points for doing challenges.

I must say that I enjoyed the main campaign a lot even though it definitely lacked in a lot of content in areas and became quickly more and more linear. The first area is great where you probably spend an hour or so. After that I was surprised what kind of content they added. Some throwback to RE2 and some scenes where you play as Carlos and run and gun with an assault rifle.

The main focus is the nemesis but he is an overall less scary version of the one from the original. He’s very predictable here and later on its more just running away from him in a corridor. Its still fun and impressive but the game has such an incredible start gameplay wise. Spectacle wise it stays strong until the end of the game, especially the last boss fight was visually great.

Now the elephant in the room. It lacks content. A lot of it. The first hour is quite faithful while adding a lot of content. After the train ride it’s the opposite. A lot of scenes are scrapped, including the hydrogen plant(replaced by underground lab) clocktower, cemetery etc. My first playthrough took me just over 4-5 hours, the second less than 2. My fastest time was around 1 hour and 25 minutes and I’m not a speedrunner. It’s a really short game. A single run in RE2 will take you longer not to mention the Claire/Leon A and B route. Barely any puzzles and not much new. At least you don’t have that awful acid shower battle in the game anymore!

[u]Story[/u]
You start off a section as Jill where you get glimpses of her life and what she is up to due to Umbrellas workings. Until you’re suddenly amidst the Zombie outbreak and the Nemesis chases you in a very cool although heavily scripted sequence.

[u]Sound[/u]
I really like the new ost, it’s a more complex version of some tracks of the original. Although I prefer the raw dread the original nemesis theme presented. Again, game is available in a lot of voiced languages! Always like this commitment.

[u]Graphics[/u]
Not much changed from RE2 although the texture models of the characters are much better! There are also a lot more visually interesting places especially the chaos from the outbreak in the start of the game.

[u]Conclusion/TL;DR[/u]
I really enjoyed my short playthrough of this game. But considering it as a remake it doesn’t add enough to justify the content they cut. Especially since places like the clocktower museum which was my favourite are missing! Unlike RE2 remake it doesn’t stay that faithful while adding more content but rather just does this in the first half of the game. After that it gets much more linear and solely became a rather fun action focused game. Could have expanded and improved the content RE3 had and it would have made my favourite RE title. Still worth looking into as the game is still an enjoyable rollercoaster ride.

I never thought I would make up my mind about a game in such a short time. I just beat PS1 RE3 a day ago, it didn't have quite the impact that PS1 RE1 and 2 did for me but it was still very enjoyable.

I'm the guy who pretty much enjoys every RE I've gotten my hands on; 0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8, Code Veronica X, Revelations 1 and 2, REmake2. (I haven't beat REmake1 yet)

But this....? Especially after beating REmake2 a couple weeks ago and PS1 RE3 a day prior? Oh man. Immediately after seeing uptown and Nemesis' arrival as a 5 minute tutorial sequence, when it's a whole journey's worth of exploration and solving in the original then suddenly I'm at the "tram" which is much further in the original, I knew it was going to be very watered down. I understand a remake doesn't need to be a 1:1 from the original, it's best to change things to keep things fresh with unexpected surprises while maintaining some familiarity, REmake2 and REmake1 proves this to be very effective. In this game it's just "hey remember that [character or place] you spent a [considerable amount of time] with in the original? Well here you--- oh it's over now. NEXT TUTORIAL".

All of that could have been forgiven and I would have pressed on and probably still enjoyed it, but they screwed up the one thing they definitely shouldn't screw up: Jill. A shame because I immediately liked Carlos and Mikhail when they show up, but Jill was already rubbing me the wrong way before the subway but I couldn't figure out what it was. The second she interacted with the UBCS members on the subway I knew what it was and it was her personality. She's a sarcastic douchebag and not the kind that really makes the character interesting or fun to hate akin to Handsome Jack in Borderlands 2. I understand that in remakes characters can change but remain familiar too. Claire was given a more scared demeanor with some slight sarcasm because she's just a college kid with a revolver, but still handles herself because she's from a law enforcement family. Leon has the composure of a police officer but the way he carries himself shows he obviously still green because he just got out of the police academy. Jill is a highly trained former officer of a special police force with experience of the undead and she...... lacks situational assessment and skepticism towards UBCS team, no investigative or interrogation skills... Just out of the gate know-it-all confrontational girlboss that actually lacks the military+LEO bearing to back up her sense of authority. ALT+F4, no way I can handle this kind of character for several hours straight

RE3 Remake is a disappointing and often frustrating game. Great aspects exist, however, the abundant issues are supremely critical to the overall experience. Did the game designers just phone it in, hoping the glowing reception of RE2 Remake would carry it? Even when not comparing it to its predecessor, RE3 Remake is a loud meh of a standalone product. While I have not played the original game, I’ve heard this remake is unfaithful and scraps much of the original content. No matter how you look at it, RE3 Remake is a mixed standalone game, disappointing sequel, or an unfaithful remake.  

For starters, the lack of content is abhorrent. It feels like a DLC for RE2 Remake. The game is only 6 or 7 seven hours long at a leisurely pace. This wouldn't be an issue if replayability existed. At all. In RE3 Remake, there are no alternative characters to play as. In RE1 Remake and RE2 Remake, I started a second playthrough right away. The other character provided their own story to experience in a familiar, enjoyable world. (Plus, it is fulfilling to play again because I had some skill built up.) Here, there is nothing close to that. The game is a one n’ done. I’d say if you’re curious, it isn’t worth more than $10. Some poor sods purchased this for $60!

The level design is far too linear with disappointing pacing that favors action over horror and puzzles. Locations are reused or uninspired copies of earlier settings. The downtown starting area is fun to explore, but you cannot return to finish exploring it (that I found). I had 2 of the 3 jewels in my pocket to deposit in a clock but no way to use them because I activated a scripted Nemesis cutscene before finding the last one. How was I supposed to know it would force me to stop and never come back? This is just a single incident that exemplifies the numerous scripted encounters that are no more than cutscenes that provide the illusion of playing a game via instruction of moving the joystick or hitting a button. (Those mechanics are good in other games but not something that works here.)

The sewers and laboratory environments are retreads of areas in the RE2 Remake, which wouldn’t be too much of an issue if they were well designed, though both are blander and without much in the way of puzzles or innovation. The hospital is scary and intense–easily the strongest part of the game. However, the A.I. of the Hunters can be bad at times. They never leave their spawn points, even returning to their assigned room after chasing you for more than a few seconds. This is made funnier when all these genetic monsters created solely to kill have just left Tyrell alone in the hospital lobby to chill on a computer.

The Nemesis battles start off as fun but soon become grindfests of smashing the fire and dodge buttons. After the first few, I audibly groaned when he’d pop up for another spout of failed revenge. There is no fun factor or innovation that builds upon the last encounter. Unlike RE2 Remake which lets you search environments after defeating the boss to pick up items you may not have collected, RE3 Remake forces you into yet another cutscene right away ultimately losing valuable resources. The final boss battle is the most lazy, embarrassing I've ever played (even more so than The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild). Uninspired and frustrating are understatements.

Jill seems like a different character than RE1 Remake. She was my favorite character but not so much here. Before, Jill was tempered, intelligent, and nice but tough enough to survive the horror she endured through perseverance. Through it all, she had a warmth about her. But here, she has become yet another generic, sarcastic badass. I can’t help but feel like I’m playing as 2013 Lara Croft. What else am I supposed to think upon seeing a blue sleeveless top, the boots, and all those utility and gun belts running through fiery buildings and squeezing through confined areas? Give her a ponytail and she’d look identical to Lara from the back. (Her appearance is a me complaint but not a strike against the game in the same way her personality change is.)

Jill falling off of buildings and standing next to explosions come off as mild inconveniences. Nemesis grabbing her neck for the tenth time might give her a migraine at best. Yes, many games I’ve played and enjoyed have characters with unnatural physical prowess. If video game protagonists were like our real-life fleshy bodies, there wouldn’t be a game as they’d outright die in the first scene. With that being said, RE3 Remake does go too far when considering the genre. A survival game needs more grounded action that reflects the consequences of bodily harm and mental trauma. A horror game loses menace when the protagonist survives every horrific encounter via a cutscene. Nemesis becomes an incompetent Saturday morning cartoon villain who fails at his one job over and over again.      

There are some annoying story cliches too. Jill has a couple nightmare fakeout scare scenes. If they’re suggesting she has PTSD from her experience at the Spencer Mansion in RE1, that’s a poor, underdeveloped way to express it. There is unexplored potential but action gotta be happening. The ending also involves the “I can’t shoot the bad guy because I might hit the good guy” gag.

In conclusion, RE3 Remake is devoid of content and challenges that don’t involve smashing the fire button. The exploration and intrigue are put second to straightforward boss fights that become tiresome quickly. While there is some of the greatness of RE2 Remake, RE3 Remake does not capture the same atmosphere or level of thrills. Not an utterly bad game, just one that is not good enough.

So I'm fairly certain I'm getting near the end of my run (was going to wait till I finished to review, but it crashed lol) and I think I can already say, it's not [i]that[/i] bad. Don't get me wrong, if I had bought this for 60 bucks or even 40 bucks I'd be [b]pissed[/b] but for the 10 bucks I got it for it's a decent enough expansion of re2. I mean assuming I finish in about 5 hours for my first ever run (hardcore and doing my best to fully explore) that's a decent length, and much like re2 which can also be beaten really fast you're meant to play it multiple times, or in other words it's like buying claire run A for 10. Some quick lil notes of some of my thoughts:

There are some noticeable graphical and sound improvements in this game, feel like the pistol in particular sounds a lot better here.

This is a very much more action based game with a far more linear path, which I'm not particularity miffed about but I wish they made it a bit more clear when you reach points of no return (I missed some stuff in the town for sure because I ran back to subway station :( )

The dodge mechanic takes a little getting use to but it's an overall welcome addition, I do wish secondary items didn't get nerfed and kept being a get out of jail free if you get grabbed. But hey, I guess part of the S.T.A.R.S training is forgetting that you can shove a flashbang in somebodies mouth. Oh, and almost as if bootyhurt about how much people liked it in re2 they fucking massacred the knife in this game...freaking useless.

I would have been totally fine if the paleheads from the ghost survivor mode in re2 just stayed in that mode ngl. I also really don't like the hunter gammas, a way worse version of the G adults (betas are cool tho).

Summary: If you're debating between this and re2, which are shockingly the same price, for the love of god get re2. If however you already have re2 and have 10 bucks to spare (do not get this at full price) I say go for it.

It's a great game. A bit more action oriented than RE2 and maybe not as polished, but it keeps the scary atmosphere true to RE and it has a great story. I wish it had more puzzles or more complex ones, and maybe a "Story B" like its predecessor; but it's still super fun to play. Great gameplay, nice controls, excellent graphics, superb sound, fun, challenging. If you liked RE2, then you'll definitively enjoy this one... even if you haven't play any other RE games, you'll like it.

So, first things first. Is RE3R good? Yes. Is RE3R fun? Also yes. As always with recent RE games, the acting and storytelling is brilliant and the gunplay feels great.

The main problem with RE3R (imo) is that this game in particular feels rushed; short story, lack of replayability and some of the game mechanics from RE2R released the year before - which are better than this game's respective mechanics - haven't been carried over which doesn't make much sense. Having never played the original RE3 I can't speak much about cut content, but it definitely feels like there should be more to it.
That lack of replayability is my main gripe, it's a "one and done" type of story that doesn't really have much variation to how the story can be approached.

But again, it is still a good game. Certainly not to the level of RE2R and RE4R, but for the first few playthroughs it is enjoyable. If you're on the fence with this one, wait for it to be on sale.

Although I did enjoy this game for the time I have played it, I have concluded that this Resident Evil 3 remake is not worth the price it is currently. Unlike this game's predecessor, Resident Evil 2 Remake, there is absolutely no other content factor to be experienced after completing the main game, due to the fact that the story is the only playable experience.

Starting off, I'd like to say that I do believe Capcom knows how to optimize a game without making it broken whilst maintaining the good graphics of the RE engine. I played this on a Steam Deck, and just like Village and RE2, the game still looked amazing. I was able to play at 1080p with most settings turned to medium, but later on went down to 720p for better framerate. So on that note, the game manages to be perfectly optimized and playable, while being graphically pleasing.

That being said, the way the levels are produced without a sense of backtracking makes the game feel way too linear compared to the games prior to RE3's release. The linearity is akin to that of a COD campaign with that one or two missions that make you go,"That was kinda cool!" and then proceed to stick to the same play style as you continue. The only things that do tend to stand out are the boss fights, which are actually pretty fun. However, they fail to replace to series's staple of puzzle solving (which is absolutely absent in this game, apart from a segment where you align a subway), and thrilling levels pertaining to each game. In RE2 Remake, you had the orphanage and Ada Wong segment; in Village, you had dollhouse. This game has so much potential to be a good, open-area type game. The material is there for a burning city that you have to navigate through in order to survive and escape. Unfortunately, the finished product seems to be rushed instead of managing to deliver a creative and intricate experience that makes want to play it again.

There is also the whole argument that the game also fails to stay true to the original RE3, however I did not play the original game, so it is not in my place to say. I would also like to add that you get this game in the Raccoon City Bundle ON SALE like I did if you don't currently own RE2 Remake. It feels more like a DLC than a standalone game, which felt fitting for being in a bundle.

Overall, you might be wondering why I've pulled an IGN and recommended this game. Well there's a cool Shrek mod for Nemesis.

Resident Evil 3 is the black sheep of the recent remakes. Not as beloved or groundbreaking as Resi 2 or 4 but apparently popular enough to warrant its own game. In my opinion it might have been better to have it as a DLC for 2 because it's really short. If I'm paying $40 for a game (thankfully I got this on sale bundled in with the second game) I expect more than ~5 hours of playtime. To be fair, though, it's a really great game. The shooting feels tight and it's always fun to kill zombies. It has that patented RE thing where you have to wait a second for your aim to steady. I actually really liked the story and thought it was well written and wasn't padded at all. The animation work is all top-notch and obviously the graphics have been completely overhauled. It's a very nice game, even playing on Steam Deck I noticed all the little details that make the world seem real. Speaking of the world, most of the "locations" are explorable areas filled with secrets and very very light puzzling. If you're coming to this after RE4 than I highly suggest starting with this over RE2 since it's more action focused and linear. I'd say my only complaint is the Nemesis who just becomes a big pain in the butt by the end. It's not scary, just really annoying. While there's a good amount of enemy variation, the only boss is just slightly different stages of the Nemesis. While it [i] is [/i] satisfying to finally kill him, I wish they'd toned it down a bit more. All in all it's a fantastic shooter whose length unfortunately requires a sale to justify buying it.

*Steam Deck note: As mentioned in the first note, I played this on a car trip (on my Steam Deck) and I'm happy to report that the game runs great on there. I was able to get roughly 3 hours of battery life with graphics on medium.. Adding in a portable power bank you've got a high quality shooter that looks and runs great (never had any stutters or framerate drops).

This game is AMAZING, but I feel like I need to point out a few good and bad stuff. To begin with, this game is very action-packed and you barely have enough time to catch your breath, which is something that I liked very much. The weapons feel better and stronger than Resident Evil 2 remake and the combat is more advanced, rewarding good skill. The game has a lot of boss-fights and you switch with Carlos for some time in the game where You really feel the adrenaline pumping. BUT, it took me only 4 hours  to finish this game and I really took my time with it. Also, the game really does NOT feel like Resident Evil at all. I barely solved 3 maybe 4 very easy puzzles and the game focused more on fighting than strategy and unlocking the map progressivelly ( only in the hospital and barely in RPD did we get these things). In addition, Nemesis is very stressful to face but he feels sooo programmed. For example: MR X ( RE2 Villain) would pop out out of nowhere and scare the shit out of you cutscene or not because he was unpredictable and NOT just programmed to be in a specific scene. Moreover, at one point Nemesis feels more of an annoyance because of the many times you face him. The game offers significantlly less replayability than RE2 and in general little replayability, since you dont have nothing new after you finish story ( except from 1 outfit and other powerups that you get from challenges, which can get boring). So, unfortunately, when compared to RE 2 it is a worse and way smaller game. In general, I think you should give this game a chance ( especially if its on discount) if you are OK with the  downsides of this game (since it offers a decent story/protagonists) and you enjoy fast paced games or RE games in general. I can assure you on thing tho: if the game did not lack so many content ( because the developers had to remove a lot of content from the game) it would have been way more appreciated than today ( yet still I admit that I love this game and definitely recommend it to new players)

Rating: ★★★★☆

Review:

As someone who played and finished the original game, I can say that the remake is a game where too much was cut out and it was rushed. Jill's dialogue is a bit soulless, and some of her facial animations are robotic. There seems to be a problem with the motion capture, but who knows?

There are unnecessary puzzles added to extend the game, and there are some unnecessary enemy additions to add challenge to the game. At the same time, since the game lacks horror elements other than atmospheric horror and the tension given by the nemesis, they used a few cheap jump scare tricks. 

The city modeling is well done, and it reflects the zombie apocalypse atmosphere really well. It's fun to feel that atmosphere while walking through the alleys. As in the original game, resource management is one of the things that makes this game good, and I think exploring and looting is a pleasure in this game.

I can say that the cutscenes are generally well done, and the action sequences are great. Especially the fight animation on the roof in the last scene was really good. Compared to the 2nd game, the particle effect and zombie deform physics are far behind. There may be many reasons for this, except that it was a rushed job.

The feeling of hitting is behind compared to the 2nd game, except for the modified version of Jill's basic weapon and the Desert Eagle-style weapon. I couldn't get the same feeling I got in the 2nd game with other weapons. Also, the M4 gun is extremely underpowered compared to the real thing. It's funny that you can take down a zombie with the M4 in 15 rounds, even if you shoot it in the head... (Note: I finished the game on Hardcore and Standard difficulty, so I don't know how it is on Easy).

If you are not loaded enough in the boss fight before the last boss fight of the game, you may have trouble. Usually, in Resident Evil level designs, boss areas have bullets and supplies, but there are not enough of them in this episode. If you don't play smart, you can die due to a lack of resources. You need to loot the environment well before entering this fight, and spending extra time for this is a bit annoying in the last stage of the game...

Overall, I liked the remake of Re3, an old cult game, even if it's not worth buying at full price the moment it comes out. It is a game that you can buy on sale and enjoy.

Jill Valentine, the skilled special operative from the Resident Evil series, and Travis Scott, the renowned rapper and songwriter, found themselves in an unexpected yet delightful situation. They were attending a charity event at a local park, where they were invited as special guests to entertain the crowd with their unique talents. As fate would have it, they were paired up for a surprise duet performance.

The stage was set, and the crowd was buzzing with anticipation. Jill and Travis stood side by side, exchanging friendly smiles. The music started playing, and they began singing a lively and energetic song together, their voices blending in perfect harmony. The audience erupted in cheers and applause as they delivered a dynamic and unforgettable performance.

After the song, Jill and Travis stepped down from the stage, their hearts racing with adrenaline and excitement. They shared a moment of camaraderie, realizing they had just created something special. As a token of their newfound friendship, they decided to take a break and find a quiet spot to relax and enjoy a well-deserved meal.

Jill led Travis to a cozy corner of the park where a picnic table was set up. On the table were two baskets filled with delicious sandwiches prepared by the event's organizers. The aroma of freshly baked bread and flavorful fillings wafted through the air, making their mouths water.

They sat down, and as they unwrapped their sandwiches, they continued to talk and laugh, swapping stories about their respective careers and adventures. Despite coming from different worlds, they found common ground and developed a genuine connection.

Between bites of their sandwiches, Jill and Travis couldn't resist humming the tune they had just performed on stage. Their impromptu singing turned into a full-blown jam session, with Jill providing a soulful melody while Travis added his unique rap style. Passersby couldn't help but stop and listen, captivated by their infectious energy and talent.

As the sun began to set, casting a warm golden glow over the park, Jill and Travis finished their sandwiches, feeling satiated and content. They sat back, admiring the beauty of the moment and reflecting on the magical experience they had shared.

With full stomachs and hearts filled with joy, Jill and Travis bid each other farewell, promising to keep in touch and perhaps collaborate again in the future. They left the park with a newfound appreciation for each other's talents and the power of music to bring people together.

And so, this unexpected encounter between Jill Valentine and Travis Scott became a cherished memory, a story they would fondly recall whenever they thought of that special day they sang and ate sandwiches in harmony.

Just gave this game another replay on PC and it holds up very well. The pacing of the campaign is phenomenal and continues the survival-horror gameplay revival from RE2 remake, especially the first act. Going through the Raccoon City streets, looting, managing inventory, and exploring was an absolute blast. This game was a bit harder than I remember, I had to think about what weapons I wanted to use and which enemies to kill or avoid. The graphics are also beautiful, there were many moments where I just had to sit and admire the scenery around me. It also helps that this game runs flawlessly on PC, just like the other recent RE titles.

Here's the problem, it's just extremely short. I forgot most of this game and still beat it with around 70% TOTAL completion in about 5 hours. That's not a lot these days, especially since this game isn't as original as when RE2 remake hit the scene in 2019. It uses a lot of assets from that game. There is a high level of replayability even compared to some of the other RE games, which is saying something because this series has always done replayability extremely well, but it doesn't change the fact that this is an extremely short adventure. I however won't discredit that the item shop, extra difficulties, challenges, and achievements are super fun to go through and do add value to this package.

I love this game and it means a lot to me personally, which I know doesn't account for everyone else, but I can definitely recommend this game anyway especially in the current day. While it's short, you will have a great time whether you're a veteran fan or a newcomer to the series for the price points it's going for these days. You can get this game bundled with RE2 remake for just 15 bucks and that's an absolute STEAL, especially considering I still had enough fun to pay $60 back when it was brand new. Definitely check it out if you enjoy scavenging, exploration, and rewarding survival gameplay. While it's the weakest game of what I consider the revival era of RE starting with 7, it's still better than a lot of games coming out today.

This is a controversial one. I think the largest complaint among fans are the differences between the original RE3: Nemesis and Remake. It's pointless listing all of them, but one of the posters on the Steam forums summarized it perfectly:

"Because it's basically a completely new game. It's vastly different than the original in almost every way.
People expect a remake to have more familiar locations and story of the original. Both RE2 remake and RE4 remake are a lot closer to the source material. In RE3 remake they took a ton of liberty and redesigned the entire thing completely for better or for worse."

The changes that I did like:[list]
[*]Chaos of the city being destroyed by the zombies is great, especially in the beginning.
[*]Storywise it's more focused, especially character development.
[*][spoiler]Brad dying a heroic death, instead of being killed by Nemesis, as if to make up for leaving Alpha Team to fend for themselves at the Spencer Mansion.[/spoiler]
[*]Jill is a bit too potty mouthed for my taste. She’s rude and snarky, but on the other hand, she every right to be, considering she mostly interacts with UBCS. At first I thought they ruined her character, but then I remembered that in the original she did slap Carlos at one point and was pretty hostile, though had a lot less dialogue to work with and didn’t swear. She does eventually warm up to Carlos, stops being snarky/sassy towards him, and seems to start liking him as a person. There is actual chemistry there, unlike in RE3: Nemesis. She’s also nice towards Brad and Kendo, people she knows and trusts.
[*]Some people complain about RE3R being more action oriented. The original was already very action oriented, especially for a fixed camera game. It had exploding barrels to kill groups of zombies for crying out loud.
[*]I’m actually shocked that people are defending RE3: Nemesis so much. I was always lukewarm towards it, being so action focused and padding out the run time by forcing you to backtrack through multiple long alleys in the first half of the game, and then the out of place Clock Tower section (which took 20-30 minutes to finish tops), pointless park, and awful Grave Digger fight. NEST 2 replaces the Dead Factory, which was essentially a lab anyway. It also reused assets like RPD. Nemesis was scripted as well, though admittedly he did appear more often. Live selection added minimum variety (it allowed you to discover an additional corridor with some items and that’s it), as did the random spawns each playthrough, increasing the replayability only a bit. For me it was entirely skippable, despite good ideas, Nemesis, and Jill.[/list]

My greatest disappointment with RE3R is that they failed to take a mediocre game with a good concept and elevate it into something truly great. They did redesign the entire thing, yet somehow were still too conservative, as if they were afraid that if they go too far, people will riot. Instead, they created a game that's only a bit less mediocre, and people hate it. For me it’s a tad better, more focused, and fun to play, but mostly forgettable. Buy it at a sale.

I'm new to the series, started playing about a month ago. Already binged games from 0 to 2 and I can definitely say I've had the least amount of fun with this entry. (I played on hardcore from the get-go so my experience might be different to anyone playing on a different difficulty setting.)

The enemies and their lay outs are tedious. While in almost every RE game resource management is a vital, and weirdly fun, part of the game where you get to decide what to spend where, I haven't really got that feeling in RE 3. The enemies were seemingly placed randomly without real care put into it (with few exceptions). Instead of giving me an obstacle which I should deliberate upon and consider my options in a span of a few moments, I was given a hindrance which only slowed my progress.

The levels were all very short. It isn't a problem in the late game as usually RE games tend to pick up the pace near the end. Still, I barely had any time to get accustomed to any areas of the game, making it feel like I was speedrunning through everything.

As for the famous Nemesis, I read a comment somewhere that read something along the lines of 'Mr.X in RE2 felt more like Nemesis than the actual Nemesis.' which is very true. In RE3 Remake, Nemesis, with the exception of his second appearance if I recall correctly, every time he appears it's a cutscene or a sequence. Because of that he never truly felt like a threatening entity that hunted Jill wherever she went, never posed much of a threat or fear.

I bought this in a bundle with RE2 pretty cheap so I don't really regret buying it. Would I recommend buying it however? No. Would I say to never buy this though? Not exactly either. I'd say that if you can get it for a really low price and you're a fan of the franchise. Sure, get it. I'd just say to not get your expectations too high as the game won't live up to them.

In conclusion, RE3 Remake is a mediocre experience that feels more like a 4-6 hour demo of a game that somehow manages to conclude it's story in that span.

It's a great cinematic experience, with a much greater emphasis on action than the RE2 remake and more linear exploration. The survival horror aspects of the series are mostly gone as RE3 drowns you in ammo and Jill gets a handy dodge button, making combat feel much more fast paced. It still keeps a few of it's scares and an overall excellent atmosphere throughout the game.

With that said, there's almost zero puzzles in this game - I only counted 2. And after a while it starts to feel a little bit tedious as you cut through far more zombies than Leon or Claire had to deal with, and while the Nemesis boss fights are visually cool, the big man himself is a bullet sponge so beating him can feel somewhat repetitive. Additionally, some areas from the original RE3 were cut for the remake, presumably for pacing issues, so the remake's campaign only lasts about 4-5 hours, which is hard to swallow if you paid full price for it.

If you can find this game for less than $20-30, it's absolutely worth playing. It's just sadly not quite as good as the RE2 or RE4 remakes.

As a longtime Resident Evil Fan since the original Resident Evil from 1996 on PS1. (What I still consider the best Resident Evil, and maybe game of all time) I am thrilled to see Capcom make Resident Evil great..er again. 

While the original Resident Evil (1996), Resident Evil 2 (1998), Resident Evil 3: Nemesis (1999) and Resident Evil Code: Veronica (2000) are still the better of the options to play. (Why are they not on Steam? You’re killing me Smalls) The Resident Evil Remake (2002) as well as Resident Evil 2 remake (2019) and Resident Evil 3 remake (2020) are still wonderful to play as a true fan of the series.  

While the remakes fall a little short at times of the critical thinking and atmosphere of the originals. They are a large, healthy, and beautiful step in the right direction away from the button mashing, guns blazing, rock punching, brainless experience of Resident Evil 4, 5, and 6 the series took after the Resident evil Remake (2002) and Resident Evil 0 had poor sales.
. 
What Capcom missed here, is they thought people no longer wished-for old-school Survival Horror games due to the poor sales of Resident Evil remake (2002) and Resident Evil 0. When in fact they trapped a true piece of art and wonderful game experience in Resident Evil Remake (2002) and a solid game in Resident Evil 0 on a console no one owned (GameCube). If Capcom would have ported the games sooner as they did Resident Evil 4. They would have had similar sales and proven people still wanted the old school, true Resident Evil experience. 

With both Resident Evil 2 and Resident Evil 3 remakes selling over 17 million copies combined. We can see people are still yearning for old-school Resident Evil. 

Overall, I would recommend this game to all fans and hope for another Resident Evil (1996) and Resident Evil Code: Veronica (2000) Remake in the future. 

As for now now, we wait for the Silent Hill 2 remake and dream of a Dino Crisis remake. 

Cheers,

Hey there, fellow gamers! I just had to drop a line about my recent experience with Resident Evil 3 Remake, and boy, oh boy, was it a wild ride! If you're a fan of survival horror and adrenaline-pumping action, this game is an absolute must-play.

First things first, let's talk graphics. They're off the charts! The level of detail in the environments, from the desolate streets of Raccoon City to the eerie interiors of the abandoned buildings, is jaw-dropping. I swear, I could almost smell the decay in the air. The character models are insanely realistic too, with every sweat bead and muscle twitch making me feel like I was right there alongside Jill Valentine.

Speaking of Jill, she's a total badass in this remake. She's not just a pretty face, folks. Armed with her trusty weapons and unwavering determination, she takes on hordes of grotesque zombies and terrifying creatures with style. The gameplay mechanics are smooth as butter, allowing for precise shooting and heart-pounding escapes. Oh, and let's not forget the explosive boss battles that had me on the edge of my seat, frantically strategizing every move.

The pacing of the game is spot-on. It's a rollercoaster of tension and release, constantly keeping you engaged. You'll explore creepy locations, solve puzzles (some of them had me scratching my head for a while), and encounter unexpected surprises around every corner. The sense of dread and urgency never lets up, making for an intense and immersive experience from start to finish.

Now, let's talk about the audio design. The atmospheric soundtrack perfectly complements the nightmarish setting, setting the mood for pure terror. Every creak, growl, and scream had me jumping out of my skin. And the voice acting? Top-notch. The characters felt alive (or undead, in some cases) with their realistic emotions and reactions. Kudos to the voice actors for bringing them to life!

While the game's campaign might be relatively short, the replayability factor is through the roof. There are multiple difficulty levels to challenge your skills, and the unlockable bonuses and achievements will keep completionists busy for hours on end. Plus, there's an addictive multiplayer mode called Resistance that adds a whole new dimension of fun and chaos.

All in all, Resident Evil 3 Remake is a blast from start to finish. It's a nerve-wracking, pulse-pounding experience that will make you appreciate the survival horror genre all over again. With its stunning visuals, tight gameplay mechanics, and captivating storyline, this game is a winner in my book. Grab your controller, turn down the lights, and get ready for a spine-chilling adventure like no other!

Тот случай, когда порекомендую сначала пройти ремейк этой части, нежели после прохождения второго. Дело в том, что на контрасте со вторым ремейком, третий выглядит и играется довольно посредственно и уступает по многим параметрам. Начиная от отсутствия в прежней мере экономить патроны, из-за чего игра превратилась больше в экшен-шутер, нежели сурвайвор, до потешного Немезиса, который вселяет больше смех, чем ужас. Так же игра страдает скудной продолжительностью. И это удивительно, ведь если бы разрабы больше уделили внимания оригиналу, то всего этого можно было избежать. Классику я прошел следом, чтобы понять из-за чего негодовали олды, пройдя ремейк. После чего их негодование стало для меня доходчиво. В ремейке по какой-то причине отсутствует часть локаций и множество головоломок из оригинала, которые могли с легкостью разбавить тон геймплея. Так же в оригинале была малая нелинейность, когда в определенные моменты прохождения застывало время, и можно было выбрать одно из двух действий, которое не кардинально, но меняло исход ситуации. Мне показалось это интересной механикой, которую стоило развить. Хорошо, что хоть додж от поступающих атак оставили. В общем, описанные выше пункты могли стереть самую главную проблему ремейка на мой взгляд. 

В целом же графика и оптимизация на уровне. Персонажи играют и выглядят достойно. Стрельба приятная. Саундтрек неплохой. Игра сохранила некую часть формулы ремейка второй части, но опять же, в сравнении с ним, третий кажется слабым и пустым. Потерянный потенциал. Короткий хронометраж. Упор на зрелищность, экшен для сохранения динамики в геймплее. Отсутствие головоломок и части локаций из оригинала. Комичный Немезис, который к тому же появляется исключительно в рамках скриптовых моментов. Некоторые боссфайты с ним это что-то с чем-то. Пройти все же стоит, но еще раз, настоятельно рекомендую проходить до второго ремейка, чтобы впечатления были слегка ярче из-за неимения на бэкграунде почвы для сравнения. Лорно никакой путаницы для Вас не будет, т.к. события двух ремейков протекают в плюс-минус одно время.
