This is a phenomenal game but a pretty mediocre remake. There really is no justifiable excuse for what Capcom keeps doing with these remakes they should far surpass the ps1 originals in more than just graphics technology is much better now. I actually love all of these remakes but it's just a shame they can't do better on a remake of 90s ps1 games and include all the necessary content from the originals something good always seems to be missing that was in the originals. I can understand cutting certain things to make a game better in a remake but in this it's clear they rushed it and cut a ton of good content to get it out faster. Entire sections and mechanics are missing like the choices and the clock tower section as well as other areas.

With that out of the way it's still one hell of a game Capcom doesn't miss. The pacing and story are pretty much perfect imo even if Jills character is kind of inferior to the original as far as growth goes. She's a bad bitch from the beginning she doesn't grow into one. But maybe it makes more sense considering she's already been through shit in re1 that was pretty bad. Carlos was fine. The story kept me interested I could see the plot twists from a mile away though blind.

Now let's talk about the elephant in the room Nemesis. I think he was actually great and well made when not scripted. The scripted parts where cool but obviously being dynamic and free more would of been better and scarier he's only really set loose on you like one or two brief times. He was terrifying though in that encounter though he was way under utilized.

The gameplay felt really good and smooth. I liked the dodging mechanic it felt really good when you got used to it. All the weapons felt really nice. The puzzles felt super simplistic for the most part. Weather that's a good or bad thing is up to you. The graphics are great like any other re engine game this game is pure eye candy.

Honestly games like this are rare these days it's extremely short under 10 hours and pretty linear but in a world of open world games this is a breath of fresh air and a joy to play. It can often be picked up for cheap on a steam sale and it well worth it for the heavily discounted price. I'd much rather play this short game than some bloated open world filled with boring filler content. This is definitely worth the purchase.

Hello friends,

First of all, as a fan of this series, I was excited, but some aspects of the game left me a bit disappointed. Let's go through them one by one.

Firstly, Resident Evil 3 stands out with its graphical quality. The details, character animations, and environmental designs in the game are quite impressive. The realistic appearance of the zombies and the atmosphere of the game immerse the player in a thrilling experience. However, I would have expected the environments to be a bit more detailed in some areas. Nonetheless, overall, the visual presentation can be considered satisfying.

The gameplay of the game is fast-paced and adrenaline-filled. As we control our character, Jill Valentine, we strive to survive against zombies. The controls are smooth and responsive, which pulls you right into the heart of the action. However, the game's short length was a bit disappointing. Although the progression of the story and the puzzles are satisfying, it may feel lacking for players expecting more content.

However, Resident Evil 3 performs weaker in terms of storytelling compared to previous games. The development of the characters and their background stories feels somewhat lacking in depth. While Jill Valentine's story is intriguing, I would have expected better development for some of the side characters. There could have been more depth and connection in the story.

The Resident Evil series is famous for its horror experience, and Resident Evil 3 continues this tradition with its atmosphere and sound design. The game shakes you with tense moments and occasionally provides scary encounters. However, more psychological horror and unexpected events could have enriched the experience further.

In conclusion, Resident Evil 3 is a game that stands out with its visual quality, smooth gameplay, and tense atmosphere. However, it has some shortcomings such as its short length, weak storytelling, and character development. Therefore, it may not be fully satisfying for players expecting more content and depth.

Ok, I feel this review is relevant to all the recent Resident Evil remakes, beginning with 2 in 2019. They are all good games. They are all even good Resident Evil games. Are they replacements for the original Resident Evil games? No, they are not. That doesn’t mean you can’t still love and enjoy them for what they are.

Understand, these remakes are not like the Dead Space remake of 2023. That game is so perfect a remake, that there really is no reason to ever play the original Dead Space unless you miss the original voice actors for Hammond and Kendra. Everything about the Dead Space remake is better than the original. That is not the case with the Resident Evil remakes.

It really comes down to what kind of Resident Evil gamer you are. Do you like the running and gunning Survival Action of OG Resident Evil 4, 5 and 6? Then you will really like the new remakes and probably not play the originals, if you ever did. However, do you love the puzzles, keys, clues and Survival Horror of the originals? Then you probably won’t really like the remakes. While the (currently) 3 remakes do still have those aspects, they are not nearly as prevalent as they were in the originals. While the Resident Evil 2 and 4 remakes have expanded the environments and even added a few new places, Resident Evil 3 remake actually took places away, most notably the Clock Tower area. I did appreciate that you got to play as Carlos more than once, and the Hospital was expanded to more than just 3 rather small areas, but I did miss the Clock Tower. I do know why they took it out, because it was an area that was purely OG puzzle and keys. Didn’t really fit the new direction of the remakes. So, I understand why people are complaining about that. The ones that complain about all the Nemesis events being scripted apparently don’t remember that ALL of the Nemesis events in the original are scripted too. Look at and any decent walkthrough of the original game, or the wiki. They can tell you where all the encounters are going to be and what prize you can get from Nemmy when you put him down, temporarily. So I don’t get that complaint.

Still, the remakes are very good games. You just need to take a few minutes and figure out what part of the Resident Evil games you loved the most, and play those versions.

I played the original Resident Evil 3: Nemesis on the PS1 in preparation for this remake and I'm heavily dissapointed. Even at a 80% discount, this "game" feels like a scam. Major story beats of the original were cut and / or replaced with much lesser renditions. One example that actually made me mad is how they reduced the entire City Hall section of the original to a single f--king puzzle. No Restaurant, no Newspaper building, no City Hall, no Clock Tower, no Park, no Facility. What they did keep is the exact same RPD section from RE2:Remake, down to the same exact puzzles. I expected a little bit of asset reuse but this is just awful. There was so little of the original game included in this remake, that this might as well be a new game entirely. The few segments that were kept are not intact though, as they happen at different times or different characters go though them. Now, the original was not a very long game either but it was compensated by having multiple choices within the main campaign that would alter the way your story played out, making it a much more replayable game. Not this remake though, there are no more choices to be made and once you've beaten it once, you've seen everything. I beat the original game in 9 hours while this one took me just 5 hours. I should also note that it came with a god-awful multiplayer no one asked for and I dare not even touch for the fear I might waste any time in that pile of garbage. Jill in the original Resident Evil and Resident Evil 3: Nemesis was already established as a capable and likeable fighter. I don't know who came up Jill's dialogue in the remake, she's always making snarky and sarcastic remarks about everything. Not everything in this laughable attempt at a remake sucks though, the shooting and movement mechanics are nicely implented. Graphically the game is stunning and always a treat to look at. It's just a shame the rest of the game is not up to the same standards.  Don't buy this game, don't play this game even if you get it for free. Instead, download an emulator and play through the original RE3.

As an isolated game it's pretty fun and I really enjoyed it.

That aside, as an RE game it kinda sucks. This was my introduction to the franchise, and I thought it was fun. I liked it enough to give the original one a try, and holy shit were things cut from this game. I had read reviews before getting the game. Even without the cut content like Clock Tower or the multiple choice stuff, it's a sin how tuned down Nemesis is in this remake.

The game feels more like an 80s action movie than a survival horror game, Evil Dead has more horror elements than this game. The devs were definitely horny when they made this game, there's booty shots, tentacles, egg impregnation, and vore.

The actual gameplay is pretty fun, but the Nemesis "boss fights" really aren't aside from the flamethrower fight. Speaking of Nemesis, he's kind of a joke in the remake, as a lot of other reviews are quick to point out. In the original, even stunning the guy was an accomplishment, in the remake however, it really doesn't take much. Now, as I had experienced this game before RE2 remake or the original RE3, I had no idea how Tyrants, and by extension Nemesis were utilized in the games, so I thought this was the standard. In the original RE3 he has a highly adaptive AI that seems to be able to understand and counter any strategy you might come up with to fight him with, even cancelling an attack to reposition and strike again. In the remake he's used as a set piece more than an actual enemy, and the dodge mechanic makes any interaction with him feel unimportant and not really memorable.

The dialogue is unnecessarily cheesy but I figured RE games were just like that because I'd seen clips of RE4 and that's really all the explanation that needs.

I honestly wish the dev team had put more effort into this remake, because while I had fun my first time going through it, revisiting after playing other installments (and the original version of the game) just makes me sad that this was how the game is "meant to be experienced". Overall the game is still a good time, but a disappointment to the franchise as a whole.

Resident Evil 3: Nemesis is a survival horror game developed by Capcom and originally released in 1999 for the PlayStation. The game received a remake in 2020, which I will be reviewing below.

The game follows Jill Valentine, a member of the Raccoon City police department, as she tries to escape the city during a zombie outbreak. She is pursued by a powerful bioweapon called Nemesis, who is sent to eliminate all S.T.A.R.S. members.

The 2020 remake of Resident Evil 3 features updated graphics and gameplay mechanics, but it also makes some changes to the original game. The biggest change is the removal of certain areas and events, which makes the game shorter than its predecessor.

In terms of gameplay, Resident Evil 3 is a mix of action and survival horror. The game features a dodge mechanic that allows players to avoid enemy attacks and counterattack. 

Compared to other games in the series, Resident Evil 3 is generally considered to be less successful than its predecessor, Resident Evil 2. The game received criticism for its shorter length and the removal of certain areas and events from the original game. However, the updated graphics and gameplay mechanics received praise from critics and fans.

Overall, Resident Evil 3 is a solid survival horror game that is worth playing for fans of the genre. However, those who are looking for a longer and more complex game may prefer some of the other games in the series.

The game is... alright. The whole thing feels like it's on rails and in a big rush to get everything over with. It has very little of the exploration that made the remake of Resident Evil 2 feel so fun and rewarding. I've replayed that game 3 times over and am certain I never want to play this one again. There is very little replay value in it due to the fact that all the encounters with enemies/bosses are completely scripted so it doesn't leave room to try playing any differently. 

That all being said, the boss fights and big setpieces the game has are SO FUN. It's unlike RE2 Remake in the way that they feel harrowing in that game; no, in every boss fight you feel like a complete badass blowing everything up. It would be more fun, however, if the game didn't TAKE THE CONTROLS AWAY FROM YOU FOR A CUTSCENE EVERY FIVE MINUTES. That might be my biggest complaint. Right when you are about to pull the trigger on the finishing blow during boss fights, the game rips the keyboard out from under your hands and shows you a cutscene of the exact thing YOU should be doing. But I digress. 

I recommend this game ONLY to people with a predisposition to enjoying Resident Evil games. If the world of Resident Evil doesn't interest you and you don't care about the lore, don't even bother with this game. If you are, however, a Resident Evil fan, then this game has some very integral lore within it for the franchise. A lot of your questions from the previous two games are answered and you need to know this stuff going forward in the series. 

All in all, this game is just alright. You can feel the Resident Evil bones underneath everything, but it's packaged in a bland and uninteresting wrapper. Anyways, that's my rant.

I've never played the original Resident Evil 3, so I can't comment on the criticisms about cut content in the remake. That being said, it is a bit disheartening to hear that a lot was cut out and I can definitely see why that would be an issue for so many people. 

With that aside, this is basically the gameplay of RE2 remake but faster paced and less puzzle heavy. The game is quite short (~5-6 hours on a first playthrough on Standard difficulty), and Nemesis himself just feels like a chore to deal with in non boss fight scenarios (However, the boss fights with him are really well done). Where the game really shines for me is its replayability. I don't know why, but the NG+ style store after completing a first playthrough is insanely addictive. You're given incentive to go back through the game completing various challenges in order to get cool unlocks to use in other playthroughs. The fast paced nature of the game makes these unlocks tempting, like getting the powerful Samurai Edge or ammo crafting companion in order to make more ammo. Not only that, but beating the game on its base hardest difficulty unlocks another, harder difficulty, then another. Because of this, I've been playing through the game multiple times trying to get achievements and Records (the little challenges to unlock points for the item shop). I've been having a blast doing this, and at the time of writing I'm going through Nightmare difficulty, the second hardest difficulty, with an infinite ammo assault rifle, HP regen coins, and attack boosting coins. Key items, consumables, and small paths shift a bit on these harder difficulties too so you can't fully know what to expect with all of this either. I went in to this remake with low expectations after reading all the reviews and controversy around it, but I've been having tons and tons of fun. 

Admittedly, I'm not necessarily the biggest Resident Evil fan out there. I've only played all the main entries (1-8), with my playthroughs of 2 and 3 being those of the recent remakes and that's about it. If you can accept that this game is faster paced and not fully authentic to the original, then you should have at least an enjoyable time with this remake, especially if you like replayability. I would definitely only recommend it on a sale though (~20$ USD), because it would not be worth a full 60$ if you don't end up liking the game enough to keep playing it over multiple times.

Super late edit: I have since played RE3 Nemesis and ouch. Lots left out of this remake, making it feel incomplete. While the remake leaves so much out, I still recommend it on a sale since what's there is fun. However, I really wish this remake had done more. It had a lot of potential that ended up going wasted.

I played RE2 (remaster) and RE3 in a row. In short, if your time and budget is limited and you can only pick one, go for RE2. It's better.

RE2 is amazing for both old and new players, a perfect game introduces new players to the franchise and a nice recap for returning players. However, RE3 feels like a new game - which is not a completely bad idea, but I feel sorry for some classic puzzles like the statue puzzles at the police station are removed. The biggest problem is the content is not that rich, I enjoyed the subway station area map but constantly fighting that undead Nemesis along the way feels tedious, and in the end I don't feel any excitement at all.

Also, RE2 has better mechanics than RE3. When it comes to the cutscenes, RE2 sometimes requires pressing the right key for actions, which offers player a better immersive experience but not in RE3. It's disappointing because Jill constantly experiences emergency incidents. The other thing is, RE2 has a better rhythm for fighting walkers and proceeding the story, yet in RE3 the fighting part is large with only one subway line puzzle to solve, I especially did not enjoy Brad dealing with endless waves of walkers in the hospital reception room. Speaking of characters, Jill is loveable but I don't see a reason to like Carlos.

I rate RE3 positive, it has flaws but still meets my standard for a good game.

[b]Upfront Conclusion:[/b] Resident Evil 3 is a decent remake which falls short of living up to it's predecessor RE 2R, but is a still a worthy addition to the franchise and a fun game overall. 

The two biggest complaints are it's too short and they cheapened the combat experience in order to raise the "difficulty". I can see merit in both those statements. 

As an example of cheapened combat in RE 4 (2005) the chainsaw bagman had a one hit kill and so does nemesis in this game. There's a certain "run from Nemesis" sequence where he will jump into the air for some kind of aerial attack which ultimately ends with an instant kill when he lands on top of you. The difference between the two instakills is that you could run away and evade the chainsaw bagman before he got too close in the original RE 4 and in this game Nemesis does not miss when he jumps into the air.

There's just no nice way of putting it... it's a cheap big "D" move. 

Only the hardest of hardcore RE fans are complaining about the retconned lore in order to make the details from RE 2R work, but if you're not a huge RE fan then this won't matter to you.

TLDR

To put it into perspective... This game (RE3 Remake) is 5€ per 1 hour of game time... Where as RE2 Remake is 1.5€ per 1 hour of game time, and RE4 Remake is 2€ per 1 hour of game time. ':D 

[b]Be warned... If you were a big fan of the original PS1 RE3.... This will be a very sour experience, since you will quickly find out that MANY of the coolest parts of the game, has been "cut" from this remake.... :/[/b]

This game is VERY short... But VERY much worth it when it's on sale, because the game itself is pretty good. Just don't go into it with the mindset of "yay! can't wait to replay the original RE3"... Because it is NOT what you are getting. ':D

Treat this remake like a short demo of the original. :)

FULL REVIEW

It's been 3 years now since this game was released, but since I'm going back to play through all of them again, I figured I'd leave a review now that the hype for these games have gone down...

Of all the remakes when it comes to RE1, RE2, RE3, and RE4, this game would by far be my favorite in the series.... had it been a bit longer, and been more true to the original. :/

The original RE3 for the PS1 is a long and exciting ride, through MANY various locations in Racoon City. Where as this "remake" is a MUCH shorter version with MUCh... and I do mean MUCH fewer locations included.

Remember the [spoiler]city part at the start of the original RE3? Yup, 80% of that has been cut. And the police station, the clocktower, the park, the factory...[/spoiler]... GONE!

I'm am not kidding... The game basically starts you off at the point where you meet [spoiler]Carlos and his group at the subway station[/spoiler]... (I am so upset writing this review xD), and to people who has never played the original, the pacing will feel "okay"... But to anyone who has played RE3 on the PS1, you will feel like this remake is RUSHING you through the various locations from the original... :/

So yeah...

This saddens me quite a bit, since RE3 for the PS1 is one of my top favorite games of all time, on any platform, in my 32 year long life. ':D ALL the other RE remakes are such incredible 1 to 1 remakes... But for some reason the RE3 Remake is the only one that didn't get the full treatment. :/

[b]Why CAPCOM why!? ':D[/b]

In any case... What IS here... is a 10/10 experience if you are able to overlook the feeling of CAPCOM ******** you over by removing most of the game... The game will take about 4-8 hours to complete (it hurts just saying it out loud), depending on how fast you rush through the game. I took me sweet time, and it took me 8.3 hours to complete on my first playthrough. :|

Atm as I'm writing this review the game is 75% off (9,99€), which I think is a fair price at this point for a discount. The games "normal" price of 39,99€ is however MUCH to steep for the amount of hours you get out of the game... 

To put it into perspective... RE3 is 5€ per 1 hour of game time... Where as RE2 is 1.5€ per 1 hour of game time (for both Leon and Claires playthrough), and RE4 is 2€ per 1 hour of game time. ':D 

5 FREAKING POUNDS PER HOUR! (insert mindblown emoji)

(Breathe Daniel.... Breathe....)

But like I said, the game is quite a good experience. Just make sure to get it on sale, and DON'T expect a "full version" of the original RE3, like we got with the RE2 and RE4 remakes...

Hot off the heels of RE2R comes RE3R, following a similar design philosophy, translation of Resident Evil 3: Nemesis to a new generation, and interesting story-telling aspects to boot! Sadly, it fails to live up to the expectations of RE2R.

PROS
+Yet again, the graphics are phenomenal, bordering on photorealistic.
+The character redesigns are all 10/10, hands down. Jill isn't fighting in a tube top, Carlos' new hair works pretty good, and Nemesis... well I'll get to him.
+Jill's undergone some changes that work well taken alone, though they are kind of awkward taken together. She's one part PTSD-stricken survivor (which makes sense from RE1), one part Sarah Conner-level badass (which makes sense considering she was in Delta Force before STARS), and one part genuinely-caring person (which makes sense considering she was one of the gentler members of STARS). Separately, in individual scenes, they work. Taken as a whole, it's a little wonky. Still a W in my book, though.
+Honestly, I now get why people like Carlos. Dude's the definition of a good guy working for the bad guys, but he still tries to do what's right. He's distinctive from other "soldier-type" characters, and I could totally see Jilos as a ship now. Don't know if I support it, but I see it.
+Mikhail is such a bro! Man's the definition of a proper Russian who's got your back!
+Nikolai is such a scumbag! Man's the definition of a crappy Russian who's only got his own interests in mind!
+Brad has a much better send-off than he did in RE2 or RE3. Man makes up for his actions in RE1 and proves why he's STARS material (most of the time).
+The title character from the original, Nemesis has been reimagined to be less of a super-Tyrant and more of a horrific abomination, becoming more animalistic every time he takes too much damage. Many disapprove of the new "trashbag" outfit, but I genuinely prefer it. It's like the bags keep him in the shape of something human(ish), and he reveals his true form as he sheds it.
+In a similar manner, each scripted encounter with Nemesis feels like a desperate run for safety, only becoming a fight when there's no choice. There are exceptions to this, which I'll cover under Cons, but there's no "oh shit" feeling quite like watching him grab a rocket launcher and target you.
+Also, DAMN that introduction sequence was terrifying.
+Return of numerous elements from RE3. The one which stands out most to me is the dodge mechanic. While sort of unnecessary, it pairs well as similar, but different from Leon's parrying in RE4R.
+kid named FINGeR makes his Resident Evil debut! Jokes aside, the sequence is unpopular with many fans, but I love it sheerly for its massive BDE.
+That hospital holdout felt like some good, high-stakes, high-tension stuff! Loved it!
+Hunters are a pain in the ass.
+Solid replayability, and good post-game unlocks like alternate costumes, infinite ammo, and special gear.
+Oh yeah, btw the sound design is fantastic.

CONS
-To start with the elephant in the room: this game ships with Resident Evil: Resistance. It's the only way to get that game, which is an asymmetrical Dead by Daylight-style game. Honestly, it's pretty decent, and plays alright if you have multiple buddies to join up with. Unfortunately, the game is dead, so the only matches you'll (maybe) find will be solidly 300+ ping. In other words, we missed on a lot of stuff for an experiment that (to date) has crashed and burned. This only adds to the impression that RE3R is just a cheap cash-grab after RE2R's success. Maybe it is. I still liked it, but it's definitely not at the same level of excellence.
-It's a good thing this game has lots of post-release content, cuz dang is it short. Getting an S+ ranking in one playthrough of RE2R at highest difficulty must be done in under 5 hours (including both parts). In RE4R, that number is 5:30. In this, that number is 2 hours. This isn't a complaint on having less time, it's a complaint on there being less to do.
-Multiple missing elements from RE3 which arguably make that game better. Live Selection is the biggest one which bugs me, but others also cite the lack of multiple endings and the missing Clock Tower sequence as shortcomings (accurate, but they don't bug me as much, I guess).
-Remember how I said Nemesis was terrifying in scripted events? He's absolutely not outside of them. I was expecting something along the lines of Mr. X from RE2R: a constant presence keeping you pressured to be stealthy, careful, and constantly on the tip of your toes. Instead, he falls from the heavens and chases you while having access to a whip. Pretty unimpressive, to be honest.
-Worse, the thing goes down with ONE frag grenade on Hardcore! Not "stunned so you can get distance" like Mr. X, outright defeated with a loot drop! Disappointment doesn't begin to describe my feelings towards this.
-There's some hinting at what's going on behind the scenes with Nikolai, especially considering scenes from RE4R, but overall I felt more confused than anything in any scene where he was being evil.
-I know they only included one poisonous creature in the Remake, but I really wish there were multiple. I can't express how wrong it feels to cure poison with a green herb instead of a blue herb.
-Look, I love the FINGeR, and it's cool, but I gotta admit, it looks a little big to be man-portable.

Is it as good as RE2R or RE4R? No. Is it worth the full price? No. Is it worth playing on sale? Abso-freaking-lutely.

Resident Evil 3 is a classic survival horror game that will have you on the edge of your seat. The game is set in Raccoon City, which has been hit by a biological weapon that has turned most of the population into zombies. You play as Jill Valentine, a member of the Special Tactics And Rescue Service (STARS), as she attempts to escape the city and uncover the truth behind the outbreak.

One of the standout features of Resident Evil 3 is the Nemesis, a terrifying bio-weapon that is pursuing Jill throughout the game. The Nemesis is relentless, and you will need to use all of your skills to avoid him and survive. The game also features a variety of other enemies, including zombies, dogs, and other monsters, each with their own strengths and weaknesses.

The gameplay in Resident Evil 3 is a mix of exploration, combat, and puzzle-solving. You will need to search the city for supplies and weapons, fight off hordes of zombies, and solve puzzles to progress through the game. The combat is satisfying, with a variety of weapons to choose from, and the puzzles are well-designed and challenging.

The graphics in Resident Evil 3 are top-notch, with detailed environments and character models that bring the game's world to life. The game also features a dynamic lighting system that adds to the game's creepy atmosphere.

One of the game's main drawbacks is its length. The game is relatively short, with a runtime of around six hours. However, the game does offer replayability, with multiple difficulty levels and a variety of unlockables to discover.

Overall, Resident Evil 3 is a fantastic survival horror game that is sure to please fans of the genre. The Nemesis is a terrifying adversary that will keep you on your toes, and the game's mix of exploration, combat, and puzzle-solving make for a satisfying experience. While the game is on the short side, it offers plenty of replayability and is a must-play for fans of the series.

Resident evil 3 remake is a step down from the previous remake done by Capcom, obviously the graphics are much better and seeing areas from the original game reimagined to set a modern esthetic is very cool, it was expected from a company that delivered a similar game like Resident evil 2 remake a few years back.

Is there anything else worth mentioning that's better compared to the original? Unfortunately no, unless you consider tank controls as something bad, depending on whether you prefer the pre-re4 games. Now, what are the cons? There's a lot:

[b] Cut content [/b] 
If you're gonna cut content from the original then atleast add something different that replaces it, in resident evil 3 remake there's 4 main areas: [spoiler] Streets, sewers, hospital, laboratory [/spoiler], this isn't bad, the problem is the fact that you only spend about 30 minutes in one of these areas, and the starting area is literally [b] 2 streets connected to each other [/b], can you really compare it to the original that relied in shortcuts to keep the map incredibly dense? No, you can't. The level design in the remake gets old pretty fast because the scenery changes a grand total of 4 times in 6 hours of gameplay, compare that to areas like the clock tower (cut), the factory (cut), downtown, city park (cut), the lab, Nothing to compensate.

[b] Nemesis [/b] 
I'm not gonna get into detail on why Nemesis is a problem, I'm gonna leave a video that sums up almost all my thoughts, [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bfwvNUxF2uw&t=537s] it's worth watching on its entirety but if you want a shorter explanation start the video at 36:40 [/url]

[b] Jill is Mary Sue incarnate [/b]
Do you remember Chris in Resident Evil 5 hitting a rock with his bare hands with such force that it ends up moving? Everyone criticized that moment as being completely bullshit and out of place for a Resident evil game, [b] Chris may be jacked to the tits and highly trained, but nothing can excuse that moment as being something doable. [/b] Jill did some very badass things in the original Resident evil 3, but none of them were too unrealistic, at the end of the day Jill is only a highly trained and experienced individual, with that being said, [b] HOW [/b] is Jill able to carry a big ass railgun, with her bare hands!?!?! That makes absolute ZERO sense, even RE5 Chris would struggle to lift that absolute monster, Jill's ability to survive to insane stuff is also dialed up to 11, Jill falls from TWO buildings, in one of them she falls on her back from a building of atleast 3 floors, COMPLETELY unharmed, compare her to Leon in Resident evil 2 remake, the rookie cop that is barely able to hold his ground, [b] Leon is portrayed just like in the original, because that's how he's supposed to be [/b], nothing over the top, and this should've been the same for Jill.

 [b] Difficulty scaling [/b] 
There's 5 difficulties: Assisted, Standard, Hardcore, Nightmare and Inferno. With this wide array of difficulty options you expect an even scaling in difficulty, it's not. It took me 4 hours to complete the game for the first time in hardcore, this should be okay considering that there's 2 other difficulties that are supposed to be the hard ones, little issue, [b] the delay between attacks of every enemy is lowered significantly [/b], this may not seem like a big issue at first with normal enemies, but this means that you will get stunlocked to death a lot more frequently, this is frustrating, but Nemesis is another story, Nemesis in inferno will stunlock you to death, EVERY time. If he connects one attack it's over, you're dead, this holds true in almost all encounters with Nemesis, the final boss on inferno is THE HARDEST BOSS IN THE RESIDENT EVIL FRANCHISE, he hits you once with his zero delay attacks YOU'RE DEAD, GAME OVER, if you're having issues with the boss watch [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fc5Ai4QwU5s] this video [/url].

[b] Final score [/b]
60/100: Just play the original or wait for sales.

Foreword: 
In this review i will explain why Resident Evil 3 Remake is an outstanding game and why it doesn't deserve the criticism mostly.

Story:
Don't come in to this game and expect the quality of story from it's predecessor. The story and the game might be a bit short, but i think that this game delivers an enjoyable fast paced story. We have our Characters Jill and Carlos which synergize both really well together and create enjoyable moments. As i said, there is not much to the story in this game, but if you're interested in the lore you can view it on youtube or search it up on the internet, worth it in my opinion, as your experience with the game itself gets way better. 

Gameplay: 
This is where the game shines. And for me the gameplay was better than Resident Evil 2 Remake. I know that there weren't that much differences, but theres one huge new mechanic, which complety changes the gameplay. It's the ability to dodge and parry, which frees you from the impaired state and gives you actually the ability to be more mobile while fighting hostiles. Apart from that it really plays like RE2 Remake. In RE2 Remake the Tyrant was tuff, but in this part Nemesis is extremely obsessed with Jill. I don't really remember moments were he wasn't chasing me around. I don't want to say more about him, cause the new players of the game should experience him for themself.

Graphics:
The Game looks and runs really well on the RE Engine, definitly a visual brilliance.

Conclusion:
This game is amazing even if some people won't agree, because they missed some characteristics of the original, which is understandable, but doesn't justify their criticism that the gameis bad. It might not be the remake that the fanbase wanted, but it's for 5-7 hours an amazing game, with two charming protagonists. I'd recommend this game for people that just want to enjoy the gameplay and don't want to deal with a complex story. You should buy this game when it's on sale, because it's a bit pricy for the short experience. I will give this game a personal score of 9,5/10

As someone who got to know Resident Evil through the remake of RE2, I found the remake of RE3 an equally excellent game! 

The game is played from the role of Jill Valentine, the STARS officer who was already the protagonist of the first Resident Evil (AFAIK; never played it). The story begins during the outbreak of the T-virus in Raccoon City, following Jill's attempts to get out of the city alive.

Much like RE2, RE3 combines action-rich exploration with survival horror, though RE3 feels much more linear compared to its predecessor. A single playthrough took me seven hours, but according to an achievement it can be done in less than two hours. There is no incentive for a second playthrough (unlike in RE2, where you could choose between two protagonists and follow different stories). This makes the game somewhat short for its price, even on sale.

The game is played in the third person, featuring Jill as the primary protagonist, and Carlos in two shorter sequences. Both characters are likeable if somewhat bland; Jill certainly doesn't have as much personality as, say, Lara Craft from the Tomb Raider reboot, or Aloy from the Horizon franchise, or Elizabeth from BioShock Infinite, or many other characters from story-focused games. The plot likewise won't win any literature prize, but it works well enough to get things going.

From a technical standpoint, the game is fantastic. The graphics are gorgeous, sounds are great, gameplay is fun and engaging. I prefer this kind of action-rich horror quite a lot over the subpar jumpscare kind that has become popular in recent years. The gunplay is pretty fun, the exploration part is very much reduced to RE2, and Nemesis as a boss enemy is kind of bleh. 

Resident Evil 3 is a fun and interesting game to play through over a weekend, even if you aren't a particular friend of horror games (like me). I'm not sure if I'll ever play through the game a second time -- there are better games if you want a good story, and better games if you want cool gameplay -- but I'd still call this an easy recommendation, and I'm certainly looking forward to playing RE4 once the price drops in sales. 

I'd recommend buying the game on sale, when it's typically 75% off (10€ / 10$ / comparable prices).

Edit: Note that there are lots of mods out there that typically change only Jill's appearance. I used one that prevented Nemesis from chasing me around (because that got kind of tedious). Most mods are made for the non-raytracing version of the game, which can still be accessed through the beta versions of the game properties.

Note further that this game comes with some free multiplayer game thingy, which I'm told is not that great (due to cheating players, not because the game itself is terrible). I haven't checked that out, and don't plan to.

Resident Evil 3 remake is underrated. Its starts a bit on the rails but quickly gets into the open city. The controls are fluid and refined—some of the best controls in an RE game or otherwise. One of the best added features is the dodge mechanic. It's similar to the dodge in the the RE Revelations series but it actually works. It's more intuitive than the way they did it in RE2R where you couldn't dodge but had to carry a knife or grenade and use that to avoid grabs instead.

Another great addition are the "coin" boosts. You can really customize your play style if you are willing to sacrifice a storage spot. So, even beyond normal, hard, and even harder modes, you can tweak the difficulty from within there with the coins.

Jill and Carlos' characters are generally well done, neither too invincible, too weak, too arrogant, nor too obnoxious as are characters in many modern games. The Mikhail villain is a bit overly one-dimensional, though.

The upgrades and rewards systems are likewise actually attainable without being ultra-expert level player (like RE2R required) nor playing for a million hours. With moderate to generous repeated gameplay, you can achieve enough weapon kills and other reward points to unlock funner stuff — including the RE trademark infinite weapons which always make for a fun playthrough. There's also a very fun fire knife called Hot Dogger that won't ever break and will set enemies ablaze briefly with every strike.

The game was criticized for being too short or excluding some stuff from original, but what is actually there is polished and I don't recall a single glitch. You don't see much criticism of what is actually there - if this had been a DLC for RE2R, more people would rave about it. It's also a great game for single evening speedrun. The nightmare and inferno modes also mix up the enemy and item locations which makes for a very different experience.

[h1] Introduction [/h1]

Resident Evil 3 is one of those chapters which were in my backlogs for a while. I’ve heard earlier that game is too short, as well that it’s not such horror. As well metacritic score shows, that game didn’t match users so much. After I finished the game may tell that this game is well done.

[h1] Main plot [/h1]

The story is interesting enough. We see a story of stars officer - Jill Valentine, who has been in Raccoon city, when started an epidemic. During all game we see one story from two characters - Jill and Carlos. While to see the hole story for both characters in RE 2 we used to play a new game from another characters view, here we have answers immediately. But I still have a question to one episode - [spoiler] in last part of the game Carlos went in underground to find a vaccine, and missed for almost a day. When Jill woke up she decided to find Carlos. So Jill made a vaccine, and then found Carlos. What Carlos has been doing all this time in underground? [/spoiler] If game shows us all story from both sides it would be correct to make at least 15 min episode where shows ‘Carlos was walking and then felled down’ for example.

Although the story is interesting - it’s very fast paced. The whole game I had no time to stop and get a rest, at this time I had a new cutscene, or a fight. So while previous part was more about puzzles and searching for keys, this part is more about action.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

Technically main mechanics were taken from RE 2 remake. Almost all mechanics are the same, but we now have an option to parry. It makes game much easier, because after each well done parry the scope automatically rises on opponents head.

The game more looks as a shooter then horror, what is true. Before each big fight game gives us enough bullets, and during all game I had no filling of weapon deficit (have played on normal level).

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

During the whole game I had only one crash, but otherwise game is done perfectly. Despite the fact that the game is very quickly passed on the plot, there are no complaints. Yes, the game is not long, if you know what is happening, you can really go through it in 3-4 hours without difficulty. It took me 7 hours, despite the fact that I went through it without straining and died a lot of times.
But in general I had enough fun, and enjoyed the game.

I don't have the same nostalgia for RE3 that some other people do. I adored RE2 for the PlayStation - played it at least a dozen times. But RE3 felt like a half-hearted side project. Reused environments, enemies, graphics, etc. I played it once and never touched it again. So when people say, "I can't believe they cut out the clock tower in the remake!", I'm thinking "I don't even remember the clock tower."

Judged on its own merits, RE3make is a fun romp. I enjoyed it way more than the original, for sure. But it's just not the masterpiece that RE2make was. It lacks the depth and replayability of that game. I think that comes down to the linear nature of RE3; With 1 & 2, you finish your first playthrough thinking, "Oh yeah, I could have done this first and saved myself so much running around." Here, every playthrough is more or less the same. And yes, the "Nemesis Choices" of the original would have helped a bit in that department. 

After a while, RE3make feels like you're just running from one boss encounter to the next. And then it's over in ~6 hours. Is it worth $60? Nah. But catch it on sale and it's worth experiencing. But just like with the original, I know that I'll be returning to RE2 when I want to get my zombie killing fix.

4th stop on my RE franchise playthrough. I never played the original 3 and I understand that it might've been better, but I enjoyed this title quite a bit. It was short, and I feel like it doesn't have too much replayability, but I very much enjoyed my time with this game. I do wish it was longer though.

### Visuals 9/10 ###
- Awesome graphic
- Very detailed faces and character expressions in cut-scenes
- Very atmospheric light/shadow ambiente
- Various zombie designs
- Played on 3070 with all settings to max and no dlss: Constant fps above 100

### Characters 6/10 ###
- The characters all stay very flat, but at least you play Jill most of the time
- Carlos is likable, but there is zero backround story
- All characters act absolutely cliché

### Story 4/10 ###
- Very very generic
- No surprises
- If you want a good story, play RE 7 + 8 :)
- I love everything about RE, so I didn't really bother

### Gameplay 9/10 ###
- Port to pc is very well executed
- Fast and easy to learn key layout
- Aiming goes really well with mouse
- Still quite difficult in differenct situations (played on hardcore)
- Even one zombie can get a problem, if he gets to close
- The dodging was clunky, but ok for some Nemesis encounters and ofc. the hospital situation -.-
- Tipp: Use the dodging on Carlos when you fight the hunters in the hospital. You have no chance otherwise, if you play on hardcore
- Some refreshing tasks, some nice secrets, but the amount of puzzles were drastically reduced, compared to the RE 2 remake


### Level design 8/10 ###
- Exploring is rewarded
- There is not much to explore, though. Pretty straight forward with some secrets not too far off the main route
- Minor puzzles, but nothing very memorable
- The overall design was pretty fitting and really well executed, especially roaming around the streets of Racoon City
- The levels aren't as complex and huge as RE 2 remake and I actually managed to play through the game in under 10 hours, with everything explored

### Overall 7.2/10 ###
What can I say, I just love Resident Evil horror games. So it is definitely a win for me. I played the RE 2 remake (which was outstanding) and this game was still good and enjoyable for me.
The playtime is really short, so try to get it on sale, because it is not worth full price money for what you get.
There is a shop after the game, that enables you to buy new items and weapons, so the re-playability is pretty high. Also additionally there is a new difficulty (nightmare).
The ending of the game was very generic and the part I disliked the most. Final boss fight, another boss fight and then a super cheese final cutscene.
But, as I said, I love RE, so I still enjoyed it a lot.
I'd say if you have never played RE, I would start with the RE 2 remake, then the RE 4 remake, then RE 7 + 8 and then RE 3.

it's time for my review of Resident Evil 3 Remake. And let me tell you, this game is like a box of chocolates...if every chocolate was a zombie trying to eat your face off.

First of all, let's talk about the graphics. This game is so beautiful, it's almost a shame to cover it in blood and guts. Almost. And don't even get me started on the character models. Jill Valentine has never looked better, and Nemesis...well, let's just say he's a face only a mother could love. If that mother was a mutated monster, that is.

But let's talk about the real star of the show: the gameplay. This game is like a mix between a horror movie and a game of tag. You're constantly running from Nemesis, trying to find a way out of Raccoon City before it's too late. And let's not forget about the puzzles. If you're like me and can't figure out how to open a door without a keycard, then this game will have you scratching your head for hours.

Overall, Resident Evil 3 Remake is a thrilling ride that will have you on the edge of your seat...or hiding under it. If you're a fan of heart-pumping action, terrifying monsters, and the occasional jump scare, then this game is a must-play. Just make sure you have a strong stomach and a good pair of running shoes, because you're gonna need both.

A solid game to play though. Re2 remake already did that "guy constantly chases you" shit so they actually do bombastic fights with the Nemesis peppered in through the game. Not as good as RE2 or 4, but still well worth it on a sale.

Stupid fun action; classic Resident Evil vibe.  

I'm really not a fan of Nemesis and the over the top action in this game. It's just goofy and going into this after playing RE2, which is pretty well grounded, this one was just ridiculous at times. So while I rolled my eyes a lot during my first playthrough, there was a lot I really enjoyed. 

The Good:
- The mechanics/gameplay are great. Most of it is carryover from RE2, but the game feels a bit smoother and maybe faster. The addition of the dodge mechanic also added some extra depth to the game when playing normally but especially when speed running. 
- Looks wise, it looks almost the same as the RE engine from RE2. Which is not a bad thing. RE2 looks amazing and so does this. RE3 might even look a bit better in a side-by-side but I couldn't notice any real differences. 

The Bad:
- The over the top action and goofy nemesis. This guy is just ridiculous. Mr. X was a lumbering presence like in the movie It Follows (go watch that if you haven't already), but Nemesis is hilarious. This man flies around the map like some evil version of Superman. I don't mind an intentionally OP enemy but they should have taken it down just a notch with this guy. It looked like he was moving at 1.5x speed and really just distracted me whenever he was around. And to make this complaint worse, the Nemesis just can't get the job done. He's an unstoppable machine when the game wants him to be scary and he's a bumbling idiot when the game wants Jill to escape or fend him off. 
- Maybe a minor complaint but boy does Jill take some damage throughout the game. I know it's just a game, but idk it just takes me out of it watching Jill drive a car off a 3 story parking garage (no seatbelt), crash it upside down, and walk away no biggie. 
- The BIGGEST con of this game is length. Not just in the main story but overall content. I was able to 100% this game in 18 hours. That is just way too short. 4.5 hours to beat it my first playthrough and my fastest playthrough was about an hour, hour and a half? Speed running aside, my first playthrough was not rushed at all. I played it very casually and still blew through it.

OVERALL, it's a fun Resident Evil game that's worth a playthrough. When the game goes on sale for $5-10 it's totally worth it. I'd say it's a rip-off at $40 so I can understand the hate this game gets. 

[SPOILER SECTION]
And another complaint with Nemesis is the whole, oh the big bad isn't dead yet trope. It can be done well (like Mr. X in RE2 or Jack in RE7), but this wasn't it. I really just did not like the Nemesis so imo it's unfortunate how much of the game revolves around him (and yes I know, the game is called Nemesis).

- Nemesis, the nemesis fight is pretty good, but you could just down him with a nade. 

- Lack of costume, not going to talk about how many costume that Jill has in OG RE3, but a Resident Evil game that has little to no costume (Jill has 2 and Carlos has a hair make-over), is an insult to the Resident Evil Franchise.

- Removal of iconic scene from the OG, OG has one of the most memorable scenes in the RE Franchise and they removed most of them.

- Lack of puzzle, OG has the most puzzles in an RE game. In Remake, you have one, the Train station puzzle which the answer to it is just infront of you.

Most of my review and comparisons are between this and RE2 Remake.
- I would highly recommend this. Even at $40 I would feel this would be worth it.
- RE Boomer fans are impossible to please because they don't know what they want and they all want different things.
- I enjoyed this far more than RE2 Remake. This felt more like RE4's playstyle. Fairly linear, little backtracking, more story, less puzzles, more action.
- I never played the OG on PSX. This game standing on it's own is fantastic. I would honestly replay this over RE2 Remake.
- My playtime casually was 11 hours. The playtime on howlongtobeat between this remake and the RE3 OG on the PSX, is about the same. 6+ hours. But a 6 hour playthrough is not possible imo if you play casually. Unless you're rushing and skipping stuff 4 hours seems not possible at all on a first playthough. Yes, RE2 Remake is a longer game if you do leon + claire 2nd scenario. But RE3R's story is more interesting.

Pros
- Jill. She's is now my favorite RE character.
- There wasn't constant pressure like RE2 Remake with Mr. X where you would run to the other side of the police station, only to have Mr. X appear right in front of you. In RE3R, if there is pressure, it is temporary and not constant.
- Wielding the knife in RE3 remake made more sense than how RE2 remake did it.
- There's no durability to the knife in RE3 remake, which i would prefer but you also can't use it deter a bite either.
- Scripted animation sequences were well done, the graphics overall were also very good.
- Characters were very high quality, and so were the animations. Mocap I'm guessing was used.
- I saw very little reused assets from RE2 remake, other than the police headquarters which was less than 1/8th of the game, and even that wasn't exactly identical.
- The story was far more interesting and action packed than RE2 Remake. But less horror survival.
- The music was absolutely significantly better than RE2 Remake in every way. RE2 Remake music was either weak or non-existent/silent in areas it shouldn't have been.
- I really enjoyed the boss battles. I died a few times, so they felt challenging, but not impossible and they weren't easy I felt.
- I didn't feel the game was a walk through the park or overly difficult.
- The dodge mechanic is handy.

Cons
- The laser sight could have been graphically improved other than just a red dot on the HUD...
- There are a few bugs, but nothing I felt was a deal breaker, such as collision areas blocking my shots when they should have hit the zambies. Sometimes dialog only occurred if I died first and replayed the scene.
- I still don't know what pressing A repeatedly during a zombie bite does... I always get bit and take damage.
- There were a few textures (very few) that could have had an increase in res. Fire maybe, nade explosion particles, and a few environment textures I saw, but that's all.
- The fire in some places looks somewhat poor and planar, and the animation rate for it felt a little too low to me.
- The animation LOD budgeter kicks in at a distance that's a bit too close. This also occurs in RE2, but since you're always inside and you don't seem zambies at a distance usually, you don't notice it as much. So it looks like it's an RE3 only thing but it's not. Basically, when you view zambies from a distance, they animate at a low sampling rate so they look choppy, but I only noticed this in RE3R about 3 times total.
- The fire hose sequence with the water spraying at the beginning of the game was quite poor imo, but it's a minor forgettable thing.
- The biggest thing I felt could have been better in RE3R were the 1 shot kills/insta deaths. Several times there was nothing I could do to avoid it or I would get stun locked and get his 3 times in a row resulting in death. Mainly with nemesis a couple times, and definitely with the dudes in the 2nd half of the game. So I saved often. I died about 30 times for my first run though this game. Fortunately, there is usually a save point before the 1 shot kills seem to occur, so not much time was lost and it wasn't as annoying as it could have been.

Note: Some of these things there are mods for to correct, so that might be something you could look at.

Overall the things I noticed that are negative are also minor. The biggest thing being the 1 shot kills. But, despite this, I would definitely suggest playing it anyways, but just make sure you save liberally to avoid some frustration.

Major spoilers ahead but who's reading reviews for RE3 remake 3 years after release? I only do reviews out of a personal sense of satisfaction anyway. So, this review is super bare bones because I havenb't played the game in a long time. 
This game is okay. I never played the original game (or anything that came out before Biohazard) so I can't speak for how well it relates to the original but I can tell you a few things. The game has the strongest start out of any RE game I've played. Jill and Carlos are a good duo. This game is unbelievably short. I can't even describe the way I played it because I bought it on Xbox One X and beat it a a few times before buying it on PC to boost my library and give it one last hurrah. It is so short. It's like 7 hours long if you take your time. It is not worth 60 dollars if they're even trying to sell it for that price anymore. It's worth more like 30 at most. The parts, from memory, go like: Wake up, run, make it to subway, gallivant around town, turn on power in unusually tense and well-made bug horror sequence, wake up scrotum demon... Part of the reason I was so excited for this game when it came out was the idea that Nemesis would function like Mr. X from the RE2 remake. This was not true, While he did act as a much more dangerous and interesting immortal antagonist, you only ever encountered him a couple of times and most of them were probably scripted. If you looted everything you were able to before triggering him then you probably won't see him outside of scripted chase sequences. I feel bad for the people who had to program him as an enemy that follows you, if he even does. I might be misremembering. Where were we? Wake up, run, make it to subway, gallivant around town, turn on power in unusually tense and well-made bug horror sequence, wake up scrotum demon, run to trigger subway, run to subway, run, go through sewers, make it up and beat him in a boss battle for the first time, walk a little and meet gunman, get chased with rocket launcher, meet Carlos. My memory for the next section is a little foggy but I think you do the most infuriating Carlos sequence ever imagined next. Actually, first they crash the subway together and Jill watches scrotum fall into the water while flailing. "Bitch can't even swim." Then, he mutates into a whole different creature and you fight him, he plays dead and then shoots heroin up your left butt cheek and you pass out. Then you do the Carlos hospital sequence before he comes and finds you? Is that right? Then Jill wakes up in the hospital and does a bunch of stuff. That is, after a defensive battle. Then we go into the basement and enter the endgame. We fight two or three regenerators and a couple of throwback enemies (hard to say throwback when we saw them two hours ago or less.) We make it through the secret underground lab and fight Nemesis AGAIN in a boss fight with little variation and the same gimmick. Then we walk two feet and fight him AGAIN. Then we shoot the bad guy and escape on helicopter. The time it took me to type that all out was probably about 1/3 of the time it took to actually do all of that. That is how short the game was. Carlos was so hot. 
Anyway, despite being visually impressive and looking good in all areas that we appeared in, and having memorable Nemesis sequences, this game's only lasting legacy is the blender p0rnography that people continue to make to this day because of how hot Jill is. I'm gonna give this a thumb up because I first played it when I was too young to care about any of the flaws and as long as I enjoyed it at any point in time (whereas I now enjoy Jill Valentine "game-over" screens with my right hand) it counts as a good game in my book. 
By the way, I don't know why the company tried to make accompanying add-on games attached to both RE3 AND Village but both of them are complete garbage. I can honestly say I'd rather bite off every finger on both of my hands before I'd ever reinstall Resistance or even try RE:Verse. Capcom making those games is a crime against humanity beyond anything committed in WWI, WWII, and every crime in Britain combined. Loved it. I am only getting into the Resident Evil series. And this might be a controversial opinion, but I think RE3 Remake is a better package than RE2 Remake (that said, both games are excellent). It improves on the formula without requiring you to play through the same content twice to get the full story. 

RE3 also handles its two playable characters better, with their stories working off each other instead of overlapping like it did previously - Jill & Carlos are partners, whereas Leon & Claire only really saw each other at the beginning/end of RE2.

Nemesis was also a great antagonist... While maybe not as foreboding as Mr. X in RE2, chasing you through the RPD corridors, it appears when it makes sense (scripted), which isn't a bad thing, and allows the setup if explosive set pieces.

Conclusion: While RE2 is a better video game, RE3 was a more fun experience for me. Overall, I do not agree with the statements saying RE3 Remake should've been relegated as DLC to the RE2 Remake... People complain about the runtime, which I don't really agree with (9 Hours, 1 Playthrough) for me, versus RE2 (14 Hours, 2 Playthroughs). So, is it shorter? From a certain perspective. But it has a slightly better overall story (more character driven than plot driven), with more locations, and a use of its characters that don't leave the player as confused as the prior remake.

It's a fun replayable short burst of action, kinda in the vain of Metroid Fusion. First-person mod (RE Framework) enhances the experience and horror, and Nightmare difficulty buffs Nemesis decently. Grenades become scarcer and more valuable for the later segments of the game, and it takes two to down Nemesis on that mode, it presents a nice resource decision for the player to make in the early game and forces you to get good at dodging.

Hot Dogger is a  really cool unlockable! This game has a much higher skill ceiling than it initially seems and it's satisfying to climb it and to try to beat Nightmare/Inferno without the buff coins. The enemies get remixed after Hardcore and the last boss also benefits a lot from the hardest difficulties. I recommend this game to those who're willing to let go of the original RE3 and allow this game to stand as it's own thing.

So, RE3make, where to begin with this one.

Well lets start with the good stuff, unlike RE2make, this game is more action oriented, and you get a dodge ability, but it can be tricky to master, doing a perfect dodge will allow you to aim directly at the enemy's weak spot while the game its slow down, so theres some skills to be learned here, at certain points in the game this ability is instead replaced with a parry like variant, which allows you to stun enemies instead. 

You get more ammo compared to RE2make as well, which is why this game is more action oriented, of course, that means more enemies, so you gotta be ready for that.

The higher difficulties will also change the item and enemy locations, which adds replayability for those looking to complete the game multiples times.

Speaking of, after completing the game once, you will unlock the Shop, which allows you to buy several items, from weapons, to items to boost your abilities, items normally found during the run, etc, which you can use on future runs, to buy them you gotta do various challenges found in Records, similar to the ones in RE2make, theres several of them, some which can be quite challenging, with the amount of points earned being based on the difficulty of the challenge, this gives you quite a bit of content to play this game which is quite short. 

The boss fights are also pretty good and enjoying, something i felt RE2make didnt quite get to the same extend. 

Now into the negative stuff...

The gore was toned down, this becomes obvious with the zombies, instead of how it was in RE2make, when shooting at zombies limbs which would cause them to tear and fall off, now just explode and disappear completely.

The game is REALLY short, this is due to entire sections and even bosses being cut from the original, which is a letdown overall, you first run, which if you do explore plenty, you might get maybe 6 hours, maybe even less, more experienced players can complete this game in likely less than an hour

The decision making mechanic was removed entirely as well. 

And the main disappointment... the star of the show, Nemesis himself, anyone that played the original RE3 or heard of it, has heard of this guy, and how much of a threat he was, while in this game hes definitely dangerous, most of his encounters are scripted instead of random, and like mentioned before, due to how short the game is, his gameplay as a pursuer is quite short, only lasting for about the a fifth of the game, after which he just becomes a recurring boss, after how amazing the Tyrant was in RE2make with how he constantly patrolled the RPD and being a constant random threat, Nemesis was a downgrade, while Nemesis is considerably more aggressive and dangerous, (specially on the higher difficulties) the short duration of the game greatly hurt him. 

Last thing would be that the final difficulty of this game Inferno can be quite... unfair to say the least, specially the final boss. 

Now, i said many negative stuff, but this is still a good game, but, its not really worth the price, which is largely cause of this game being tied with RE:Resistance, which is an online PvP game (which is pretty much dead at this point i believe) so i would recommend buying this game when its on sale if possible, thats why many people said this should have come has a DLC for RE2make, and i can see why. 

Its a good game, but its not a good remake.

Being new to the RE series a friend recommended me this game to get used to the gameplay mechanics and what to do. It took me awhile to get used to the fact that you can dodge in this game using Jill or Carlos. Though I think this is the only game where you can dodge? The game itself is pretty short, so you can get through a lot of the game play and plot quickly when you play. As for the scares, it wasn't bad overall, but nothing really scared me a ton. The most important thing would be to always constantly look at your map since it lists out locked items and areas you haven't fully explored. As for puzzles, I will say there aren't too many complex puzzles in this game most are pretty straightforward.

If you do want more of a challenge, you can always switch your game to different modes. There are: Assisted, Standard, Hardcore, Nightmare, and Inferno. I was also told by my friend that the games adjusts naturally based on how you play. So if you play good you get more of a challenge but if you don't then it gets easier for you. Though it does prompt you to adjust the actual difficulty if you tend to die a lot. Overall it was a great experience playing RE3, both the characters are enjoyable and fun to play, the different locations and enemies are a challenge at times.

I feel like I need to write a positive review to offset some of the negative ones. This game is great. I played the original years ago when it came out and was always luke warm to it, Code Veronica was a far better sequel to RE2 in my opinion. So I was less excited about trying this remake than I was for RE2. However, I was pleasantly surprised, this game was really fun! It had a nice mix of action and traditional RE elements, and I feel like the new additions and design choices only improved the game. 

The nemesis can still be a pain, but I feel like the pacing and overall story structure of this version makes far more sense. Both to modernise and just generally improve the original game. 

One of the complaints I've seen a lot is length and value. While I agree this is not a $60-70 game, it definitely fits in that $30 range quite nicely. I feel like people who complain about this game's length are the same people who keep buying and praising the 100+ hour bloated collect-a-thons that Ubisoft churns out every year. Quantity does not equal quality and a game like this proves that in spades. About an 8-10 hour campaign for a first play through is perfectly reasonable and enjoyable. All these people who say they are "thorough" and "collect everything" in a first playthrough, and yet, also claim it took them 3 hours are simply full of $hit. I like to play lots of games and I enjoy a mix of short and long campaigns to mix it up; it's about quality. if a game is tight, cohesive, and enjoyable at 10-15 hours that's great. 100 hour games can be enjoyable, but are also exhausting! Especially when bloated with needless things included just to pad the run time. 

This game, while linear, has an enjoyable enough gameplay loop that subsequent playthroughs can still be rewarding, but they're totally optional as well. 

Basically, if you like RE and want to play a solid game, you can't go wrong here.

I stayed up until now (3:49 am) in order to run the game on hardcore and get the Minimalist achievement, where you can't access the item box whatsoever.

Despite a lot of the negativity people throw at RE3, I firmly believe this is better than the RE2 remake, purely because you can beat this game in 3 hours on a first playthrough, where RE2 takes a fair bit longer, and you can't really casually run it. With all coins and infinite rocket, you can run through Inferno in an 1:10, and even shorter if you aren't a mongaloid like me and can actually fight the final boss.

This remake is shorter than Jill "skort" classic outfit, would i recommend it? absolutely.. is it a good remake? absolutely no! is it a fun game? definitely yeah, is it worth purchasing? probably no get it on steam sale instead.. 

P.S. if you planning to play this game consider installing mods, it will make your experience 10x better..

Would give it a 9 if it wasnt cut off to 5 hours of gameplay. Still very good tho.

Recommended On Sale (or around the £15/£20 price mark) 

I did pre-order at full price, and while the extra costume was decent and the game was great, there's simply not enough here to warrant that price. I almost regret it...almost. 

Things I liked: 
+ The graphics are fantastic
+ The gore is great
+ There is a survival aspect with inventory management, upgrades to find and plenty of weapons late-game. 
+ This one shows more of Raccoon City, a setting I prefer over all
+ There are two playable characters (both of which are really awesome)
+ There are callbacks to the RE2 Remake
+ It's more Resident Evil goodness
+ Dodge mechanic is cool - going slow-mo after you perform a perfect dodge and aim! The other games sorely needed this. (RE2 and RE4 remake)
+ Cool live-action intro scene. Really works to get you immersed in the city. 
+ Faithful to the source material, minus some missing parts (see below)

Things I'm neutral on: 
O The boss doesn't hunt you down like in RE2 Remake, it's more scripted
O Less scary than the previous game. Plenty of panic moments, but less horror. 

Things I didn't like: 
- TOOO SHORT. The primary complaint of every review. My first Hardcore playthrough was about 5 hours and my Hardcore Speedrun was 1hour40min! I've heard reports of entire sections of the original game not remade here, so they could have easily done more. Here is a guide that shows what modders have done to make it more of a classic https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2818555371
- Boss fights aren't very interesting. They feel somewhat samey: Knock them down to a weak state and shoot the blob. 
- I get a black screen hitch at a certain point in the game EVERYTIME. Lost a no-save run to it on the hardest difficulty (there are no autosaves) and lots of other people are STILL having this issue. Have to download a Stream Version beta just to finish the game. 
- Not many costumes. 

Overall: 
I really enjoyed this game for what it was. 
A quick 5 hour game about a virus that I can play in parts while I go out and work in the real world plagued by a virus. (this review was written during covid). The game does feel rushed and definitely could have been longer. But what was here, I enjoyed. We asked for more and we got a bit more, just not as much as we hoped. 

That said, I'd buy another for about this length - the quality is just too damn good. 
I'd probably hold off on the pre-order though and wait for a sale. Which is what I'm telling you to do now that I've completed a dozen times!

Lets start this review off the right way. Yes I know this game is short, yes I know this game cut stuff out from the original, and no I didn't play the original and don't have easy access to it either. Do I care about this stuff? No, not really. I respect others opinions however, I must politely say I don't really care that some people didn't enjoy this game as much as I did.

Now that that's out of the way, I loved this game so much as it was like Resident Evil 2: Remake for me. A game I couldn't put down and enjoyed all the way through to the end. Nemesis has always been one of the coolest Resident Evil characters to me, and as a newcomer to playing these games the most interaction I had with him prior to this game was in other media and games such as Marvel vs. Capcom. His persistent chase of Jill Valentine is awesome and iconic and I was super stoked to hear him yell at you whilst chasing you, and even stare at you menacingly in certain areas like the toy store. I love the doge roll Jill has and the shoulder check/punch Carlos has as both made game play encounters with hoards of zombies really fun to deal with!

I like to look at this games shorter length as a positive more than a negative, to me it makes it have more replay value. And honestly not every game needs to be the 80+ hour long open world game that is popping up everywhere nowadays to be classified as "good", but I digress.

This game is great I loved every minute of it and I will be replaying it very soon! I'll leave you with a quote from my favorite character,

"S.T.A.R.S!" -Nemesis

Resident Evil 3. I got this game after playing and not liking RE2, in my opinion, I liked it a lot more. My second introduction to the series. It removes a lot of the puzzle sections of RE2 with more action segments. The story is a lot more captivating to. Leon S. Kennedy is my favorite RE protagonist but in my first intro to the series, RE2 Remake, the actor who played him was a little bland, emotionless, and lifeless. But here, Jill and Carlos' actor and character are amazing. Natural delivery, distinct personalities, and the random bits of dialogue in gameplay are perfect. The combat is actually satisfying compared to RE2, amazing optimization, and that stuff. I felt weirdly connected to them to. Jill reminds me of a TWD Season 3-4 Clementine. And Carlos is played by the same guy who played Javier in TWD Season 3, they both were the same "wise-cracking, smartass" with excellent delivery. One thing is that this game is way to short to be $40. Get it on sale for $10 like I did.

One thing I'm finding consistently annoying with the remakes is the dynamic/RnG health that enemies appear to have. I really do miss the old days of knowing that a head shot meant something OR explosives were really powerful. Resident Evil 3 is an absolutely fantastic game that delivers on every level. From the intense and pulse-pounding action to the stunning visuals and immersive sound design, this game is a masterpiece of survival horror.

The controls are tight and responsive, making it easy to navigate the game's environments and take down the hordes of terrifying enemies. The game also features a wide variety of weapons and upgrades, allowing you to customize your playstyle and approach each encounter in your own unique way.

Overall, I can't recommend Resident Evil 3 enough. If you're a fan of survival horror games, or just looking for a thrilling and immersive gaming experience, this game is an absolute must-play.

So, long story short, this game is not as good as any of the other Resident Evil remakes. RE2, RE7 an RE Village are all far better games than this game in literally every way. Also, this game is literally just RE2 with two different characters and a few new small map areas as you essentially re-enter many of the same locations from RE2, like the Police Station. Additionally, this game has the shortest campaign of any Resident Evil remake so far, coming in at just under five hours to do a single playthrough while not skipping anything and completing all the side content. All of the other newer RE games have typically taken about 8-9 hours for a single playthrough. It is also worth noting that RE3 has no bonus content after you beat the game besides the usual, do this for unlimited ammo guns in your playthrough or unlock this to have this gun or tool at the start of your playthrough. Thus, it may just be me, but I personally have no desire to do a second playthrough of this game. Anyway, I did still enjoy playing the game and it's definitely worth it to purchase on either a bundle sale with another RE game or a 75% off or more sale. However, please don't pay the current full price for this game of $40 as it is definitely not worth that.

You know, if I had written this at launch or maybe even before RE4R came out I would have recommended this, but in a post-RE4R world, hell no this game is not worth more than like $10. For reference, I've 100%'d this game and haven't touched it since (and even then I took longer than most).

 I'll keep it brief, but the only really good parts of this game are the cut-scenes and characters, the gameplay is so chopped down from it's original PS1 version that it's not even funny. RE2R also had a lot of cut content, but this is taking it to a whole new level. It sucks because RE3R could have been amazing, and for one brief period in the city (the section the demo covers), it's really tense and fun. Being chased by a beefed up Nemesis is where the game shines, but it only really does it once and the PS1 version did it far better. Combat is fluid and engaging, being able to dodge-roll as Jill and punch as Carlos feels great, but it'll only last about 6 hours. Multiple difficulties are nice, but with barely any unlockables and such a short game it is kinda mute.

 Just buy RE4R, it's a game actually worth supporting, and play the original if you can, it is miles better than this half-baked "remake".
