Resident Evil 3 Remake is a solid game with a lot of great features, but it falls short of its predecessor, Resident Evil 2 Remake. The game's graphics and sound design are excellent, and the gameplay is fast-paced and exciting. However, the game's campaign is significantly shorter than Resident Evil 2 Remake, and some parts of the original game have been cut or changed.One of the best things about Resident Evil 3 Remake is its intense action sequences. The game features a dodge mechanic that allows players to avoid enemy attacks and counter-attack. The game's boss fights are also challenging and require careful planning and quick reflexes.However, the game's shorter length and lack of replay ability compared to Resident Evil 2 Remake are major drawbacks. Additionally, some fans have criticized the game's lack of certain key locations and enemies from the original game. In conclusion, while Resident Evil 3 Remake is a solid game with excellent graphics and exciting gameplay, it falls short of its predecessor in terms of content and replay ability. Fans of the series will still enjoy the game's intense action and challenging boss fights, but may feel disappointed by the game's shortened campaign and lack of certain elements from the original game! [h1]Resident Evil 3[/h1]

[i]Such a disappointing sequel to the perfect RE2[/i]

After having played RE2 back in 2019, that game was like, the perfect remake ever made. Everything was well made and considered. So you could say fans were expecting another killer sequel/remake for the RE3 iteration.

Alas, it is not the case. 

Granted, I never played the RE3 classic from 20 years ago but that one too wasn't much raved about back then. What is kind of irritating is the removal of game portions in this remake that were present in the classic.

The gameplay is more or so the same as RE2 and it works superb. Visuals, animation, sound, voice acting, music... all good!

However, the short nature (there's even an achievement to beat the game under 2 hours) of RE3 and the removal of portions that was included in the classic are quite underwhelming.

To be clear, this is NOT a bad game and NOT a bad Resident Evil game. RE6 still holds that candle of sh!t, being the worst of the series in my opinion (massive reuse of game assets everywhere, bad characters, mediocre story and being way too much action gun-ho, cowboy western style; which doesn't make sense in a RE game).

Also, I'd like to note that the UltraWide Monitor support is 100% well made and working.

[h1]RECOMMENDATION:[/h1]
[b]Again, not an awful game nor sequel but not the best either. I do recommend RE3 for the fans and on sale.[/b]

[i]And now, with the imminent release of the RE4 Remake coming out in a day, I can't wait to play that game! 

I can just say that yeah, BRING ON THE REMAKES!
Heck, why not remake the 5 and 6 while at it![/i]

RESIDENT EVIL 3 is... underwhelming.
After I finished RESIDENT EVIL 2, one thing I mentioned was that the game was shorter than the others I have played.
It was around 9 hours where the rest I've played finish off around 12, but I didn't claim that as a flaw as RE2 more than made up for it with numerous things. Plus the fact that there is two stories in RE2, that's basically double the playtime!

RE3 is... even shorter than RE2. When I say even, I mean around 6 hours shorter, at least in my playthrough.
My total play time (time just having the game open at all, & accumulates over every run) was around 5 hours & 30 minutes.
My actual run time (clear time as the game puts it) was barely over 3 hours & 30 minutes. That's ridiculous! I've never played the original RESIDENT EVIL 3: NEMESIS, but even I was disappointed with this game. Many people I see expressing their disappointment usually are players of the original game, but I am not. The game is unreasonably short, and although I've never experienced any of it myself, it cut a lot of content from the original game for seemingly no reason.

Not to mention, considering this game's big bad is NEMESIS himself, he only appears in scripted events for some reason! He appears unscripted about one time if I recall correctly, and that's terrible! I don't know how he was in the original game, but I seriously doubt he was only in scripted events. RE2 contained Mr. X, and he was constantly moving around. You could hear his footsteps getting closer all the time, making you feel terror as you attempt to do the tasks around the RPD. I don't know why RE3 refused to do this with Nemesis, but it makes no sense and only adds to the disappointment.

RE3's gameplay isn't bad, it's honestly really fun. It basically shares the same mechanics as RE2, but with an added roll move for Jill which is a really fun mechanic, especially when maneuvering around Nemesis.

Another flaw to note: this game's audio is terrible. Usually in voice acting, it's clear the microphone was not good and every line tends to sound a bit muffled. This becomes extremely clear at the very end of the game. Trust me, you'll know what I'm talking about.

Out of the now 5 games in the RE Franchise that I have played, this one is extremely disappointing. I've played 7, 8 Village, 1, 2 and now 3. 
So far, this game is probably at the bottom of my list out of these 5. The rest were great in their own ways, and while this one is still decent, it's not on the same level. It's really disappointing, even as a new player who never got to experience the original.

Capcom really went all out with the RE2 Remake, and it's clear they didn't do the same for this one. I feel really bad for those of you out there who played the original RE3:NEMESIS, as I know all of you were let down.
No matter the fun I had with RE3, there is no doubt I am left with some irritating disappointment.

[h1] RESIDENT EVIL [/h1]

The Resident Evil franchise, a household name these days, set the gold standard for survival horror back in the day alongside its main competitor, Silent Hill. As a result, with such a legacy come great expectations and with the franchise finally back on the right path, post-RE6, what better way to excite and wow fans than by remaking one of the most iconic entries in the series.

[h2] REMAKING NEMESIS [/h2]

Following in the footsteps of the fantastic Resident Evil 2 remake, RE3 does away with the top-down perspective for a much more comfortable and atmospheric over the shoulder view. 
It still utilizes the RE Engine that was originally shipped with RE7 so in the visual department it's an absolute feast, especially here where the environment feels much more varied than the last remake. 
Gunplay is still extremely solid, although some weapons are somewhat underpowered despite their appearance, and great care has been given to the sound once again with meaty sound effects and catchy tunes. 
Exploration is a big aspect of the game ,as is a tradition in the series, meaning you will often run out of supplies, forcing you to scavenge around the levels which are quite well designed although admittedly not as impressive as RE2's in terms of ambition and scope. Also big props for the quality-of-life improvements ported here from RE2, like the game showing when it's safe to discard a key item or when you are done exploring an area. 
That's a comment that comes up quite frequently in fact when discussing this remake; it does a lot of things well just not as well as the last one, the tyrant stalking you being one of the many examples to be brought up as this time around the titular Nemesis is reserved mostly for cutscenes and scripted sequences, but it's still a great spook when the lad shows up. There's much more banter and dialogue between the characters with more screentime given to the sidecast in this one, compared to RE2's mostly cheesy back-and-forths between Leon and Claire which led to nowhere. Overall, there was clearly a bigger focus on story and characters, a lovely change from the drab storytelling we saw previously.

[h3] CONCLUSION [/h3]

Now, while i personally never got the chance to enjoy the original, it has to be mentioned that many sequences from the classic game were completely cut and certain mechanics were also axed from the gameplay department. For first time players like myself ,however, it isn't that noticeable as the whole experience feels very well interconnected with a clear beginning, middle and satisfying conclusion to a truly fun remake of a survival horror masterpiece.

I will say that I never played the original RE3, so I can't really comment on the story/location/puzzle changes. The story moves along at a fast pace, again almost too fast - so I can agree with others in saying a larger game with some better pacing would have gone a long way to make this great game even better.

Overall another great addition to the stellar Resident Evil remakes.

Another great remaster for the series, I didn't have too many of the issues with the game like some of the die hard fans of the IP seemed to experience.

I thought it was pretty much an extension of the previous remake with a couple of nice little quality of life changes that made the game-play a little more seamless. The most notable two (at least for me) being the addition of a dodge function which I was dying (sometimes literally) for to be included in RE2R, and another smaller change being certain inventory management aspects such as not having to go into the inventory EVERY time you pick up an item. Small things, but frequent things.

Other aspects of the game however seem to have regressed, for some reason you can no longer break out of an attack with your knife or any grenades you might have laying around in your inventory.

A lot of the criticism seems to be directed at the length of the game. Whilst I largely agree, I think I have an unpopular opinion by saying that there isn't that much less content, maybe a few hours, than the previous game. I think RE2R does a better job of making you think there's more content than there actually is by splitting it up into 4 "individual" playthroughs which in reality differ by about 10% each between them. 

Resident Evil 3 is a singular story which only changes in difficulty. Despite this, although I enjoyed my first playthrough of 2 more so than 3, subsequent playthroughs of 3 are much more enjoyable as they're packed with more action and combat rather than puzzles which are something that aren't as fun to replay! I think this installation drags on a lot less and acknowledges its length correctly and I found that I had finished it with all the achievements just before it got stale rather than after, like it was beginning to after 30 hours of RE2.

I'd say if you liked RE2, or even if you're completely new to the Resident Evil universe pick it up! It's a fun little adventure and plays quite smoothly. But get it on sale! I wouldn't pay more than the £8 it costs on sale. Though it is a great game, it's a short one and therefore doesn't justify its £35 base price.

Capcom has done great with the latest remakes: They mantain fidelity to the original while being a complete rework and man, they look gorgeous. This RE3 remake is the best way to experience the game for sure.
And for the game itself, it is the first mistep on the saga, with the old Capcom moving more and more on the action part and reducing the puzzles and the horror setting that made its predecessor one of the most iconic games of all times. This is where they started thinking that puttin a missile launcher on a zombie is a great choice and from here it escalated quickly until they kind of came back to the origins on RE 7.
On RE3 Nemesis, all the effort has moved to action and pressing the player: There are more bullets, more zombies and of course there is Nemesis chasing you in its 3500 different forms and making you run. It is a good game, but not the best one on the saga. Anyway, at this point this one is part of the story of the videogames so you should play it if you did not already.

Half-decent game, terrible Resident Evil game. Lemme preface this by saying I absolutely love Resident Evil 3: Nemesis and have probably put more time into it than any reasonably sane person should, and after running through this...this just ain't it, chief.

RE3: Nemesis had some fantastic elements to it. It was the first game in the franchise to utilize a dodge and counter mechanic, which was fantastic! Granted, it didn't work very well and was difficult to get the hang of, but once you'd get the hang of it fighting Nemesis got really fun, really fast. Being able to explore Raccoon City at your own pace was fantastic, and sure, some of the backtracking could get tedious, but it was among the best horror games in its day. This is like a really low effort reboot. Most of the iconic locations don't even appear, the sequence of events is all mixed up, Jill doesn't even really act like Jill, and what were they even thinking with that Nemesis redesign?! They went from a genuinely intimidating boss to Crooked Nose McGee over here. Bad decisions all around. It was also disappointingly short, and the only really good elements to this remake were the Hunter Alpha redesigns and the pale heads. I don't even want to talk about the Hunter Gammas, that was too strange.

After they did such an amazing job with RE2's remake, I'm still bewildered as to how they went so far wrong with this one. There are next to no puzzles. The Clock Tower was cut completely, along with 50% of the total game if not more. Brad's death in the original had a purpose, here it's just lazy writing. The entire game can be summed up as lazy writing. Take notes, this is NOT how you design a good remake. As a Resident Evil fan, I'm disappointed beyond measure. Really the only thing they DID get right was fixing the dodge mechanic, but Resident Evil 3 should not be a game you can easily run start to finish in under an hour.

Only get this on sale because that's the only way it's even remotely worth it. Though even that's debatable.

The core gameplay is just like the RE2 remake, which is a good game. However, there are many things that make this game a nuisance. 

The game switches periodically between two main characters: Jill and Carlos. While playing as Jill, I felt that my inventory space was constantly too limited. I know that's part of the genre but I don't feel like it was executed well. In later parts of the game, I was constantly running back and forth to the storage box. It just felt like the game was giving me things I didn't really need but I hoarded them anyway because who knows when they might come in useful.

While playing as Jill, you are also frequently pursued by the Nemesis. He's just an unkillable annoyance. There are some games that are based around this kind of mechanic and RE games have adopted it on occasion (RE7, 8 and the RE2 remake) but those are much better designed. Luring the Nemesis away from areas I wanted to explore was more difficult and getting anything done with him on top of me was out of the question.

I understand that the entire game is focused around this mechanic but it was much more annoying than fun or scary. When he wasn't bothering me in explorable areas, he would chase me down a linear path where I just had to keep moving forward. Those segments aren't tense or exciting. I know that if I just keep sprinting in the obvious direction, I'll be fine and I always was. These sequences just felt like they were there to pad out the play time or force the player from one area to the other.

Speaking of padding out play time, there was lots of backtracking through areas. This is also one of those things that can be done well or poorly. Heck, the entire metroidvania genre is based around revisiting areas. In this game, sometimes it worked and sometimes it didn't. One segment of the game takes place in a hospital and you first play through it with Carlos and then with Jill. I had already made several passes over the area with Carlos and now I get to do it again with no difference. It's optional as it's just to get items that only Jill can access but the assumption is always that I might need that stuff later on so I'm compelled to do it.

I guess I have mixed feelings about it. I certainly feel conflicted about one segment of the game where the player revisits the police station from the RE2 remake. And I mean the SAME. It's the exact same map in the exact same engine. The location of enemies and items has changed but it's a copy/paste situation. On one hand, it's kind of cool that we are hitting up the same location from another game in this universe but on the other, it came off as lazy. 

I think a big part of that is the length of the game. It's short. It's really short. Look at the play times on other reviews here. They are commonly in the 4-10 hour range. That's not a coincidence. So when a game that short reuses a level from another game, it feels shady. 

There are other problems too. One enemy type, hunters I think they're called, have an instant kill attack and take a lot of shots to take down. You also fight them in close quarters and they love to jump around a lot. Thankfully hand grenades killed them in one hit but those don't exactly grow on trees. 

These enemies would be more manageable if the dodge mechanic wasn't so touch and go. Sometimes it works wonderfully and it feels great. Other times it just feels frustrating. I get the feeling that some enemy attacks weren't tested very thoroughly with the dodge in mind. 

There are some other minor points but what it comes down to is that this very much feels like it was made by the Resident Evil B team and as a quick cash grab at that. Compared to something like the Dead Space remake that recently came out, RE3 isn't even close. 

On sale for $15 or less, it's great. A bit frustrating but there's definitely some good old over-the-shoulder horror action. Anything more than that feels like a rip off to me.

I think this game is a step back from the original in almost every conceivable way aside from presentation. It's been awhile since I've played 3 classic, but one of the things that really stuck out to me about that game was the sheer amount of content available, and the pretty decent length for an RE game. You certainly got your money's worth if you bought 3 back in the day, and this is the inverse of that. Entire sections of the original are completely absent from this version. For example, a substantial 2-3 hour arc of the original has been consolidated into a 5-10 minute cutscene. It feels like this was supposed to be a dlc for re2 remake that some suit at Capcom decided to turn into a full price release. The repeated attempts from Capcom to validate shit like this with terrible multiplayer spinoffs only rubs salt in the wound. 

And just to clarify; I feel like this game is a blemish rather than indicative of the overall quality of the remakes. The other remakes Capcom has done have been fantastic projects that have retained the spirit of the originals while being different enough experiences to not make the older games feel obsolete. This game does neither of those things. If you want to play RE3, stick to classic.

After had playing the Remake of Resident Evil 2, I saw that Resident Evil 3 Remake was on the horizon, so I waited patiently for this to release, since I enjoyed RE2 Remake that is.   Getting my hands on the Remake of RE3, I had to play straight away, and to my expectations, it was an amazing time!   Again, after seeing the visuals and character models upgrade from RE2 Remake, I knew this was gonna be even better!

Everything about Resident Evil 3 Remake was sooooo much better, but what wasn't very easy to control, and or learn was the dodging mechanic.   I never played the Original Re3 which was just called, Resident Evil Nemesis!  I heard that the dodging mechanic wasn't the best, which was done that way on purpose, so for the Remake, the Devs decided to keep the nostalgic aspect of it, and implement the dodging, but make it super freaking awkward to use!  

Nemesis on the other hand, was as well, changed.   If you know of the OG Nemesis, you'll definitely notice the changes, but I still think it was well done.  People other than myself were disappointed that Nemesis at his second phase was changed to look more like a dog, rather than his Stage where he would just have several Tentacles swirling around him.  As well as his Final Phase was changed too, but again, STILL a great experience overall.

Carlos, this guy, this freaking guy!  From his Chad like appearance, to his shaggy hairdo, some people were all over him like Hot cakes, and others were like, %$#?!?!?!?!? Aight, simmer down, his change isn't even that bad, it's actually better in my opinion, but luckily the Devs introduced DLC that gives you Carlos, and Jill's Classic outfits, but if you want the TRUE classic outfits, Nexusmods is just one click away, lol!

I thought the ending to this Remake of 3 was Wow, Jill is such a Bad ass!  "Y'know what? This is the last F%$#ing Time!"  That line gave me chills!  Jill has had enough of Nemesis's BS!  I don't blame her, being chased the whole game, gosh, I'd be like, and this time, "STAY DEAD!"

Gave deserves a 10/10 ranking, but it didn't get that from TONS of cut content, it's actually a shame.  I give it a 8/10 just my personal opinion, but that's just me cause I like these Remakes, they just look so good!

I can understand why so many were disappointed with RE3 when it was released, but I think this game is fine. Yeah, there are quite a few set pieces and the game lacks the backtracking and puzzles of Resident Evil. Yet the core gameplay is still as tight as ever and even improved upon from RE2 with the dodge mechanic making it's return from the original RE3. Everything from the soundtrack, presentation, cutscenes, and sound design is great.  Yes, the game is short and it's not really a bad thing since it encourages you to play the game again on higher difficulties to challenge yourself. It also makes it less of a slog when you're replaying to do challenges (no healing, item box, etc.) since there's no moment in the game where it feels annoying to get through (other than the semi-lengthy opening). What's disappointing is the lack of extra content compared to RE2 and even older RE titles. It would have been great to have mercenaries and maybe even a short side mode where you play as Nikolai fucking shit up. It's not one of the best RE titles, but it's still pretty fun and enjoyable to play through.

A solid remake with some issues here and there.
The Story is pretty average but it at least gives a decent enough job as to progress the game forward in the way that it does. The characters are also just fine. Jill is decent enough to play as with Carlos being a bit more enjoyable due to his personality being both serious while able to throw a joke here and there. The villain of this game kinda feels like "generic evil Russian" with their goal being about money, but still does an alright job. The coolest character in the game is of course Nemesis which it being this unstoppable force that will do anything to get the job done and feels like an actual threat to Jill. 
The Setting of Raccoon City is really enjoyable to play through with every environment feeling like it has gone through hell and is infested with the undead. From the streets to the underground lab, every location you venture through does a great job at creating a perfect environment. 
Visually, its impressive. Performance was solid throughout my playtime and i had not encountered any bugs or glitches. Art Direction is also on point with it following in the same footsteps that RE2 remake went with. 
Sound and Audio are pretty good with it again following the same queues that the previous remake went with. 
In terms of gameplay, it's more of the same with some little things added on. If you have played the RE2 remake, you'll feel right at home with it being exactly the same when it comes to movement, gun play and inventory. One of the new things that have been added was the dodge/parry ability you can perform that can really help you out in a tough situation. The enemies are also pretty similar with the zombies well.. being the same since the last game, however there are new additions that do switch things up with the way players will approach the game. Nemesis itself is also a really nice challenge for the player with it acting like the Tyrant did in RE2 whereas he cannot be killed, but his abilities differ from Mr X as Nemesis with run at you and even grab you from long distances which can put you in a tough situation. The boss fights are really well done with each fight you have against Nemesis being different and tougher than the last one due to them evolving and becoming more powerful.  
Finally, there are some things that i feel that hold the game back from being as great as the previous remake. First of all, this isn't the full RE3. Instead (for some reason) this game is only a portion of what the original RE3 had to offer which i find confusing as to why they wouldn't go all the way out to give fans a full game and charging a £33 price tag on it. It may not be a full price, but this is still way too much for a 5 hour game (if even). One nit pick i had with the game was the way it overloads you with ammo to the point where it doesn't become an issue whereas RE2 made ammo sparse and forced the player to think carefully with how they would use that resource which was a really fun and challenging way to engage the player. The last nit pick i think i have with the game is the fact that it can be annoying when trying to dodge/parry enemies as sometimes it could be an insta death if done in a certain direction. 
Overall, Resident Evil 3 follows the remake trail quite nicely even with an alright story, but i would recommend getting this game on a discount as i don't agree that a 5 hour experience is worth that much money and the fact that it isn't the full story of the original.

I really, really wanted this game to be another grand slam like the RE2 remake. Unfortunately, it falls quite flat in comparison, and is a bit of a disappointment overall.

The RE2 remake was a masterpiece both as its own game, and as a faithful recreation of the original Resident Evil 2. It brought the older fans back and rallied all kinds of new ones as well. It combined amazing graphics, audio, and solid gameplay together into one awesome survival-horror themed package. It had different characters to pick from, each offering the player different perspectives to see the story with as they venture into the depths of hell in Raccoon City. There was a variety of game modes that injected a bunch of fresh content into the game, greatly enhancing replay value..

Blah blah.. point is, that game was amazing. The RE3 remake, on the other hand, is not.

The RE3 remake comes up short even in comparison to the original RE3 - only surpassing it in terms of visuals and sound. Everything else seems to be either pretty lackluster, or completely missing. Sure, the environments are nice to look at, but they offer very little to encourage exploration. For example, there are almost no puzzles in the game this time around. You can turn your brain completely off as you trudge your way through this bland hallway simulator, blowing away one zombie after another. 

Yeah, don't be fooled into thinking this is gonna be another blood-pumping, nail-biting, survival-horror epic just because you've played the other games. This is a generic zombie shooter at best, and there ain't sweet fuck all to be afraid of here. In the original RE3, Nemesis was one scary ass mofo that kept you on your toes all through the game (like Mr. X in RE2). The new Nemesis feels like a step backwards in both aesthetic design and gameplay function. He has been reduced to a mere annoyance that shows up for a few different story triggers, and gets stomped far too easily.

The story and characters are mostly what you remember from the original RE3, keeping it simple like before. The story starts with Jill getting attacked and chased by the Nemesis monster (which will continue to happen through the game). In an effort to reach safety, she encounters a few folks along the way and ultimately teams up with some umbrella mercenaries. The story becomes about securing the vaccine to the zombie virus and potentially saving Raccoon City, while trying not to get killed by Nemesis in the process. It's a simple plot with simple, boring, one-dimensional characters that don't develop in any real way. Carlos appeared to be the only semi-interesting character, whereas our protagonist Jill Valentine and the main antagonist were about as entertaining as white paint.

Before you know it, the journey comes to an end after like 5-6 hours. Again, where RE2 had lots of replay value.. this has almost none. Hooray, an item shop that lets you start with some basic items. But where are the extra game modes? Where are the alternate story paths? Where are the big decisions and multiple endings from the original? None of that exists here. There is almost no reason to play through this again. 

It just feels so half-assed. Could have been amazing.. what a shame.

Update: 

I did go back and play through this again, giving the game another chance.. but damn, what a waste of time and energy that was. It was just as painfully boring and linear as the first run through. There is absolutely no replay value here.

Additionally, I have since gone back to the original RE3: Nemesis for a playthrough. I wanted to see if it's as good as I remember, or if I was being biased due to nostalgia. Turns out that the original RE3 was even better than I remembered. Seriously, it's so much better than this garbage remake in almost every single way (except graphics and voice acting, obviously, but those are the least important parts of a game anyway). 

So yeah, skip this trash and save your cash! Or play the original RE3 instead :)

[h1]Resident Evil 3 (2020)[/h1]

[i]Resident Evil 3[/i], the great remake that could have been. I was one of the fools who pre-ordered this game on PS4 thinking it was going to be bigger than RE2R. For someone who holds RE3 Nemesis as one of my top RE games, I have a lot to say here.

To make things clear: as an action horror game, it's [b]okay[/b]; there are issues here and there but it works about 80% of the time at least. As a Resident Evil game AND a Resident Evil remake, it's pretty terrible. There are a couple of ways to tackle this game so I'll be reviewing it from the perspective of one who's grown up playing the original 1999 game.

That being said, this is probably my least favorite RE game and I didn't have that much more fun outside of my first playthrough.

[u]Story + Characters (Possible Spoilers!)[/u]

[spoiler]Most people will mention a lot about how improved the storyline is in the remake compared to RE3 Nemesis and I can see why: it's a lot more focused and streamlined. The plot for RE3R is almost like the original plot, except there's a plotline switch that focuses from escaping the city to getting the vaccine to stop the missile strike from blowing up... Raccoon City?[/spoiler]

[spoiler]The issue I have with this story is that, halfway, it goes absolutely nowhere. Jill makes the vaccine to "save the city" and the vaccine gets destroyed anyway (Jill couldn't care less about RC at the end). Also, aside from other reasons, Jill already has the T-virus antibodies from being cured so this plotline with the vaccine was pointless.[/spoiler]

[spoiler]It's like the RE3R team read a synopsis of the RE3 plot and decided it needed a human main antagonist to show that, "oh, it's not the monsters that are actual evil, it's human greed that's actual evil" except the original already showed these points much better without Nicholai being such a blatant villain with actual subtlety.[/spoiler]

[spoiler]As for the characters, almost everyone in this game has been dumbed down to a certain degree. Jill is snobby and acts way too hard to be a badass, Nicholai may as well be wearing a big white mustache to twirl whenever he's going to do something evil, Mikhail's despair over the loss of his subordinates under him is replaced by a generic disgruntled leader character, Dario is turned from a survivor struck with overwhelming grief over his daughter's death to a complete noodle of an idiot, and Nemesis is turned into an incompetent goofball that only tosses Jill around even when he's got her dead to rights. The only characters who improved from the original were Tyrell and Carlos who is by far the best character out of everyone; anyone who plays this game will LOVE Carlos.[/spoiler]

[u]Gameplay[/u]

This game is [b]short[/b]. That could be confusing considering that most RE games are short, but RE3R is one of the shortest Resident Evil games I've ever played due to the fact that it's the [i]most[/i] linear RE game yet. The reason for why this game can be completed so quickly is that there's not really much to explore compared to other RE games; you never have to backtrack that much because what you leave behind is relatively insignificant and you never have to go back to places for more puzzle solving. My first run was a little under three hours on PS4 and I explored as much as I could.

Given that the gameplay is derived from RE2R, it's still solid. Aiming and shooting feels good, controls are responsive, dodging is fun to do but is situational because enemies will sometimes rush you down from behind which makes dodging based on luck at that point. However, that's basically all there is to say that is good about the gameplay because the pacing that this game goes at does not work with the mechanics. 

Many new enemies you meet are either long ranged or agile which results in you trying to spin your camera to see where they're at and attempting to dodge them. They also range from being insignificant to defeat or being outright drivel. Ne-α Parasites can hit you from nearly across an entire room, Drain Deimos are relegated to one section and are never seen again, Hunter Gammas are almost free enemies considering that one shotgun blast to their mouths stuns them and one Flame Round will kill them, Pale Heads are lazily reused from RE2R's Ghost Survivors, and Hunter Betas are armored and can now randomly one-shot you at ANY condition of health with almost no warning. Dispatching enemies is easy because the game will give you the resources right next to the enemy that is weak to it ([spoiler]example, the Sewer section[/spoiler]) and you are given so much ammo in this game even on harder difficulties.

Nemesis T-Type is the titular enemy that made RE3 Nemesis as memorable as it was. Although he's much stronger than any enemy you will encounter, compared to his original, he is an absolute joke. Mind you, this was basically Umbrella's peak tyrant who could tank 10 Freeze Rounds. take two Rocket Launcher missiles, three Red Barrels, and would still come after you 11 times in the original AND follow you in most areas of the Raccoon City streets. In the Remake, up to Hardcore difficulty, a single Hand Grenade or Red Barrel can down him the fastest. Nemesis only ever truly stalks you in the Downtown area once ([spoiler]after the Power Station[/spoiler]). For him to be anywhere as tough, you basically have to amp up the difficulty to the point where his attack patterns become unfair ([spoiler]final boss, anyone?[/spoiler]).

There is no reason to think about item management at all. There are few key items that are used to progress forward and those that you do get are quickly / twice used (at most) to progress because it's so obvious where to use them. Puzzles are laughably easy to complete (with one puzzle at the end requiring a tiny bit of thought) and are almost non-existent; most "puzzles" that require you to progress will simply be installing key items, unlocking doors, or turning on switches.

It's never a good sign when there are challenges in a Resident Evil game that make you grind hundreds of kills in a series that EMPHASIZES on saving resources, running past a majority of enemies, and killing only what you're required to especially in an action horror game as short as this one. After beating the game, you're left with playing the game on harder difficulties and completing records to unlock rewards, but the replay value is short; I was able to 100% the game within a [b]day and a half[/b].

[u]Graphics & Sound[/u]

I will admit at least that the graphics on RE3R are as beautiful as usual for a game that uses the RE engine. However, I couldn't help but feel that RE2R had much better use of shadows and gore to emphasize the horror aspect and rarely was I ever tense playing this game. Many of the character designs are great; I liked Carlos' design the best and Jill's design is good enough for people to make mods for her.

The sound effects for the guns, explosions, and the chaos of the city are decent as well. Nothing sounded out of place or as if I was shooting out anything weaker or stronger than what the gun looked like.

[u]Conclusion[/u]

Like everyone else mentions, there's an insane amount of cut OG content. In short, about 70% of RE3 has either been changed or outright cut from the remake. To name a few: no Enhanced Ammo, no Clock Tower, no Park, no Cemetery, no Incineration Disposal Plant, no Grave Diggers or Brain Suckers, no complex mixing of Gunpowders and Grenades, no Nemesis-dropped weapons like the STI EAGLE.

It's a damn shame because newer fans will never know how much better this game could have been. Such aspects matter if taking them out removes a lot of depth from the remake and given how easy it is to complete this game in under an hour without speedrun strats, it only goes to show. I would only buy this game on discount and would recommend to RE fans just so you can say you've played it.

My fourth entry into the resident evil play through chronologically, I will be comparing this to the previous titles of 0-2 and treat this as if the original never existed. On what is only available on Steam at the time.

The Good: 
I prefer Nemesis over Tyrant, Tyrant was the silent brood that stalked you, Nemesis on the other hand? He would yell "Stars" and it felt like his ENTIRE purpose was to see you dead, well, yes... BUT, it was a lot more intimidating than Tyrant's silent walk in his goofy ahh hat. I may be biased with Jill, but I love Jill and her love interest with Carlos was actually well written in my personal opinion. I like Jill, I like Carlos, simple as. Sound design and graphics are great as usual. Setting was more of what I wanted out of RE2, the actual city itself and it affected the people. RE2 you were basically either only in the police station or underground, I really wanted to see more of Raccoon city, this game delivered that. I like the more interactive cinematics that were not in the previous titles. I LOVED the hospital section of the game, hospitals are an untapped goldmine in the RE universe, I need more of it, I love the setting and the atmosphere, I want more. The concept art looked great for it too! Maybe I am biased with my love of outlast! Settings were amazing overall, I enjoyed. I like the nice connections this game has with RE2 with pre and post events of that game, it was nice how it connected.

The bad:
RE is known for puzzles and backtracking, this one isn't too on par with that tradition, it exists! but seemed a little poor? Or I am getting use to it since I am binge playing RE games! haha! 

The Ugly:
Honestly, I wanted to put this in a middle ground? I more have no opinion regarding it since i have not played the original but.... The timing of the game, I had a run about 3 hours, it is a short game. Not worth the price to RE standards. There is supposedly cut content compared to the original so that is kind of disappointing. I'm sure capcom has their reasoning. Sure it is a shorter game to RE standards, but it felt like ti did not overstay it's welcome, length felt just right for the story it was trying to tell so I won't hold it against them. 

Conclusion: 
It's a great game for what the story is trying to tell and despite it's flaws, I think it hold's up greatly in my eyes. Nothing too disappointing for me and I really enjoyed the characters and story. Final boss was fun IMO. I give it an 8.5/10

[h1] As a gamer I recommend it, as a resident evil fan I only feel disappointment :/  [/h1]

This game objectively is good/ ok-ish, but as a remake is really barebones and it lacks in so many ways in comparison with the original and with the remake of resident evil 2. I recommend people to buy it at a heavy discount but this is in no way a complete game, they decided to cut half of the game just to put a multiplayer mode call "RESISTANCE" that was already dead a month after release, Capcom keeps trying to make RE multiplayer games  with no idea of what people want, we want coop game, no call of duty or Dying light clones. Please stop, they ended up hurting the campaign just for the sake of it...

[u]  [b] The good stuff [/b] [/u] 

This game has good qualities to it, this is by no means a bad game (although it was a rip off at 60 dollars at launch so I didn't buy it at that price) so let's start. 

The voice acting is superb, specially Jill, I love seeing a "new game" with her as a protagonist again, I like her new design but I still like her old one a bit more but it's still great, although is sad to see is such a short game :/. Nemesis design is great too, and how racoon city looks is just breathtaking, gameplay is very similar to RE2 but is a bit faster thanks to Jill's new dodge technique. The game is overall fun and I liked it, there are certain story moments that are great but the more I look at it the cons start to pop up more than the pros sadly.

[u]  [b] The bad stuff: The game that it will never be [/b] [/u] 

The remake of this game cuts so many stuff from the original, no clocktower, no park, no exploration, no anticipation, almost no puzzles, no dismemberment system as RE2, and the list can go all day. RE3 remake is extremely linear, the game is filled with scripted moments that makes nemesis to not be a menace at all, in RE2 remake MR.X was a chasing menace made to kill every witness of the racoon city incident, chasing you across the RPD in such unexpected ways and it was terrifying. But in RE3 Nemesis only has 1 real persecutor segment and is stunned with a battery in the most lame way possible, the beast that is meant to kill all the STARS members to avoid spreading the information of the mansion incident, is now just a predictable enemy that doesn't chase you after the first 20 min  of the game.... this is not how is supposed to work and now makes sense why Nemesis is no longer on the title of the game.

The overall map of raccoon city is now limited to just 2 streets and like 3 hallways, this is supposed to be the Racoon city game, but the city segment is so short that is really sad, all the locations are there but they are just cameos  and references, so they are closed in one way or another as if it was a fan game instead of a AAA remake like RE2 was, and after this section nemesis won't chase you anymore because they rushed their "animal" form so quickly for the sake of action set pieces that is no longer menacing, he just becomes a boss everytime you see him :/. So the rocket launcher nemesis is basically limited to a 2 minute sequence... like why??? that is his signature  weapon and is now just a cameo for 5 seconds because is just a run segment so you don't even see him using it. So, going back to the map, now is just City => Sewers => Hospital => Lab and yeah RE2 only had 3.5 locations but all of them were connected via puzzles but in this one they are shorter, they are not connected, you just see them once.

They also completely eliminated the decision making of the original, making this 100% linear in level design and 100% linear in story too. Now you can't choose if you want to explore the city but you can't choose story elements either, so the replayability of this game is non existent. And it sucks because they touched the PTSD of Jill on the beginning of this game but just a little bit, and is such a miss opportunity because if they had included more nightmares and more story choices they could've made a really good exploration of her character, but after the intro she just becomes a bad ass character with no build up :(.

[u] [b] Conclusion [/b] [/u] 

I am negative overall but I actually enjoyed the game, but this game could've been such a masterpiece just as RE2 was, imagining a complete racoon city with interconnected puzzles with nemesis chasing you across all the city as MR.X did , making decisions in the game with multiple endings, giving STARS members more screen time and exploring how umbrella is chasing Jill and how she deals with it thanks to her PTSD and her lack of trust in others.  that is a game I imagined after finishing RE2 remake, and is obvious this game was not made by the same team. This was made by a different team at capcom and it really shows. The RE2 team is working on the RE4 remake so I am excited for that one. That's why I can't recommend it as an RE fan, Capcom gave this game, THE NEMESIS GAME, to a secondary group and took half of their resources to make a trash multiplayer game that was dead a week after release, the lack of time and love put in this proyect is shown if you compare it with RE2 or the original RE3. As a separate thing , yeah is good, is decent. But capcom just chased the easiest and laziest  way to make money, and it sucks this game will always be remembered as the game it will never be :'(.

While i can understand people being upset about the clocktower not making the final cut, i cant say the same for the park and the cemetary. The latter 2 being fairly small areas with little to them but crossover sections in the original. Anyways, i do believe that they could have easily snuck in the clocktower by just having nemesis show up like he does in the remake but then something happens and you run into the clocktower. So even story-wise that should have been no problem in the remake... oh well... maybe they ran out of time?

[b]People saying "This feels like RE6 and has too much action".[/b]
A: The devs did state multiple times that this recreation will have much more action than RE2 and as far as im concerned there where plenty of explosions and action in the original "RE3 Nemesis". Also, in no way does this feel like RE6... again people are just using excuses to crap on this game by comparing it to capcoms worst RE game, which is RE6. The combat is still very much the same as in RE2 Remake, as are the jump scares, tension, atmosphere and surprises!

[b]People saying "This should have been DLC"[/b]
A: I disagree. There is still enough on offer here to justify the price tag AND you get another game on top being "RE: Resistance".

[b]Conclusion:
Dont worry too much about all these people who are upset because the game isnt a 1:1 recreation of the original because lets face it, thats literally 90% of the complaints. Let's also not forget that Capcom wanted this game out in just over a year so i feel for the devs.[/b]

Anyways...with that out of the way lets get into the pros and cons:

[b]Pros:[/b]
----------
- More varied environments
- Ties up the original games plot holes well
- Realistic graphics
- Nemesis is relentless and will try to mess up your day in any way he can 
(RE2s Mr. X doent even hold a candle against him)
- Inventory management is done a bit better than in RE2 with quick stash on already picked up items

[b]Cons:[/b]
---------
- Explosive barrels make initial zombie encounters way too easy
- Soundtrack volume in safe rooms is way too low and the "remixed" save room soundtrack isnt as good as the original 
(why cant capcom give us the option for the original soundtrack like in RE2 Remake?)
- 1 or 2 questionable QTE's 
(i.e.: Jill crawling away with tentacle attached to her leg for nearly 30s)
- Sometimes its hard to tell if youre doing damage to nemesis in fights due to vague animations
- No Mercenaries mode
- Barely any puzzles and way too easy
- Some sections felt really short with less intricate level designs compared to the original game
(They should have just reused some of their outdoor/indoor assets to give each section a bit more length)

[b]Final thoughts:[/b]
---------------
Survival horror is still very much present in RE3 so dont let other reviews dissuade you on that! It's just that RE3 Remake has more variety and more action sprinkled on top, thats all.
There are still plenty of jump scares, tension, atmosphere and surprises throughout!

[b]Final Verdict:[/b]
--------------
8/10

Resident Evil 3 Remake is an undeniably good-looking game that falls short in a few categories but excels in some others. I haven't played the original title so I won't be making criticisms on certain aspects that have either been removed or expanded upon as I'm yet to experience the 1999 game for myself.

I wrapped up my first playthrough of the story in just under 5 hours, and I've played through it a few more times since, in order to obtain as many achievements and collectables as possible, totalling to 21 hours of playtime. 

Although the story is on the shorter side, I think the shop system that can be found in-game following your first completion of the story adds a level of replay ability that increases the value of the title and makes it easier if you are aiming for 100% as it lets you cut certain corners that would typically make the experience feel drawn out and just not as enjoyable upon a second playthrough.

Another thing I really enjoyed about this game is the amount of colour that can be found throughout raccoon city and how Capcom was able to make it feel as though the city was once a living, breathing entity where thousands of people once went about there everyday lives until all hell broke loose.

My main criticism with the game is the lack of bosses that you go up against throughout its duration. Unlike the resident evil 2 remake where you explore a plethora of different environments and have a boss fight that matches up with the zones theme. The only boss you face in this game is a variation of nemesis that is often reused at least once more. For instance, the clock tower fight where nemesis seems to be in an animal-like state is almost the exact same as the nemesis you face for the first time in the underground facility. 

Overall, I think that the resident evil 3 remake is a game that excels in several categories but also falls short in others. I would recommend waiting for it to go on sale as the total amount of playtime doesn't warrant a £35 price (roughly $40) but I still believe it is a title that you should check out at least once.

First off, Resident Evil 3: Nemesis (yas, the OG) is my most favorite RE game EVEEERRRR. Probably my most favorite game EVEEERRRR as well - so I really have a lot to say here. I lost count of my replays already -- replays when we still had PS1, replays during college, replays when I started working, heck, I even replayed it once more during the height of this pandemic just so I could feel "solace" from my childhood, so to speak.

It would be a lie if I said it wasn't the least bit disheartening to find out that a lot of the locations and puzzles were cut and this game would pass you by like the weekends. The other remakes were fine (at least to my standards) -- [b]so why must this happen to the one I love most?[/b]

However, I would also be lying if I said I did not enjoy the visual treat that it is, like how tremendously eyegasmic RE2R is. Jill is also my favorite RE character, and I love how she turned out in this highly-detailed, full-blown 3D model. I love the face model they chose for her, including the voice actress who brought her to life. I was judging her "new look" so hard when this was announced, but I am so happy to surprisingly be charmed instead come actual gameplay. AND SHOULD I EVEN MENTION HOW A MILLION TIMES HOTTER CARLOS IS NOW?!?!?!

Despite the lack of actual content (lol), the action has been explosive right off the bat -- and this was nothing less of a treat for me (as someone who stopped gaming for more than a decade). I can agree with most reviews that somehow, some way, this was very lazily produced as a lot of the content has been recycled from RE2R, but I couldn't help but recall that the original ones (at least the first 2-3 of the OG games) were also very interconnected and used the same locations and elements, so this did not bother me much at all, that this is something I could brush off as a mere happenstance due to the plot's demands, universe building, all that shebang.

Overall, the 3D art and design goodness, the unique cinematography whether in the cutscenes or interactive chase scenes, the semi-awkward but albeit laughable dialogues and one-liners (Carlos, I'm looking at you), the superb voice acting, and all the stress it gave me are what's making it worth recommending nevertheless. I can still reconnect with my younger self replaying RE3:N/B:TLE for the Nth time during my playthrough, and for me that is the most important part. [b]And yes, do NOT buy at full price.[/b] HAHA.

Short version: get it on sale.
Long?
The Gameplay:
It's a pretty standard, over-the-shoulder shooter. The gameplay is nearly identical to that of the RE2 Remake with some differences. These differences (like the knife taking up a weapon slot in your wheel) are pretty annoying coming right off RE2R, but it's still feels nice enough to play. The puzzles aren't too difficult, and it's fairly puzzle-lite considering it's a Resident Evil game. It's pretty much memory puzzles and mazes.
The good thing too is that (1) you can turn ray-tracing off and rest assured that the game is still going to look awesome and (2) it's flawless from a mechanical standpoint. As-in: no bugs. Ever. It's got that final polish and then some extra shine on top.
The Story:
Now, I won't talk about content cut from the original. I didn't play it. As far as I can tell, this trimmed all the fat without realizing that the fat gave it flavor. All the story content is there, but there's less impact, and the story is more linear overall.
That being said, the story is solid, but it's also a hard one to get wrong. Jill's primary goals are to escape RC and save as many innocents while she does it. Carlos isn't really given much of a story in this at all which is sad since it's his only appearance in the franchise and odd because he's the secondary protagonist. He's effectively a supportive himbo that pops up to remind you how awesome you are.
The ending is tragic with Raccoon City being destroyed (presumably with some people not evacuated yet) but lacks the impact due solely to how linear and resistant to deviation the storyline is. I mean, we're told people are still alive in RC, but we, the player, never see them. These citizens have no material presence to the player, and I like linear stories. It's saying a lot that I think that how linear and rigid it is is a flaw. Even if it was just a few encounters with people other than UBCS, it would have helped in the emotional impact.
Despite this, I like it so, so much. Jill is wonderful, Nemesis is my personal nemesis, and the fall of Raccoon City is horrifyingly sad particularly if you have the repertoire of the first, second, and prequel game under your belt. It's an intrinsic part of the original RE story.
The Problem:
It is very easy to complete this game in an hour and a half. I have, and I don't speedrun. Ever. My first playthough took just over three solely because I took my time and got super turned around. That means that I would literally bleeding minimum wage if I bought it at the 2022 full price. Luckily, I bought it on sale, and I still kind of feel like the playtime hasn't warranted the price. If you aren't 100% into the game and know you'll replay it, this might not be the best game to buy. Luckily, I do really like the game and replay it a lot. It's a nice game night. Something simple that you can play in one sitting.
And Resistance just seems like an attempt to pad out the price. Particularly with the new RE:Verse on the field.
So if you nab it on a wicked sale? It's a good choice. Otherwise, you'll get more playtime-to-price out of RE2R and the (at the time) upcoming RE4R.
And gosh, I hate to leave it like this. It feels like I'm saying don't buy it, but it's so very good, and I love it very much. the game by itself is great, the mechanics are good, the battle and fighting mechanics in my opinion are great and the graphics are gorgeous. The characters are interesting and have depth to them, I love the relationship between Jill and Carlos especially. The in-game shop is a great feature and definitely made me more inclined to replay on higher difficulties. I really love how they connected the game to RE2 in the RPD and how things were the same as they were there, the safes having the same codes and Carlos not opening the changing room locker but taking the note, leaving Claire/Leon to find what's inside instead. The attention to detail was really nice there. The horror element was really well done in certain areas, like the part where Jill has to restore the power in the beginning, always freaks me out. And the hospital section felt very eerie and especially scary the first time I played it.
As a remake I cant really say much since I didn't play the original, but I've watched reviews and they could definitely have done a lot of things better. The game feels pretty short honestly and they cut way more content than they should've. The fact that there's also only one ending even further contributes to the non replayability of the game unless you're a completionist. Compared to RE2 remake this completely fails at the remake part but it's still a good game. The beginning of the game feels very mid, it's just straight forward and just scripted sequences. 
In my experience playing on normal was the best option. The battles are pretty well leveled out and its all around a nice time. But then when you get to nightmare and inferno modes?? It's fine all the way up to the last bossfight. (the beginning is pretty difficult but still its managable) It's not even hard in an enjoyable way, you get stunlocked all the time and it's near impossible. Horrible design there as it seems like they ramped up the difficulty by 1000 compared to the rest of the game. The bossfights overall could be better, the second and third are basically mostly the same. The last one has a good premiss and design but it is far too easy on assisted-hardcore but then gets WAY TOO hard on nightmare and inferno. 

Over all I still love this game tho, it's one of my favourites and I really want to fully complete it. I've grown attached to the characters and story and it's just great.
If you plan on getting it then get it when it's on sale. :)

First things first, I DON'T hate this game. I actually had a relatively enjoyable time playing it, treating it as a pretty average, rather toneless experience, BUT. It just comes across as low effort disappointment. It lacks substance and feels so very simplified, guiding the player by hand like a baby through a very short content - ridiculously short for a game in this price range. Especially given the fact that most of its good qualities and mechanics come from RE2 Remake. It feels more like a DLC or a cash grab - as if someone thought, "hmm, we have most of the gameplay already figured out from RE2, let's just switch character models, throw in a few short locations, assemble some level art and switch difficulties to 5 instead of 3 and voila, the game!"
That's not ok. Such low effort games are NOT to be encouraged. And as someone who hasn't even played the original RE3, I can't even imagine the disappointment of the original fans who were looking for a remake of their beloved title. Throwing in metaphorical scraps to the players is just not alright and I refuse to accept such approach. 

But I've said that this game is "meh" to me even if I don't treat it like a RE remake. So to illustrate this fact with the very beginning, as this trend keeps up through most of the game.
The opening sequences of the game show me that - there is no real threat, almost ever, as the chase scene is scripted and only requires the player to literally press "W" for a fraction of a second, for a few times. I cannot feel any danger if all I need to do for survival is to press one button. I don't worry for Jill either, cause she easily shrugs off injuries that should have shattered her spine into pieces. Being thrown around, falling multiple floors in a car without even a seatbelt, getting pushed around in explosions - eh, just a day like any other. Let's just press a hand to what's left of our ribs and walk it off.
I also don't really fear the main antagonist, Nemesis, since he just literally barges into the opening without any foreword, gives a super easy-to-escape chase and proves not to be any threat, since scripted Jill is immortal and I would have to consciously try to make her fail.
So, besides showing that the player is not to be trusted to actually play a game, having things dumbed down, it also removes any fear factor from a horror game. A HORROR game. How am I to feel scared or cornered if I know my character is close to indestructible when the script requires it, my nemesis is not much of a threat most of the time (even when he appears in a regular gameplay, simply throwing ONE grenade makes him incapacitated. Lol). Not much to fear out there, is there?
This game has many more flaws (and few good qualities, but they ARE some, not to say no). But this review has gone on for long enough.
Just... stop cutting corners, cutting content and making the lowest effort possible, treating the players like idiots, happy to accept anything from you. Eh...

Even though this remake received backlash for its cut content from the original game and its linearity, it's still pretty good. The new Nemesis is relentless, but the game could have explored more of him before transforming him into the typical giant monster blob we see in almost all Resident Evil boss battles.
The game is more action-packed than RE2R, but despite the cut content, the narrative is well-written, and the characters, especially Jill and Carlos, are well-developed. Although it's a short game, it's still enjoyable and fun to play.

RE3 Remake has a bad reputation compared to the second game's remake. In addition to cutting a lot from the original, it was made by a "B-Team" who didn't quite "get" classic Resident Evil gameplay the way the RE2M team did, resulting in a game that struggles mechanically and tonally.

That being said, I still like it a lot. You might call it a guilty pleasure.

There's a lot to complain about. The new dodge mechanic invalidates classic RE resource management since you just dodge past many monsters who'd force a fight/flight choice before, but it doesn't work as a blastathon like RE4/Desd Space since the action is rarely as consistent. This is all exacerbated by the second third of the game going way overboard on linear set-pieces.

However, when it hits the mark, like in the exploration focused areas (streets, hospital), or some of the more inventive combat scenarios (brainsucker maze, sewers) it's intense and memorable

Overall it suffers most from not being able to decide what it wants to be. Is it smart survival horror or adrenaline pumping action-horror? Devs didn't seem to knoww. But the parts of the game that are inspired and creative still shine through and are worth experiencing despite all the balls it drops.

TL;DR: Hello you lazy people, nah I'm kidding. I can write a lot about a game I like for a review. So, Jill is hot and has some cool gameplay features. There's cut and added content. Carlos is obviously hot as well with DIFFERENT gameplay mechanics than Jill's. Best character in RE3 ngl. Nemesis is more scripted and linear than Mr X was which he was supposed to be an expansion of.  8/10.

Welp, I successfully completed this in one day. Can't say that it wasn't bad. Mind you I got this on sale for $15 AUD and the experiences are from Standard difficulty. None of that easy shit. No I won't do any like checkbox shit. You'll get an actual review from me. Also I compare a few things to RE2

(SPOILERS IN THIS PART ONLY RN!!!!)
Story: Being the new RE fan I am. I haven't played the original for RE3 but according to people there is cut out parts from the original. After completing this in 1 day, I can see that. Overall, they kept the premise of the story line. Zombie outbreak in Raccoon city. Nemesis is hunting down S.T.A.R.S members, Jill is one. She gets hunted down by Nemesis. Meets Carlos. Do a bunch of shit to get them out of the city. Now, not everything is cut content. The RPD part is new. I believe the original just had Carlos in the hospital saving Jill and that was the only time you played Carlos, now we have Carlos in RPD then in hospital saving Jill. Nice little add-on to the story there.

Gameplay: It's still RE. Shoot zombies, scavenge, craft, unlock stuff. Boss battles, all that. Coming from RE2 remake, Nemesis is a bit more scripted and linear than Mr X BUT he is more deadlier(More on that later). A lot of the typical shit is still recycled. Herbs, spray, zombie behaviour, dogs, lickers. All that shit but there are a few different zombie types that they added. First off, pale heads are in this. If you never did 'no way out' or 'runaway' ghost survivors in RE2 then you wouldn't know them. Basically, you need heavy ammo so the pistol that holds MAG ammo. They're annoying but one shot to the head if you have that gun. Shotguns work but they'll get up again soon. Hunters (I believe that's what they're called) of all types are new. The gamma ones in the sewers weren't too annoying, you learn their mechanics pretty easily and you just have to be effective with your attack on them. The betas or whatever ones you'll encounter in the hospitals are..... brutal to say the least. Acid rounds are effective on them but they have a shell on their head that you have to break through so fighting them in NEST was annoying but as Carlos it was fine cause he had the AR so just spray and pray motherfuckersssss.

Nemesis: As I have stated, Nemesis is a more scripted and linear Tyrant comapred to Mr X. He is also supposed to be an expansion on Mr X apparently. He doesn't stalk you and hunt you down like Mr X does. He moreso just comes out of nowhere and hunts you down. In saying this, he is WAYYYYYY fucking deadlier than Mr X. Stage 2 boss battle was rough but he can stun-lock you if you aren't dodging his attacks with the quickstep or roll (If you can pull it off.). This will fuck you as you are pretty likely to die quickly if he stun-locks you. The easiest way to get out of a stun-lock is desperately pressing space and going in a direction. You can only pray if that happens. So Nemesis is and sometimes can be busted. So what? Well, it may be the difference between dying or living so just fair warning. Otherwise, his boss battles are what they're supposed to be. Fun yet challenging, stage 2 boss battle had me going insane ngl.

Carlos: He's hot... what else can I say? jk, I have more to say. Despite his looks, Carlos is surprisingly easier than Jill is imo. He can punch or barge through zombies which can be useful in a one on one or Carlos vs Hunter moment. He's more resistant to damage than Jill is apparently and the horde mode felt very much like something I've seen before just changed to fit the situation. HMMMMMM. Anywho, Carlos is just a good character and his sections were easier than Jill's parts were.

Jill: Now, Jill's graphics and looks wise is hot and that's about all for her graphics. Now, gameplay for Jill is a bit weird. Coming from RE2, I forgot about the roll/quickstep mechanic but it is useful. You might just use it to get past zombies but right click/aim after rolling and you can get a slow-mo headshot on the zombie you rolled past. Pretty fucking epic right? Wait, there's more. She is the ONLY character in this game who can lockpick and cut the chains off to access new areas. I guess it's cause she is the character you use all the time but it is pretty fun. She also gets to use some fun guns and ANOTHER MINIGAME TO CREATE SOMETHING. But it is kind of fun to figure it out so good on you capcom recycling that Idea.

Conclusion: Do I think it's worth the full price? No, get this shit on sale because off sale is not worth it. Do I think it's a good game? Yes. I probably will play this over and over again. I do want to see how easy assisted mode is and eventually work my skill level up to do the hardest difficulty which is nightmare I think? I don't know man. If I have to give /10 rating, this game gets a solid 8/10 for me. Obviously cut content, recycled content like zombie behaviour and design, and a more scripted and linear Nemesis, does bring the game down in the ratings. But seeing as it is a 5/10 or over it does get my recomendation. Now gamers, go and enjoy this game while it's on sale. Otherwise, wait until another sale or if you DESPERATELY want it then get it off of sale.

[h1] Well after beating the game in a concerning little amount of time, i'm completely torn on whether or not to recommend.... [/h1]

[i] Pros [/i]

* Great looking graphics and thick horror atmosphere thanks to the RE Engie.
* Animations are nice and smooth, scripted events are really well animated, and fantastic facial captures and modeling.
* Voice acting and sound design are top notch which should be a given for a survival horror game.
* Music is great and heavily supports the current atmosphere you are in.
* Story still takes inspiration from the OG RE3 but is modernized with a cinematic feel.

[i] Cons [/i]

* Game is extremely short for a $60 price tag. My first run took little under 4 hours on Hardcore and not knowing what to do at all...
* Gore and some body physics downgraded. Less gore when you shoot Zombies and zombie's legs cannot be shot off like in RE2.
* Can have an extreme trial and error feel for first play throughs. this may be case by case but I would recommend having multiple saves at a time.
* Does not have much replayability which for an RE title is extremely disappointing. No 2nd runs like RE2, no side stories like RE2, and no extra fun game modes after completion.

This game is just straight up disappointing so many things within the game are just annoying. While this is called Resident Evil 3 it should just have been RE2 DLC since that's the amount of effort they put in the game. While the game does look really good along with a few new additions in terms of movement, weapons, and enemies. Most of the game is just reused assets that feel so close to the RE2 Remake that was released earlier. While Jill is the main character, she feels so annoying with her dialogue and actions towards other characters feels too hostile or weird given the situation. While Nemesis is the main villain of the game, he just feels like a nuisance just appearing out of nowhere and disappearing just as quickly. Along with Jill you also get to play as Carlos who gets to go through the police station along with the Hospital which is probably the best level in the game. He is such a better character from Jill as he is the only one trying to do good no matter the situation. The game is so short that you basically get the downtown as a level for like 20 minutes then after that you can’t access it. Just forced to go down linear levels with hardly any variation from what you have already seen before. With the Hospital being a decent level just a little later on just for the game to end basically 25 minutes later. There was a concern from myself when the lockpick was ready to be discarded despite still having 2 sections left in the game. Which made me feel like there was nothing really to explore, just in-game cutscenes you are forced to sit through and some pretty generic and annoying boss battles. On that topic the final boss fight on Nightmare and Inferno is just bullshit with it constantly going into combo moves where if you miss 1 dodge your dead. Including 1 move where it repeats it 7 times in a row where as mentioned you die alot. 3 hits in a row means your death so you basically have to be perfect just to beat it. Along with that there are bugs that could crash your game, 1 can happen sometimes before you complete Carlos’s 1st level. While the other occurs at the end of the train cutscene before it is supposed to load Carlo’s first level. This happened on my 1st run through as well as at least 10 times while playing the game on Inferno. Which really brought my overall opinion of this game even lower than it was before. While the game is harder on the tougher difficulties nothing really changes except some item placements and harder enemies. Which is a let down considering they at least you have improved it on harder difficulties. Even getting all the records is time consuming with many of them just involving you killing a certain number of enemies with various weapons or just the number of enemies killed overall to just pad the game until you get the better weapons from the shop. The shop is just unlocking cool weapons or items you can use my completing records which just makes it overall a chore to complete. I feel like this game had so much potential to be as good as the first 2 games despite their issues. Instead it is a hollow shell of a once good game but just falls flat in execution in many terms of gameplay and storytelling. Overall, I would give Resident Evil 3 a 2/10.

Resident Evil 3 is the remake to the 1999 game RE 3: Nemesis. Building on the remake of RE2, 3 uses the RE Engine to great effect making a photo realistic survival horror game that plays well and can be unnerving at times. I never played the original 1999 title but from what I have been told this is a poor remake of it. As someone that went into this game fresh I can assure anyone else new to it that it is not a bad game at all. 

RE3 takes the gameplay of 2 but makes it more action oriented just like what the original title did. Jill has access to more ammo, storage, and has a dodge roll mechanic similar to what RE6 introduced. It is an extremely fast paced title that can easily be finished in under 5 hours if you know what you are doing. This is the most unfortunate thing about it due to their apparently being cut levels/boss fights, and the fact that the titular Nemesis no longer appears randomly to stalk you throughout the game. Every time Nemesis appears it is a scripted fight and he can be dispatched if you have enough ammo and no how to confront him during these scenarios. It is by no means bad but it does lower the amount of tension the pursuer creates whenever he appears. The other unfortunate thing about 3 is that it is not a very replayable title like previous games in the past. There is a store that you can buy items post game for a next playthrough but it is not nearly as well thought out as previous titles. 

When it came out RE3 was slightly controversial due to the price point it came out and the lack of content it had. While that may be a valid criticism, in 2023 on sale it can be a very value based title for $5 if you are looking to play something that is horror themed and survival horror.

After reading many reviews of RE3, my expectations were exceptionally low for this remake. I am a huge fan of the series, however, so I decided to buy it while it was on sale.

I do get surprised by some reviews. There are things I disagree on. Here is what you can expect:
[b]Game length[/b]: expect 4-5 hours of gameplay your first run. The campaign omits many areas and puzzles from the original RE3 game. 
[b]Graphics[/b]: Very good! 
[b]Difficulty[/b]: as much as some areas could be made more difficult, others WILL offer you a bit of challenge. You WILL die. Several times. 
[b]Ammo[/b]: there is abundance of ammo and you probably won't experience the lingering stress of scarcity that we know and love from RE. 
[b]Backpedaling[/b]: the game is relatively linear for being a RE game, correct. But there IS definitely some optional backpedaling to acquire some upgrades.
[b]Replayability[/b]: you can play the campaign 2-3 times to try to beat your initial game time and complete some achievements. That was fun for me.
[b]Nemesis[/b]: encounters with Nemmy are short lived, yet I would argue that they can be intense sometimes. There is little randomness to his patterns of attack. I can see why this is disappointing for some. But he is still powerful, and will definitely be the reason for some frustration as he will kill you. 

I have now played through the campaign twice, and I think the game has recieved way too much negative critique. As long as you accept that the game is 4-5 hours of gameplay your first run, you will enjoy it. Again, I bought it on sale, so maybe that's why it doesn't bother me as much. Try to view it as a DLC campaign for RE2 and you are good to go. If you want to make it harder, play it on Hardcore.

Pros

2. The music and the atmosphere it creates. The music ties very well with each part of the game. In some parts it makes you feel safe and relieved, in other parts it creates the feel of urgency and in other parts it makes your poo touch your underwear. I even enjoyed the credits because I wanted to listen to the whole song.

4. Gameplay is fun. The whole "combine things to solve problems, manage your limited ammo and survive" is very addictive.

6. Jill is hot.

Cons
1. Overall, the opening level/sequence is down right laughable. 
- Incohesive behavior that contradicts the dialogue. e.g. "There is a monster chasing us."  he says. And after 15 seconds of just standing there and talking about it, he starts to casually walk away in slow-motion while scratching his head.
- Incohesive scripted set pieces. Monster literally got through the building wall, but then gets he/she/it (because is 2022) gets stopped with furniture.
- "Interactive" gameplay blended with the scripted scenes, I guess to make you feel one with the protagonist (?). In actuality it has the opposite effect - the opposite of immersion? Sorry, english is not my first language.  Anyway, the monster is chasing you, "Press W to watch the scripted scene". Car is not starting "press w to try and start the car". Press "W" to walk five steps, then you enter a scripted scene again.  That's just stupid, play the scripted scene already or let me play the game.
- Rescue helicopter blew up with no apparent reason

2. The combat mechanics, basically don't exist. I've seen reviews praising the dodging ability of Jill and the "shoving" ability of Carlos which I find immensely stupid. You mean to tell me that a trained police officer can't perform any combat move on weak zombies, other than dodging? Because I've seen her battling and surviving against Nemesis in the previous scripted scene. Also, Carlos's "shoving" ability is less useful than dodging on some occasions, but I guess special forces self defense training only consists of pushing and hammer-punching because dodging is for ..female cats -.-
