RE3 Remake uses the same RE Engine from the recent titles of the franchise which means a game with good graphics, nice visual effects and a solid voice acting, all condensed into a modern interface.

And that's it. That's almost all and every possible praisable stuff this game can get. Almost everything else is a tremendous disappointment, especially for the classic fanbase.

First of all, the game itself feels and looks more like a DLC from RE2 Remake and not like an original title since many different elements, from items to enemies and models to ambiences are literally reused in a way. 

The game fails to deliver a tense pace due to a laughable Nemesis whose new model can't compensate for the lack of a good challenge, combined with so many unnecessary cutscenes and missable encounters (including the usually bad boss battles) in-game that are easily solved while throwing a single grenade on him (an example of an absolute disregard for the terror that Nemesis should represent - he drops an item and pauses for a very long time, which is enough for you to kill the other enemies nearby, while collecting all the items scattered around and leaving the area, plus not being chased by him afterwards). If at least the Remake had some of the original good encounters, like the one inside the Raccoon P.D., when Nemesis jumps out of nowhere, breaking into a corridor after shattering a window, a moment that freezes your heart and gives you a sense of desperation and unpreparation, the Remake would've been so much better and well-considered by the players. But no, this kind of moment was stripped away and replaced with some cheap ones where you simply press an action button and concludes the scene, without having to think what to do or where to run. In the Remake, you have many scenarios of tranquility and calmness knowing that Nemesis won't be able to follow you properly or break through many rooms as it should. And speaking of action buttons that concludes some scenes, we don't even have those text boxes giving us the decision about to run or to fight Nemesis we previously had in the original game.

The general exploration was ruined in comparison to the original game due to the removal of puzzles (replaced with uninsteresting ones) and an unexplainable destruction of the original street map: whereas in the original game you could walk through different streets using the connections between them while having some options to get from point A to point B, always with a permanent sense of tension, the general areas on the remake are usually linear and without the same freedom to explore. To clarify this specific point, you pass through many classic places from the original game but you simply cannot visit them here ([spoiler]like the Stagla gas station[/spoiler]) like if they were only referenced to somehow but not really being part of the experience which ends up into a tremendous frustration. The number of areas that were removed from the original game alongside their respective puzzles is enormous.

The recreated personality of Jill is awful (and for many people, her recreated appearence too). Take Leon or Claire from the RE2 Remake for comparison: Leon as a rookie who haven't even had a single day on the academy and Claire as a girl looking for her missing older brother. Jill, by the time, had already fought against hordes of zombies and other monsters in RE1 while unscathed thus being a respected member of S.T.A.R.S Team Alpha (a special division of Raccoon P.D.) who survived all that terror and remained investigating the events soon after. And when you put these 3 characters from the Remakes side by side, Jill falls bland. She looks generic, unmemorable, naive (as seen from some decisions she takes) and unexperienced (even more than Leon and Claire, who are always trying to encourage themselves during RE2 Remake). Every other RE game co-starred by Jill itself have a much better Jill than this one, by default.

The replay value is absolutely non-existent, especially when compared to RE2 Remake and RE: Village (both titles using the same engine, as mentioned before). Since there are many places removed from the original game, there is little to nothing that makes you want to play this Remake again because the experience itself isn't memorable.

Capcom had a great opportunity to create an incredible and cherished remake, even more than RE 2, but instead has created a huge disappointment for much of its fanbase and showed how greedly rushed the Remake was.

RE3R has a bit of a weird reputation. My understanding is that it cut content and mechanics from the original game, creating a linear, streamlined experience that especially stung for the fanbase after the runaway success of RE2R. Now, the only survival horror games I've ever played are the three Resident Evil remakes, so I can't really comment on comparisons to RE3, but I can say that if you expect anything like the police station in RE2R, you will be disappointed. On its own merits though, I think this game rules.

I haven't played the original, but my understanding is that in RE2 Mr. X was a scripted encounter while in RE3 Nemesis stalked you (or seemed to stalk you via programming wizardry) throughout the game. In the remakes, these roles have been switched. Mr. X's thundering footsteps are fully ingrained within me. He's a constant ever-approaching threat, closing onto you as you scurry through the labyrinthine station. Nemesis meanwhile is solely a scripted enemy, appearing during certain story moments and for boss fights throughout the game. This could be disappointing if the scripted scenes were meh. Thankfully, they're all lovely. Nemesis is your guide through and the instigator of the total destruction of Raccoon City, smashing through walls as you run building to building trying to escape. That's the real joy of the game: watching Raccoon City burn. In RE2R, the police station was monumental. I got the feeling, running laps around it to open doors and solve puzzles, that it would last forever. Every block in RE3R by contrast is waiting to be turned to rubble. The methodical pace of RE2R is thus quickened in a more action-focused direction, and you don't stay in any given place for anywhere near as long as in RE2R. Nemesis is coming to blow it up, after all.

The story here is also...really good? Jill, who was a bit of a blank slate in REmake, is really efficiently established here as practically a war journalist. She's close to closing in on Umbrella when she's turned into a reluctant action hero after her entire apartment collapses. Something I noticed in RE2R is that when the writing team expands on the original game into new directions, their writing becomes very strong (e.g. Kendo, a heartbreaking interlude that's unique to the remake). Here they're given even more room to breathe, to their immense benefit. RE3R is a surprisingly nasty story, following Jill as she tries to save who she can, and find any way to hold Umbrella responsible for their crimes, all while running, shooting, and swearing her way through the city. The characters she meets are strongly established and there's plenty of twists as the conspiracy unravels. 

RE3R is more than a different game than RE2R: it's its negative image. This is apparent in its mechanical construction (compare Mr. X's and Nemesis' behaviors, which are a microcosm of the games as a whole) but extends to the thematic core. RE2R's story, for as dark as it got, is still a story about defeating the odds. The ending is downright saccharine as [spoiler]the protagonists was into the sunlight, smiling kid in tow, preserving the innocence of a future age[/spoiler]. By contrast RE3R is downright bleak, with various forces conspiring to derail Jill's efforts, and an ending [spoiler]that legitimately shocked me, as the vaccine's destruction rendered all of her efforts null[/spoiler]. A particular comparison I found interesting as I got to the end is that the motivations for one of RE3R's villains is very similar to those of a fan-favorite in RE2R. Under the warm light of the second remake, the character can find the goodness in themselves and do the right thing. Here, things are less kind. These games take place in the same time frame, sometimes even sharing locations, but they live in different worlds. Playing both games back-to-back, however, they interweave with other, creating a larger understanding of the city and the many forces that drove it (for good or for ill). 

I can understand wanting RE3R to take a different approach. But for what it is, and what it wants to be, it's a home run. RE3R feels like a fully realized version of itself, and for me that's the most I can ask from a game.

If you could give a 'mixed' rating to a game, I'd probably give one to RE3. It's shorter and more scripted than its predecessor and drops the ball completely when it comes to Nemesis, who is completely tame and unintimidating. Ironically enough, as he is supposed to be an upgrade on REmake 2's Mr. X, who was absolutely horrifying, especially the first time you met him.

What it comes down to is how mostly everything involving Nemesis - boss fights excepted - is either a cutscene or completely scripted. He doesn't free roam the area like X did, so there is no randomness to his movements. Mostly it's just laughably easy chase sequences that are more interested in being cinematic than fun or challenging. On more than one occasion, I escaped Nemesis by simply holding down the forward button.

The core gameplay remains good, however, so I can still recommend REmake 3 to anyone who was a fan of its predecessor. It's just a shame that instead of going bigger and better, they went smaller, shorter and more linear.

Unlike Mr X in RE2, Nemesis was supposed to be faster, stronger and smarter. And where you have Mr X stalking you in the entire RPD, Nemesis only stalks you for 5-10 minutes of the entire game, other than that it's all scripted and only boss fights. And to know that I don't have a better Mr X stalking me was so dissapointing. Other than scripted encounters, cutscenes were absolute joke. Nemesis had our protagonist Jill in his hands many times, only to throw her away or, get stopped by a bookshelf (3 minutes after he bursts into your apartment breaking walls mind you). Also you could take him down with a simple hand grenade in each counter like what the hell? We are talking about an absolute biological weapon here.

Cutscenes were so beautiful, but until the NEST, it was just cutscenes, I didn't feel like I'm playing a game at all. And if it wasn't for cutscenes, the game had so many scripted scenes at the begging were what you did didn't really matter, but you had to go through each time you play it because you couldn't skip them because they were not a cutscene. These were absolutely pointless! Also it was really boring and even more dissapointing after you figure out those are scripted.

But the worst part of the game is, in my opinion. It was too short. As you can see I have almost 7 hours into the game, and I finished the game 1.5 times (I was playing the hardcore and trying to get the unlockables but I got bored and dropped it off midway). There is also no replayability other than playing the same game in a more difficult mode.

TLDR; The game is not worth spending money, graphics are absolutely beautiful and Carlos is so hot, but the game is not adrenaline pumping enough for a horror-action game, and it's too short to spend actual money on it. Go check other Resident Evil games, they are done better.

Resident Evil 3 Remake was much anticipated after the successful RE 2 Remake that came out in 2019 so it's clear that this game had a lot of expectations, unfortunately RE2 was done by the original developers from Japan and RE3 Remake did another studio that underestimated their strength.
This game is great in some ways, but it cuts off what shouldn't even be cut off, given that when you look at what the original RE3 from 1999 looked like and this one won't fit a lot of things here, and it's true, since this game has been shortened so that it probably doesn't work anymore, and this is a mistake that has hit the player a lot, there are not nearly as many things as in the original part, and if they are so insignificant, or they are just for rewards. I was looking forward to it when I fought the underground worm, or when I decided whether to fight the Nemesis or not, but I didn't see these things and CAPCOM itself didn't even tell the players.
From another point of view, this game still sticks to the story from the original game and still tries to stick to what made this Resident Evil great, but as I said, after they cut so many things, this story in RE3 is definitely just a joke that isn't funny. Yes, the game retains its horror feel, but it's not as strong as in RE2, because they did practically only Ctrl + C and Ctrl + V with this game. They did RE2 Remake vol.2 just with a different story, taking away the opportunity to defend themselves, if you are caught by a zombie, and add that Nemesis is incredibly annoying and on a higher difficulty will not even let you get up, once you get to the ground, you can press Esc and load the last saved position, because he will not let you get up. Zombie design and their behavior have not changed since the last game, they all have the same model, animation, grab animation and scripts. I'm almost sorry they couldn't stick to what they were 21 years ago (I'm speaking for year 2020). They had a great plan and also a great design and everything looked so perfect, unfortunately it was not enough to convert a well-made game to Modern style. The whole game already seems like a horror for people who have never played a horror game, for me as a fan of RE games and also a fan of Horror, this RE game is really bad. But what I can't deny this part is shooting and action, this still sticks to what makes these Resident Evil games great and that's simple Gunplay. You can modify weapons, acquire new ones and expand your arsenal. This thing is something I can appreciate, but in terms of how the Resident Evil series should work, it's quite a small plus.
Of course, it's great to see Racoon City from a different angle than usual, because while we saw Racoon City it was just the Police Station and the Orphanage, in this game we look at the Metro, Power Plant, Metro Control Rooms, Umbrella Laboratory and also ... Sewers.
In terms of design, this part is really great, but again it's just a small plus. If you are a really big fan of the Resident Evil series so I can not recommend this game, perhaps only in Discount, but if you are new to this series and not interested in original, so I can recommend this game to you ... but also at a discount, because spending 40$ for a 6-hour story that you can finish in 2 hours is really a very bold price.  I think that 20$ is a more affordable price. For me, this game is really very bad and a bit pointless, the only thing this game saves is Jill herself, who is Arrogant and has no fear and really adds style to this game (Something like Dante).

This game is good. Not the best Resident Evil of the franchise, but you will have a good time playing Resident Evil 3 Remake.

First, I have to mention that I haven't played the original Resident Evil 3 that came out in 1999. So I will not feel any nostalgia about that game.

The things I want to say about Resident Evil 3 Remake are:

1- Nemesis is fun to fight but it feels underwhelming during the story. Nemesis is a menace just during the first section of the game. After that, you will only encounter him in boss fight arenas. I wish Nemesis had a longer "stalker" phase (such as Mr. X in RE2 or Lady Dimitrescu in RE8). Despite that, I enjoyed really enjoyed being chased by it in the streets, he is way more threatening than the other stalkers from the other Resident Evil games. The boss fights are fun too, maybe it is a little bit too easy to win against his stage 2.

2- The story is short. In my first playthrough, I beat the game in Standard difficulty  in 4 hours, while spending a lot of time exploring the streets and collecting every items. Resident Evil 3 Remake feels like it was being rushed during development. I want to explore more of Raccoon City's streets, sewers, and NEST 2.

3- Almost no puzzles. If I remember correctly, there's one easy puzzle at the beginning of the game when you have to select a valid route for the subway and then, nothing else.

4- It might be controversial but I think this Resident Evil has a good replay value. There are 5 different difficulty modes and the 2 hardest difficulties offers different enemies at different locations. There also are challenges that give you points to spend after completing them. These points can be exchanged for new weapons, more health, more inventory slots, infinite ammo weapons, more damage output, recovery items and more. I beat the game more than 10 times and I'm still having fun finding a new way to beat the game once again.

5- Speedrunning the game is really fun. I'm usually not a fan of speedrunning games but RE3R doesn't have long boring phases as we can have in RE Village with Beneviento's House or Moreau's Reservoir being dull to play after the first time.

6- Some cinematics would have been way better to play than to watch and there are some part of the game in which you just have to press W and press left click once.

7- Visually, this game is beautiful. Resident Evil games doesn't disappoint when it comes to graphism. Jill's and Carlos' looks are great, Nemesis looks like the scary pursuer it is.

In conclusion, Resident Evil 3 Remake is a good game that could have been better. You should really give this game a chance and try it because you will have a great time playing it. Not worth the full price, but worth the €15 RE2R + RE3R bundle when it's on sale!

If you are expecting a well made remake (Like Resident Evil 2 Remake) you are in for a few surprises. RE3 can't quite live up to its predecessor. Almost everything this game does right is packed in the beginning area of the game (downtown Raccoon City). The game's opening sequence, ammo scarcity, jump scares and constant chases by Nemesis (within Downtown area) are definitely its strongest points. 

Compared to the Good old RE3, some story elements were touched to bring them up to modern standards, which was a good call. On the other hand, I was expecting Nemesis to be more of an ever-present thread, Like RE 2's Mr. X or RE 7's Jack Baker or just like Nemesis was on its original run. 

The developers this time decided to remove a lot of the game's puzzles and a whole bunch of areas from the original ([u]Raccoon City Park, Graveryard, City Hall, Press Office, Clock Tower, Dead Factory[/u]), they also removed the branching paths and different endings based on the player's decision during cutscenes, in addition they also removed "The Mercenaries" and decided to rush Nemesis transformations so you are limited to basically two Chases and 4 boss fight with Nemesis, which is pretty much this game's identity. 

This game can be finished by someone new to the survival horror genre in about 7 hours, normally this short of a run time wouldn't be a problem if the game had different modes/reasons to replay (Like RE2's extra main scenarios) but they are not present. 

TL;DR: This is a visually stunning game updated to modern standards that suffers from [b]A LOT[/b]] of cut content and rushes the player to its ending without any sort of reason to replay it. Do yourself a favor a [b]wait for a sale[/b] before buying this game.

I loved the resident evil 2 remake (RE2), I loved the exploration aspects of the game and the item discovery along with the puzzle solving. The pacing of RE2 is very good as well, slowly building up the suspense and allowing you to absorb what is happening on screen while feeling the terror of being chased by Mr.X (Later on). Resident evil 3 remake (RE3) either lacks in these in some aspects or ignores them completely.

RE3 has exploration mechanics but all while you are getting chased constantly and hit without mercy. It's nearly impossible to dodge the new "big boss" Nemesis, and I hate how they changed it from the original. It has a new dodge mechanic that allows you to side step and roll out of the way if you hit it just right, but how do you dodge an enemy that is charging behind you that you cannot see? You can't most of the time which allows it to grant free hits on you.

Item discovery in RE3 is constant and boring. In RE2 you are able to take your time with looking around at the police station and finding items, while new storage upgrades/weapons are few and far between. In RE3 you are constantly running, only have time to explore your surroundings in brief instances and when it does slow down while you are doing the very childish puzzle solving as it just throws new items and upgrades at you. 

What makes all good Resident Evils great? The suspense and terror of not knowing what is around the corner, the close calls with enemies when you are 1 hit away from death, that breath of relief knowing you made it to a safe room in time when a licker was inches from your heels. Those are things RE2 had. In RE3 as stated before you are constantly being chased and hit at all times. It is annoying and not fun. I was stuck for 20-30 minutes on the third encounter with Nemesis just because he kept either grabbing me with his tongue or hit me from feet away when he charged. Why don't you just dodge it? Because like I said, its nearly impossible to hit the dodge roll at the right time when you can't even see him!

In its defense, I was only able to get as far as the subway leaving the station because it took me almost 2 hours to get there. I however, wanted a refund because of the fact I had nearly no fun while playing this game. The only good parts that I experienced while playing were looking at the stunning graphics for the brief moments that I could stand still and a brief part when you are turning on the power and these new scary spider zombies are chasing you.

I may buy this game in the future when it is on sale for the story, but as of right now I am not paying full price for a crappy run and gun simulator.

RE3 is an erotic game where half the monsters want to stick their tentacles inside Jill and the other half want to eat her... no, wait...

RE3 is a really good action horror game, though its short length prevents the game from being truly amazing as the player is limited to playing the same short campaign over and over again.

8/10 (if purchased at discount)
7/10 (if purchased at full price)

Pros
- The change in direction to be more action oriented doesn't completely eliminate the scare roots of RE2 remake, and it's a nice change of pace. Zombie encounters aren't as fun as human encounters in RE4, but it's still a very fun action horror game in its own right.
- Dodge system is an excellent addition and the game gets really fun once you get good at it. If the game were longer, this could have easily been my favorite RE game thanks to the dodge system.
- Letting players choose unlockables with currencies is a very nice idea. Getting specific unlocks in RE2 remake was incredibly stressful. RE3's system allows casual players to obtain many of their favorite unlocks without stress. In fact, since you're allowed to use infinite weapons to obtain S-rank in higher difficulties, getting all unlockables was much more enjoyable and casual compared to RE2 remake.
- The shop has some interesting items that allows the player to customize their gameplay a bit. Some items give health regen, some give more damage, there's an item that makes dodging easier, etc. It's better than the typical infinite ammo unlocks you see in most RE games.
- Nightmare and Inferno difficulties have different spawns, which freshens things up a bit.
- Graphics and overall atmosphere are very nice.
- Unlike RE2 remake, characters no longer use plastic knives. :P

Cons
- The game is too short. Supposedly, they cut a lot of contents from classic RE3 (I never played classic RE3). Even with the shop items varying things a bit, the player is still restricted to the same short campaign. This is a shame because the game is so good.
- Nemesis is disappointing compared to the Tyrant in RE2 remake. There are only a few parts where the Nemesis chases the player and all of these are short scripted events. By comparison, RE2's Tyrant dynamically chases the player throughout many parts of the game. Nemesis was supposed to be the big thing for RE3, so it's a big shame to see it reduced to this.
- Not having checkpoints for boss fights makes it frustrating to learn to fight a boss in harder difficulties as you need to constantly run back to the boss and skip cutscenes.
- Needs a random mode that randomizes the location of items and enemies. Once the player has the game memorized, the game loses its scare factor.
